```
#!/Users/travis/build/MacPython/numpy-wheels/venv/bin/python
```

title: numpy.random.vonmises documentation contains incorrect code example.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Ogaday', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6689770?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Ogaday', 'type': u'User', 'id': 6689770, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Ogaday/followers'}
body:
The numpy.random [reference](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.random.vonmises.html) for the von Mises distribution contains an incorrect code sample (pasted below).

```python
mu, kappa = 0.0, 4.0 # mean and dispersion
s = np.random.vonmises(mu, kappa, 1000)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import scipy.special as sps
count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 50, normed=True)
x = np.arange(-np.pi, np.pi, 2*np.pi/50.)
y = -np.exp(kappa*np.cos(x-mu))/(2*np.pi*sps.jn(0,kappa))
plt.plot(x, y/max(y), linewidth=2, color='r')
plt.show()
```

While this works for the example, line 5 doesn't concur with the definition of the von Mises probability density function, given above the example. According to documentation about the [special functions] (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/special.html#module-scipy.special), the modified bessel function of order real order is given by scipy.special.iv(). Using that function instead means the sign doesn't need to be changed.

I noticed the problem when I tried to emulate the code and I found that area under the pdf didn't sum to 1 when I used the trapezium rule and would sometimes even go below the x axis, when neither the exponential function or the bessel function should ever be negative. Compare:

```python
#incorrect, according to documentation

import numpy as np
import scipy.special as sps
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
tau = np.pi*2

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1, figsize = (10,8))

n = 10
xs = np.linspace(0, 4, n)     #create a range of kappas

mu = 0
m = 50
width = tau/float(m)
sums = np.empty(n)    #for storing the integrals under the curves for different kappas

for i in range(n):
    kappa = xs[i]
    x = np.linspace(-np.pi, np.pi, m)
    y = -np.exp(kappa*np.cos(x-mu))/(tau*sps.jn(0,kappa))
    ax.plot(x, y, label="kappa = {}".format(kappa))
    sums[i] = sum([(y[j]+y[j+1])/2*width for j in range(m-1)])
ax.set_axes("tight")
ax.legend()
print "the area under the pdf for different kappas: "
for i in range(n):
    print "kappa =", xs[i], ", integral =", sums[i]
fig.show()
```

```python
#correct, using the correct bessel function

import numpy as np
import scipy.special as sps
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
tau = np.pi*2

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1, figsize = (10,8))

n = 10
xs = np.linspace(0, 4, n)     #create a range of kappas

mu = 0
m = 50
width = tau/float(m)
sums = np.empty(n)    #for storing the integrals under the curves for different kappas

for i in range(n):
    kappa = xs[i]
    x = np.linspace(-np.pi, np.pi, m)
    y = np.exp(kappa*np.cos(x-mu))/(tau*sps.iv(0,kappa))
    ax.plot(x, y, label="kappa = {}".format(kappa))
    sums[i] = sum([(y[j]+y[j+1])/2*width for j in range(m-1)])
ax.set_axes("tight")
ax.legend()
print "the area under the pdf for different kappas: "
for i in range(n):
    print "kappa =", xs[i], ", integral =", sums[i]
fig.show()
```

Excuse my use of tau.

Using: Python 2.7.9 :: Anaconda 2.2.0 (64-bit), IPython 3.1.0, numpy 1.9.2

title: Generator for normally distributed random numbers that reproduces MATLAB
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Shambricool', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/11981051?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Shambricool', 'type': u'User', 'id': 11981051, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Shambricool/followers'}
body:
We've faced the problem of reproducing MATLAB's randn() while porting a project from MATLAB to Python (see this issue https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/4666). The solution that worked for us was to use MATLAB Coder for generating a C code for randn() function and wrapping it as a C extension to Python.
MATLAB uses Ziggurat method for generating gaussian random numbers and there were a lot of proposals here to implement it. Maybe the code generated by MATALB Coder could be used by numpy for implementing Ziggurat in numpy?
A project with a C extension for Python can be found here https://github.com/Shambricool/py_matlab_randn

body:
All elements of the array generated by `numpy.arange(start, stop, step)` should be strictly smaller than `stop`.

On my Ubuntu 14.04 installation this happened: 
```
In [117]: np.arange(0.5, 0.8, 0.1)
Out[117]: array([ 0.5,  0.6,  0.7,  0.8])

In [118]: np.arange(0.5, 0.9, 0.1)
Out[118]: array([ 0.5,  0.6,  0.7,  0.8])

In [123]: np.arange(0.5, 0.8, 0.1)[-1]
Out[123]: 0.79999999999999993

In [124]: np.arange(0.5, 0.9, 0.1)[-1]
Out[124]: 0.79999999999999993
```
Is this an issue on other installations?

It works fine when running the same code in the terminal Interpreter on the phone, or in pyotherside on the desktop, it does not matter how big the attempted fit is (it does not simply run out of memory)
To investigate further, running the debugger on polyfit(a,b,1,w=c) showed me the last few lines before also freezing:

    (Pdb)

    (Pdb) 
    > /usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/core/machar.py(224)_do_init()

    (Pdb) 
    > /usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/core/machar.py(225)_do_init()

    (Pdb) 

Has anyone an idea what could be causing this?
I havent seen any bug like this yet.
To reproduce, I created a quick demo:
[numpy bug showcase](https://github.com/dasimmet/numpy-polyfit-bug-on-jolla-)
run the installed app with sailfish-numpy in terminal on the jolla and press the button, it should bring up the python debugger.

the version of numpy I use is built by installing dependencies and running "pip wheel numpy" on the jolla phone, then extracted into the app dir.

title: ix_() returned array has dtype=float64 when given empty range
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/chkothe', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5318120?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'chkothe', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5318120, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chkothe/followers'}
body:
```
>>> np.ix_(range(0,0))
(array([], dtype=float64),)
```
The correct dtype should be int32, since float indices are usually not accepted as indices in numpy arrays. That dtype is returned for non-empty ranges:
```
>>> np.ix_(range(0,1))[0].dtype
dtype('int32')
```

title: BUG: Fixes random.noncentral_chisquare when 0 < df <= 1
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/behzadnouri', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1288998?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'behzadnouri', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1288998, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/behzadnouri/followers'}
body:
Closes #5766.

For sanity check, this is a comparison of theoretical cumulant-generating function and the emprical one at 3 different values for degree of freedom:

```
# cumulant-generating function
cgf = lambda t, df, nonc: nonc * t / (1 - 2*t) - .5 * df * np.log(1 - 2*t)

size, nonc = 1 << 26, .01
t = np.linspace(-.5, .5, 50, endpoint=False)

for df in .1, .5, .9:
    a = np.random.noncentral_chisquare(df, nonc, size)
    y = np.fromiter((np.exp(a * x).mean(axis=0) for x in t[1::3]), 'f8')
    l, = plt.plot(t, cgf(t, df, nonc), label='df: {}'.format(df))
    plt.plot(t[1::3], np.log(y), l.get_color() + 'o', label='_nolegend_')
```
![ffig2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1288998/7334529/0e8e9682-eb64-11e4-9858-af058db122ca.png)

same plots with `nonc = 2`:
![ffig3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1288998/7334532/263639a2-eb64-11e4-8d12-92821bd5fa03.png)

title: BUG: numpy.arctan returns nan for large complex arguments
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pbrod', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1193469?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pbrod', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1193469, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pbrod/followers'}
body:
The cmath.atan  is able to handle large complex values

    >>> import numpy as np
    >>> import cmath
    >>> t = -1.10076957173e+292+0j
    >>> cmath.atan(t)
    Out[37]: (-1.5707963267948966+0j) 
    >>> cmath.atan(1j*t)
    Out[38]: (-1.5707963267948966-9.084553440447778e-293j)

while numpy.arctan does not as shown here:

    >>> np.arctan(t)
    Out[39]: (nan+nan*j)
    np.arctan(1j*t)
    Out[40]: (nan+nan*j)

title: An error in odeint program
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ocean164347', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/12109547?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ocean164347', 'type': u'User', 'id': 12109547, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ocean164347/followers'}
body:
I wrote a program to use odeint to solve a differential equation. But it had a problem. When I setted Cosmopara as np.array([70.0,0.3,0,-1.0,0]), it gave a warning that "invalid value encountered in sqrt" and "invalid value encountered in double_scalars" in "h = np.sqrt(y1 ** 2 + Omega_M * t ** (-3) + Omega_DE*y2)". But I checked that line and didn't find any error. If Cosmopara = np.array([70.0,0.3,0.0,-1.0,0.0]), Y shouldn't change but it changed. Besides, If I chose Cosmopara = np.array([70.0,0.3,0.1,-1.0,0.1]), this program could give a right result. I don't know why. So please help me. Followwing is my program.

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.integrate import odeint

global CosmoPara
Cosmopara = np.array([70.0,0.3,0.0,-1.0,0.0])

def derivfun(Y,t):
    Omega_M = Cosmopara[1]
    Sigma_0 = Cosmopara[2]
    omega = Cosmopara[3]
    delta = Cosmopara[4]
    Omega_DE = 1-Omega_M-Sigma_0 ** 2
    y1 = Y[0]
    y2 = Y[1]
    h = np.sqrt(y1 ** 2 + Omega_M * t ** (-3) + Omega_DE * y2)
    dy1dt = -3.0 * y1/t + (delta * Omega_DE * y2)/(t * h)
    dy2dt = -(3.0 * (1+omega) + 2.0 * delta * y1/h) * y2/t
    return np.array([dy1dt,dy2dt])
    
z = np.linspace(1,2.5,15001)
time = 1.0/z
Omega_M = Cosmopara[1]
Sigma_0 = Cosmopara[2]
omega = Cosmopara[3]
delta = Cosmopara[4]
Omega_DE = 1-Omega_M-Sigma_0 ** 2
y1init = Sigma_0
y2init = 1
Yinit = np.array([y1init,y2init])

Y = odeint(derivfun,Yinit,time)

y1 = Y[:,0]
y2 = Y[:,1]

h = np.sqrt(y1 ** 2 + Omega_M * time ** (-3) + Omega_DE * y2)

plt.figure()
plt.plot(z,h)
plt.show()

body:
I try to reshape a large array. numpy.reshape returns 

ValueError: total size of new array must be unchanged

I couldn't find it, but is it possible that there is a overflow of np.prod in the source code?
I checked the shapes and they are certainly ok! I read in a from a binary file and if I increase the size, the error sets in, where it was lacking at the beginning.

title: dtype "f64" silently results in "float32"
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cdeil', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/852409?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cdeil', 'type': u'User', 'id': 852409, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cdeil/followers'}
body:
I've recently been bitten by this:
```python
>>> import numpy as np
>>> np.dtype('f64')
dtype('float32')
>>> np.__version__
'1.9.2'
```

Some proposals what to change:
1.  Warning for `'f64'` input?
2.  Error for `'f64'` input?
3.  Make 'f64' result in 'float64'

I know change is difficult for numpy because of backwards-compatibility concerns.
Hopefully it's possible to be more strict here ... in my code I was getting slightly incorrect results for half a year because I was using 32-bit floats where I know I needed to use 64-bit floats, but for some reason wrote "f64" instead of "float64".

title: BUG: fix instability of structured dtype hash
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pitrou', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1721820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pitrou', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1721820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/followers'}
body:
The hash value of a structured dtype was dependent on iteration order
of the fields mapping, which could make (in rare conditions) two
equal dtypes hash to different values.  We now consider the fields
in deterministic order, according to the names property.

Closes #5715.

(note this PR also removes a few oddities in reference counting)

title: Int32 overflow when creating array from large list
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/psinger', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1677826?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'psinger', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1677826, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/psinger/followers'}
body:
When trying to create an array from a huge list, I receive the following error:

ValueError: negative dimensions are not allowed

After some debugging, I found that it seems to be a problem with some INT32 overflow in the C code of numpy. So you can quite easily reproduce the error the following way:

```python
In [25]: l = range(2147483647)

In [26]: x = np.array(l)

In [27]: del x

In [28]: l = range(2147483648)

In [29]: x = np.array(l)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-29-ec8d2fa9a1ea> in <module>()
----> 1 x = np.array(l)

ValueError: negative dimensions are not allowed
```

title: abs() of numpy floating-point scalar fails on signed zeros
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pitrou', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1721820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pitrou', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1721820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/followers'}
body:
```
>>> np.float64(-0.0)
-0.0
>>> abs(np.float64(-0.0))
-0.0
```

Compare with:
```
>>> abs(-0.0)
0.0
```

np.abs() seems to get it right:
```
>>> np.abs(np.float64(-0.0))
0.0
```

```
>>> arr = np.array([1.5-2.5j])
>>> out = np.zeros_like(arr)

array([ 2.-2.j])

array([ 0.+0.j])

array([ 0.+0.j])
```

title: Hide testing helper tracebacks when using them with pytest
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ml31415', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2386612?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ml31415', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2386612, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ml31415/followers'}
body:
I'm using the nice helper functions from `numpy.testing` for a bunch of own testing modules. Tests there run with pytest. Unfortunately so far errors are totally cluttered up with backtraces from within the testing module itself. pytest supports a simple function marker, to hide the tracebacks of these assert helpers. This patch adds these markers to the testing utils.

It shouldn't have any downsides and be hopefully side effects free, and would greatly improve the life of combined numpy and pytest users ;-)

induced by array_split, not just the final partition sub_arys[-1].

title: ENH: add options for disabling use of pickle in load/save
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pv', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/35046?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pv', 'type': u'User', 'id': 35046, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/followers'}
body:
Following the [discussion on the mailing list](http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.python.numeric.general/60071), add options to `np.load` and `np.save` for disallowing use of pickle.

Very good reason for not using pickle on loading is security (arbitrary code execution), and a good reason for not using it on saving is enforcing portability (pickles are not portable; e.g. they are generally incompatible between Py2 and Py3).

This doesn't add the options to `savez*`, since the API for those is such that adding kwargs cannot be cleanly done.

I didn't add `allow_pickle` to the end of kwarg lists, as the `encoding`, `fix_imports` kwargs have not been included in a released version yet.

Changing the default value to `allow_pickle=False` could make sense, but that probably has not insignificant backward compat issues, so I won't consider it here.

title: Can't find gfortan on RHEL 6.4
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ewmoore', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2314641?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ewmoore', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2314641, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.distutils', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.distutils'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20high', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: high'}]
body:
I cannot build Scipy against a current numpy on RHEL 6.4.  Running `gfortran --version` or `gfortran -dumpversion` both provide the same output:
```
GNU Fortran (GCC) 4.4.7 20120313 (Red Hat 4.4.7-3)
Copyright (C) 2010 Free Software Foundation, Inc.

GNU Fortran comes with NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.
You may redistribute copies of GNU Fortran
under the terms of the GNU General Public License.
For more information about these matters, see the file named COPYING
```

This has to do with the changes made to how gnu fortran compilers are detected in #5333. Going back to  8a2dd0680e8470aab7ad63622c0d0af703f58d42 works. 

This isn't the newest RHEL, but it is still in the full support phase.

title: issubdtype(None, float) == issubdtype(np.float64, None) == True ??
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/bskinn', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/11325439?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'bskinn', 'type': u'User', 'id': 11325439, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bskinn/followers'}
body:
Using Python 2.7.6 & numpy 1.8.1, passing `None` and either `float` or a `numpy.float#` subtype to `issubdtype` always yields `True`:

    >>> np.issubdtype(None, float)
    True
    >>> np.issubdtype(float, None)
    True
    >>> np.issubdtype(np.float64, None)
    True
    >>> np.issubdtype(None, np.float64)
    True

If I understand the nature of `NoneType` correctly, it seems to me that `issubdtype` should return `False` in all cases where `None` is passed to either argument, save for when `None` is passed as both arguments.  `np.issubdtype(None, int)` yields `False`, as I would expect.

Apologies if I'm misunderstanding, or if this has been fixed between 1.8.1 and 1.9.2.

title: Cannot generate random variates from noncentral chi-square distribution with dof = 1
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/xiaoweiz', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4540215?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'xiaoweiz', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4540215, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/xiaoweiz/followers'}
body:
The issue is a duplicate of scipy/scipy#4720 

The [document](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.random.noncentral_chisquare.html#numpy.random.noncentral_chisquare)  suggests that the parameter _degree of freedom_ should be `df >= 1` to use `numpy.random.noncentral_chisquare`. However, taking `df = 1` raises error. 

```python
import numpy as np
df = 1
nc = 2
np.random.noncentral_chisquare(df, nc)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-7c9f3f6a3a16> in <module>()
----> 1 np.random.noncentral_chisquare(df, nc)

mtrand.pyx in mtrand.RandomState.noncentral_chisquare (numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.c:15618)()

ValueError: df <= 0
```

It makes me suspect that the random variate generation of the noncentral chi-square distribution with degree of freedom `df` and noncentrality parameter `nc` is implemented in numpy using a method similar to the following.
```python
np.random.chisquare(df-1) + (np.random.standard_normal()+np.sqrt(nc))**2
```
However, this method is valid only for the case where `df > 1` because with `df = 1`, it needs to generate a chi-square random variate with degree of freedom 0, which is not mathematically well-defined.

On the other hand, noncentral chi-square distribution is indeed mathematically well-defined for all `df > 0`. It simply requires a different algorithm for random variate generation if `0 < df <= 1`, such as the following one: 
```python
np.random.chisquare(df + 2*np.random.poisson(nc / 2.0))
```

body:
This looks like a very old bug - ever since msvc9 was introduced.

Known (to me) cases which triggered the issue on win32:
* The Python install path contained spaces.
* site.cfg library_dirs contained paths with spaces.

Build would fail in the link stage with an error similar to "Files.obj cannot be found".

Any suggestions on how to implement a test for this?

title: NumPy "dot" hangs when used with multiprocessing (potentially Apple Accelerate related?)
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/josePhoenix', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/172886?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'josePhoenix', 'type': u'User', 'id': 172886, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/josePhoenix/followers'}
body:
I'm having a devil of a time making a minimal test case, but this seems to be my issue: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23963997/python-child-process-crashes-on-numpy-dot-if-pyside-is-imported

In my case, I have code that farms out a bunch of calculations, including matrix products to a `multiprocessing.Pool` with `pool.map`. The computation hangs partway through, and some hacky `print`-based debugging shows it hanging on a call to `np.dot` down in the guts of the program. 

Replacing `pool.map` with the built-in (serial) `map` makes everything work.

I used not to have this issue, then something changed (lunar eclipse?) and now my computation hangs consistently whenever multiprocessing is used. A minimal test case continues to elude me. (It's not enough to simply generate 10 random NxN arrays and dot them in a `multiprocessing`-based way.)

```
>>> numpy.show_config()
lapack_opt_info:
    extra_link_args = ['-Wl,-framework', '-Wl,Accelerate']
    extra_compile_args = ['-msse3', '-DAPPLE_ACCELERATE_SGEMV_PATCH']

body:
Naively, I would expect that these have the same syntax, but they don't....

It would be nice if someone could make their syntax consistent.


In [23]: np.repeat(vec3, 2)
Out[23]: array([-1., -1., -2., -2., -3., -3.], dtype=float32)

In [24]: np.tile(vec3, 2)
Out[24]: array([-1., -2., -3., -1., -2., -3.], dtype=float32)

In [25]: np.tile(vec3, (2,))
Out[25]: array([-1., -2., -3., -1., -2., -3.], dtype=float32)

In [26]: np.repeat(vec3, (2,))
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-26-ddd537e03337> in <module>()
----> 1 np.repeat(vec3, (2,))

/u/lisa/local/export.soft.lisa.master/linux-x86_64-fc14.x86_64_v3/canopy/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/fromnumeric.pyc in repeat(a, repeats, axis)
    388     except AttributeError:
    389         return _wrapit(a, 'repeat', repeats, axis)
--> 390     return repeat(repeats, axis)
    391 
    392 

ValueError: a.shape[axis] != len(repeats)

title: random.multivariate_normal doesn't work in 1d case
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/iuventus', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/11708501?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'iuventus', 'type': u'User', 'id': 11708501, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/iuventus/followers'}
body:
I don't think a mathematician would write a multivariate function that doesn't work in the particular case of n = 1. 

I've written code that in several places generates correlated normals with a given covariance matrix, but I now need to re-write the code to handle the special case in which the incoming data is one-dimensional. 

I consider this a bug, because I cannot imagine why anyone would design it like that.

title: some numpy linalg matrix norms do not like negative axes
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/argriffing', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/101416?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'argriffing', 'type': u'User', 'id': 101416, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.linalg', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.linalg'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}]
body:
```python
>>> import numpy as np
>>> np.__version__
'1.10.0.dev0+a4cd474'
>>> I = np.eye(4)
>>> np.linalg.norm(I, axis=(0, 1))
2.0
>>> np.linalg.norm(I, axis=(-2, -1))
2.0
>>> np.linalg.norm(I, 'fro', axis=(-2, -1))
2.0
>>> np.linalg.norm(I, 1, axis=(0, 1))
1.0
>>> np.linalg.norm(I, 1, axis=(1, 0))
1.0
>>> np.linalg.norm(I, 1, axis=(-2, -1))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "[...]/numpy/linalg/linalg.py", line 2161, in norm
    ret = add.reduce(abs(x), axis=row_axis).max(axis=col_axis)
  File "[...]/numpy/core/_methods.py", line 26, in _amax
    return umr_maximum(a, axis, None, out, keepdims)
ValueError: 'axis' entry is out of bounds
```

title: DOC: Covariance matrix should be symmetric
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cowlicks', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/598099?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cowlicks', 'type': u'User', 'id': 598099, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/followers'}
body: Fix a typo in `random.multivariate_normal.__doc__` where a non-symmetric matrix is used as the covariance matrix. The covariance matrix is specified to be symmetric [here](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/c0c6690d0cdfe820d14d5d8520ddd999c32a156a/numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.pyx#L4231).

title: segfault while casting rational dtype
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cowlicks', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/598099?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cowlicks', 'type': u'User', 'id': 598099, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/followers'}
body:
On numpy master and numpy-types master.
```python
In [1]: import numpy, npytypes.rational

In [2]: numpy.array([npytypes.rational.rational(1111)]).astype('int8')
[1]    4639 segmentation fault  ipython
```
Instead, this should raise an overflow error.

This could possibly related to this [issue #3359](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/3359).

title: Possible bug with multiple views and basic slicing
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ebolyen', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3976804?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ebolyen', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3976804, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ebolyen/followers'}
body:
We were able to reproduce this in numpy 1.8.1 and 1.9.2. When given a slice from the beginning of the array (relative to the end) to some other point (also relative to the end) with a step size greater than 1, we receive a view which appears to operate as expected. However, when this view is viewed as an `|S<n>` dtype where `<n>` is greater than 1 we receive a `ValueError`:

```python
In [1]:import numpy as np

In [2]: char_array = np.fromstring("ABCDEFG", dtype='|S1')

In [3]: char_array.size
Out[3]: 7

In [4]: char_array.view('|S7')
Out[4]: 
array(['ABCDEFG'], 
      dtype='|S7')

In [5]: sliced = char_array[-7:-3:2]

In [6]: sliced
Out[6]: 
array(['A', 'C'], 
      dtype='|S1')

In [7]: sliced.size
Out[7]: 2

In [8]: sliced.view('|S2')
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-8-8887abf56c24> in <module>()
----> 1 sliced.view('|S2')

ValueError: new type not compatible with array.

In [9]: sliced.dtype
Out[9]: dtype('S1')

In [10]: sliced.copy().view('|S2')
Out[10]: 
array(['AC'], 
      dtype='|S2')
```

Changing the slice step to 1 works as expected. Performing a copy and then creating a view will also work as expected.

title: record dtype hashing is fragile
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pitrou', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1721820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pitrou', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1721820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/followers'}
body:
When pickling and unpickling a record type, hash equality can fail sporadically (tested under Python 3.4). If you take this script:

```
import pickle
import numpy as np

ty = np.dtype([('a', np.float64),
               ('b', np.int32),
               ('c', np.complex64),
               ('d', (np.str, 5))])

newty = pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(ty))
assert hash(newty) == hash(ty), (ty == newty, ty.fields, newty.fields)
```

and run it in a loop (e.g. `while python nprecbug.py; do :; done`), eventually you'll hit a failure:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "nprecbug.py", line 12, in <module>
    assert hash(newty) == hash(ty), (ty == newty, ty.fields, newty.fields)
AssertionError: (True, mappingproxy({'b': (dtype('int32'), 8), 'd': (dtype('<U5'), 20), 'a': (dtype('float64'), 0), 'c': (dtype('complex64'), 12)}), mappingproxy({'b': (dtype('int32'), 8), 'c': (dtype('complex64'), 12), 'a': (dtype('float64'), 0), 'd': (dtype('<U5'), 20)}))
```

As you can see, `__hash__` seems to be sensitive to the ordering of fields in the mappingproxy. By contrast, `__eq__` does the right thing.

title: BUG: Fix advanced object non-array value assignment
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
If the value array in an advanced indexing assignment was a non-array
and the array being assigned to is an object array, a temporary
array is created to make the object assignment work well like
slicing in general.
However, this array was created with the swapping of the mapiter
object. So we have to swap it back as if it was an array being
subscripted with MapIterSwapAxes.

---

This is seems like a pretty bad bug, though then again I am impressed nobody noticed, since most of the time it should just make code fail....

title: ENH: Improve np.ma.compress_rowcols() performance, ENH: add compress_nd()
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ddasilva', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/536378?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ddasilva', 'type': u'User', 'id': 536378, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/followers'}
body:
I found that `np.ma.compress_rowcols()` was extremely too slow for my use case of a 2x1036800 matrix. I traced the problem back to the underlying algorithm being of runtime O(N^2 + M^2). I made a simple modification which reduces this to O(NLogN + MLogM), which solved my use case.

This improvement was done by replacing the underlying data structures used to hold valid indeces from lists to sets. It converts back to lists when array slicing is done.

Also, I noticed this error message might be outdated. Did this function used to be called `compress2d`?
``        raise NotImplementedError("compress2d works for 2D arrays only.")``

title: Occasional wildly incorrect results from numpy.linalg.lstsq

title: Numerical precision inconsistency in np.linalg.norm (vector vs. matrix)
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/maciejkula', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2392579?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'maciejkula', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2392579, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/maciejkula/followers'}
body:
There is a slight numerical inconsistency in `np.linalg.norm` in evaluating the length of vectors vs. the column-wise or row-wise length of matrices.

Minimal example to reproduce on 1.9.1:
```
import numpy as np

x = np.random.rand(100)
np.linalg.norm(x) == np.linalg.norm(np.vstack([x]), axis=1)[0]
```
Prints:
```
Out[27]: False
```
The last few digits of the output do not agree.

I understand this passes from the `allclose` perspective, but in some applications it is extremely surprising and hard to debug. I encountered this when writing an approximate nearest neighbour lookup tree and realising points were not being assigned to the same leaf nodes depending on whether I used the one-vector-at-a-time or matrix-based approach.

Numpy 1.8.1 gives the same result in both cases.

title: Mean of dtype object array works sometimes
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/amueller', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/449558?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'amueller', 'type': u'User', 'id': 449558, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/amueller/followers'}
body:
Hi.
We ran into this at scikit-learn and it is more of an integration/testing issue than anything else.
It boils down to this expression:
```python
np.arange(10).astype(object).mean(axis=0)
```
which either produces ``4.5`` or raises an error. I'd like to know what causes the error, in which version it is, and how to robustly test for it.
Maybe I'm overlooking something, but testing it on several platforms, what I get is this:

```
Ubuntu 12.04 + Py 2.7.3 + np 1.6.1 == Pass
Ubuntu 12.04 + Py 2.6.9 + np 1.6.2 == Pass
Ubuntu 12.04 + Py 3.4.3 + np 1.9.2 == Pass

Ubuntu 14.04 + Py 2.7.9 + np 1.8.0 == Fail
Ubuntu 14.04 + Py 2.7.9 + np 1.9.2 == Pass

OSX Yosemite + Py 2.7.6 + np 1.9.0 == Fail
OSX Yosemite + Py 2.7.6 + np 1.9.1 == Fail
OSX Yosemite + Py 2.7.6 + np 1.9.2 == Fail
OSX Yosemite + Py 2.7.9 + np 1.9.2 == Pass

Ubuntu 14.04 + Py 2.7.3 + np 1.6.1 == Pass
Ubuntu 14.04 + Py 2.7.6 + np 1.8.0 == Fail
Ubuntu 14.04 + Py 2.7.6 + np 1.9.0 == Pass
```
So even for the same Python and numpy version, the behavior is different between Ubuntu and OS X.

Any help would be much appreciated.
cc @trevorstephens

title: tanh has problems with large complex numbers
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mieswicht', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3873559?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mieswicht', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3873559, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mieswicht/followers'}
body:
Hi,

when working with complex impedance data, i encountered an issue and narrowed it down to:

>>> from numpy import *
>>> x=(616.47292227535877+53.814558958179042j)

>>> tanh(x)

Warning (from warnings module):
  File "C:\python\Test\Impedance class reduced.py", line 1
    from numpy import *
RuntimeWarning: overflow encountered in tanh

Warning (from warnings module):
  File "C:\python\Test\Impedance class reduced.py", line 1
    from numpy import *
RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in tanh

When actually, it should return (1-0j), see http://tinyurl.com/nm4goq3
Then i tried
>>> sinh(x)/cosh(x)

Warning (from warnings module):
  File "C:\python\Test\Impedance class reduced.py", line 1
    from numpy import *
RuntimeWarning: overflow encountered in cdouble_scalars

Warning (from warnings module):
  File "C:\python\Test\Impedance class reduced.py", line 1
    from numpy import *
RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in cdouble_scalars
(nan+nan*j)

However, the solution was to use numpy.divide:

>>> divide(sinh(x),cosh(x))
(1-0j)

This took me quite some time to figure out, so i guess it would be a good idea to include it in the next release (maybe even with with coth?).

Thanks a lot!

title: BUG: deprecation for ignored corrcoef args
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/matthew-brett', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/67612?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'matthew-brett', 'type': u'User', 'id': 67612, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.lib', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.lib'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.ma', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.ma'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Deprecate', 'color': u'009800', 'name': u'Deprecate'}]
body:
The `ddof` and `bias` arguments to `corrcoef` cancel in the math of the 
correlation coefficient, so there is no point in passing these values, and it
is confusing to the user to see these in the docstring.

Remove, deprecate, and test.

When the `bias` argument goes away, we will need to make the
`allow_masked` argument to `ma.corrcoef` into a keyword-only argument; warn
about this change.

title: `numpy.where` and `numpy.ma.where` are inconsistent when using `None` as a scalar
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jakirkham', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3019665?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jakirkham', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3019665, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakirkham/followers'}
body:
Two pull requests have been offered ( https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/5582 ) ( https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/5583 ) to address the inconsistency. Below are four examples.

    >>> import numpy
    >>> numpy.where(True)
    ... (array([0]),)
    >>> numpy.where(True, None, None)
    ... array(None, dtype=object)
    >>> numpy.ma.where(True)
    ... (array([0]),)
    >>> numpy.ma.where(True, None, None)
    ... (array([0]),)

It it worth noting that it doesn't matter if the first argument (the conditional) is an array or scalar. The inconsistency regards the use of `None` as a scalar, which is currently permitted by `numpy.where`, but not by `numpy.ma.where`.

title: argsort (..., axis=None) doesn't use flattened array for 0d inputs.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mdickinson', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/662003?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mdickinson', 'type': u'User', 'id': 662003, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/followers'}
body:
There seems to be an inconsistency in `numpy.argsort` with respect to zero-dimensional arrays when `axis=None`.  The docs for the `axis` parameter say:

> If None, the flattened array is used.

But for a 0d array, this doesn't seem to be true: I get a scalar out where I expected a 1d array
```
In [29]: x = np.array(5)

In [30]: np.argsort(x, axis=None)
Out[30]: 0

In [31]: np.argsort(x.ravel(), axis=None)
Out[31]: array([0])
```

I'd expect both `Out[30]` and `Out[31]` above to give me `array([0])`.  For 2d arrays, the results are the same with and without explicit flattening, as expected:

```
In [32]: x = np.array([[6, 7], [1, 4]])

In [33]: np.argsort(x, axis=None)
Out[33]: array([2, 3, 0, 1])

In [34]: np.argsort(x.ravel(), axis=None)
Out[34]: array([2, 3, 0, 1])
```

title: MRG: deprecate ddof / bias args to corrcoef
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/matthew-brett', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/67612?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'matthew-brett', 'type': u'User', 'id': 67612, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matthew-brett/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.lib', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.lib'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.ma', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.ma'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Deprecate', 'color': u'009800', 'name': u'Deprecate'}]
body:
As discussed on the mailing list, the values for the bias and ddof
arguments to the corrcoef cancel in calculation, and are therefore
pointless and confusing.

Deprecate these arguments and document their pending removal.

This PR also includes a version of the warnings.catch_warnings decorator
that allows warnings to be tested for multiple times without error.

title: Ufunc override should normalize the sig keyword argument
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
Opening this as a reminder of unfinished work after merging #5659.

The ufunc override mechanism should make sure that, if `sig` is part of the keyword arguments, it gets normalized to `signature`.

It may also be a good idea to make `signature` the keyword argument announced in the docs, with a small footnote saying that `sig` is also acceptable for backwards compatibility reasons, rather than having them advertised as equally valid alternatives.

title: Segmentation fault when creating a nargs>32 ufunc using frompyfunc in numpy 1.9.2
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhauru', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5229876?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhauru', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5229876, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhauru/followers'}
body:
Title says most of it, here's a minimal example:

faulter.py reads
```python
import numpy as np
print('numpy version:', np.version.version)

def passer(*args):
    pass

for i in (31,32):
    print('\ni =',i)
    vctrzd = np.frompyfunc(passer, i, 1)
    print('about to do it')
    vctrzd(*(np.random.rand(1),)*i)
    print('done')
```
In 1.8.2 this is handled nicely, as when I run this with my /usr/bin/python3 I just get a ValueError:
```
numpy version: 1.8.2

i = 31
about to do it
done

i = 32
about to do it
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "faulter.py", line 11, in <module>
    vctrzd(*(np.random.rand(1),)*i)
ValueError: Cannot construct an iterator with more than 32 operands (33 were requested)
```

However, I have a virtualenv with the numpy 1.9.2. and there this happens:
```
numpy version: 1.9.2

i = 31
about to do it
done

i = 32
about to do it
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

If I run this in an interactive gdb session using
```
gdb env/bin/python3
(gdb) r faulter.py
```
I get
```
[Thread debugging using libthread_db enabled]
Using host libthread_db library "/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libthread_db.so.1".
[New Thread 0x7ffff3b90700 (LWP 9139)]
[New Thread 0x7ffff338f700 (LWP 9140)]
[New Thread 0x7ffff0b8e700 (LWP 9141)]
numpy version: 1.9.2

i = 31
about to do it
done

i = 32
about to do it

Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x00007ffff63e3189 in PyUFunc_GenericFunction (ufunc=0x0, args=0x12, args@entry=0x7fffeb2f6c28, 
    kwds=kwds@entry=0x0, op=0x7fffffffd5d0) at numpy/core/src/umath/ufunc_object.c:2535
2535	numpy/core/src/umath/ufunc_object.c: No such file or directory.
```

I'm running Ubuntu 14.10 and python 3.4.2. The system-wide installation that has numpy 1.8.2. came from the Ubuntu binary repositories where as the virtualenv one with numpy 1.9.2. was installed with pip.

Let me know if more details are needed/helpful.

body:
Modified the generic sort functions, npy_quicksort, npy_heapsort
and npy_mergesort, to have a signature compatible with the other
sort functions. Got rid of the global compare ugliness, and
refactored PyArray_Sort and PyArray_Partition to use the new
functions through a call to _new_sortlike.

title: einsum - double diagonal fails when combined with contraction
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/aherrmann', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/732652?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'aherrmann', 'type': u'User', 'id': 732652, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/aherrmann/followers'}
body:
`einsum` has the ability to contract indices, but also to extract diagonals between indices. A combination of the two should also be possible.

E.g. if we have an array of shape (2,3,3) we can contract the first index, and take the diagonal between the last two as follows:

```python
>>> x = np.zeros((2,3,3))
>>> np.einsum('tii->i', x).shape
(3,)
```

However, it fails if we take more than one diagonal. E.g.:

```python
>>> x = np.zeros((2,3,3,4,4))
>>> np.einsum('tiijj->ij', x).shape
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<ipython-input-30-4ab3a3e6fc50>", line 1, in <module>
    np.einsum('tiijj->ij', x).shape
ValueError: dimensions in operand 0 for collapsing index 'j' don't match (0 != 4)
```

To me, this seems like a bug because the same thing works if we just change the order of the axes:

```python
>>> x = np.zeros((3,3,4,4,2))
>>> np.einsum('iijjt->ijt', x).shape
(3, 4, 2)
```

---

Tested on NumPy version 1.8.2 with Python version 2.7.9 on openSuse 13.1 x64_86.

title: BUG: loadtxt fails with complex data in Python 3.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The problem is that the Python complex type constructor only accepts a
pair of numbers or a string, unlike other numeric types it does not work
with byte strings. The numpy error is subtle, as loadtxt opens the file
in the default text mode, but then converts the input lines to byte
strings when they are split into separate values. The fix here is to
convert the values back to strings in the complex converter.

Closes #5655.

title: BUG some ufunc methods do not yet take tuple for output
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
#5621 introduced the nice option to allow tuples for output arrays, including a tuple holding a single array for a single output. However, it missed also changing the outputs for some of the ufunc methods such as reduce:
```
a = np.arange(10.)
b = np.array(1.)
np.add.reduce(a, out=b)
# array(45.0)
np.add.reduce(a, out=(b,))
# TypeError: output must be an array
```
cc @jaimefrio

title: ENH: Strict checking of ufunc keyword argument names
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
Raises a TypeError if any of the keyword arguments supplied to a
ufunc does not exactly match the name in the signature. Prior to
this, trailing characters were discarded, e.g. 'out2' would be
treated as if it where 'out'.

title: loadtxt fails with complex data under python 3
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/DavidPowell', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1106295?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'DavidPowell', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1106295, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/DavidPowell/followers'}
body:
If the file `complex-data.txt` contains the following

````
8.56701944e-02-4.51046468e-03j
-8.10738577e-02+1.38042481e-03j
-4.05139503e-02+2.73159837e-04j
4.28743806e-02-3.94370325e-03j
-4.76092917e-02+3.93395282e-03j
1.17309845e-01-3.28224736e-04j
````

Then the code
````
import numpy as np
np.loadtxt('complex-data.txt', dtype=np.complex128)
```

gives the exception `TypeError: complex() argument must be a string or a number, not 'bytes'`. It works perfectly fine under python 2.

This appears to be caused by `loadtxt` failing to properly decode the text file. May be related to #2715, #4208, #4543, #5530. These issues give me the impression that `loadtxt` is essentially broken under python 3, and needs a radical overhaul.

Are there any suggested workarounds?

body:
I've worked through some more of the random module docstrings to make them more consistent and standardized.  The return values for some functions were missing or in a couple of cases, incorrect with respect to the actual behavior.  In keeping with the description of the ``size`` parameter that @gdementen proposed, I would like to suggest a similar type of return definition, where applicable::

        Returns
        -------
        samples : ndarray or scalar
            The drawn samples, of shape ``(m, n, k)``.

If this looks good, I'll continue working through the module and try to make it more consistent.  Thanks.
