title: BUG? : np.ravel does not flatten out certain arrays
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/MechCoder', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1867024?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'MechCoder', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1867024, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/MechCoder/followers'}
body:
For arrays in which the number of elements are not the same along the inner axes, `np.ravel` and `np.flatten` return the array as it is. I'm not sure if this is intended behavior or not.

    In [23]: a = np.ravel([[1, 2], [3, 4, 5]])

    In [24]: a
    Out[24]: array([[1, 2], [3, 4, 5]], dtype=object)

I thought of giving this as a shot, but I'm not sure what part of the source I should modify, the ravel function just says `asarray(a).ravel()` and I was not able to figure out (quickly) where the ravel methods for the ndarray is.

title: ENH: Add support for ATLAS > 3.9.33.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Recent ATLAS combines the previous libraries into two

* libsatlas -- single threaded.
* libtatlas -- threaded.

This fix is a bit of hack in that ATLAS > 3.9.33 is treated as a new,
separate library covered by atlas_3_10_info, but the latter derived
from atlas_info, which treats the cblas, atlas, and atlas_lapack
libraries separately, so the new info has a bit of repetition.

The alternative would be to rewrite atlas_info, but that can wait
on a larger cleanup of the build system.

Closes #3774.

title: BUG: Xerbla doesn't get linked in 1.9 on Fedora 21.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Add our python_xerbla to the blasdot sources. That function is
needed for all modules that link to the ATLAS 3.10 libraries, which
in Fedora 21 are located in just two files: libsatlas and libtatlas.

Also make the test for xerbla linkage work better. If xerbla is not
linked the test will be skipped with a message.

title: BUG: Make RandomState.seed, RandomState.randint and RandomState.shuffle threadsafe
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sturlamolden', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1970862?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sturlamolden', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1970862, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/followers'}
body:
Similar bugs to #5388 

Access to ```RandomState.internal_state``` must always be serialized by ```RandomState.lock```, even when the GIL is not released.

title: BUG: Make RandomState.set_state and RandomState.get_state threadsafe
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sturlamolden', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1970862?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sturlamolden', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1970862, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/followers'}
body: Parts of RandomState.set_state and RandomState.get_state are not thread safe when we allow the GIL to be released. Synchronize access with RandomState.lock.

body:
Add our python_xerbla to the multiarray sources. That function is
needed for all modules that link to the ATLAS 3.10 libraries, which
are now all located in two files, libsatlas and libtatlas.

Also make the test for xerbla linkage work better. If xerbla is not
linked the test will be skipped with a message.

Closes #5362.

linked before any other module links to ATLAS or one of the other

title: Simple math error
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/VSGSleuth', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10240505?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'VSGSleuth', 'type': u'User', 'id': 10240505, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/VSGSleuth/followers'}
body:
## try the code
import numpy as np
u=np.array([170],dtype=np.uint8)
v=u[0]*100000000
print v

## I (probably naively) expected that python would recognize that the uint8 object was being multiplied to make a Long int product and yield the Longint answer 170000000000.  Instead, the result of the calculation defaults presumably to the 32 bit product, in this case a nonsensical negative number.  This is fixable by typing the initial array as 64 bits, or by explicitly typing the scalar 100000000 as 64 bit.  But this is not a standard requirement for other calculations in python.

## Apologies if I have repeated an earlier bug or simply exhibited my own ignorance.  Took me a full afternoon to figure this out.

title: `np.ravel` should return the same array type it was given
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Garrett-R', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6614695?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Garrett-R', 'type': u'User', 'id': 6614695, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Garrett-R/followers'}
body:
If given a matrix, then `np.ravel` should return a matrix.  And similarly for a masked array.  Currently, it always returns an ndarray.

In PR #5358, `np.diagonal` was modified to return whatever array type it took in.  Also, `np.cumsum` and `np.clip` return the same array type.  So, `np.ravel`'s behavior is surprising.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jpiabrantes', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2369107?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jpiabrantes', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2369107, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpiabrantes/followers'}
body:
I found something real weird when using addition in numpy arrays:

from numpy import *
x = array([[0]])
x += 0.1*2
print x
-> [[0]]
x = x + 0.1*2
print x
->[[0.2]]

My numpy version is: '1.8.2'

title: ENH: add np.broadcast_to and reimplement np.broadcast_arrays
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/shoyer', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1217238?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'shoyer', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1217238, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/followers'}
body:
Per the [mailing list discussion](http://mail.scipy.org/pipermail/numpy-discussion/2014-December/071796.html), I have implemented a new function `broadcast_to` that broadcasts an array to a given shape according to numpy's broadcasting rules.

The new array iterator has functionality that could make several of these functions into *almost* one liners (thank you @jaimefrio, @seberg and @mwiebe for showing how), although we do have to do some extra work to preserve subclasses.

The first commit (eventually to be squashed away) shows how I would implement these *without* relying heavily on `nditer`. It also includes the `broadcast_shape` function (no longer necessary for the implementation of `broadcast_arrays`), which almost but didn't quite work as a one-liner (it failed for size 0 arrays). We could revive it if others think it would serve a useful purpose.

Question: should we allow for broadcasting with negative numbers in the shape? This seems strange but it does work (sort of like reshape) with the current implementation and I suppose someone could find it useful. On the other hand, numbers less than -1 are also supported, which may just be a bug with nditer?

    In [1]: import numpy as np

    In [2]: x = np.array([1, 2, 3])

    # possibly useful
    In [3]: np.broadcast_to(x, (-1, -1))
    Out[3]: array([[1, 2, 3]])

    # probably not useful
    In [4]: np.broadcast_to(x, (-10,))
    Out[4]: array([1, 2, 3])

(I did not yet add tests for the behavior with negative sizes.)

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cournape', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/25111?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cournape', 'type': u'User', 'id': 25111, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/followers'}
body:
Complex types memory representations in C for a given `type` are guaranteed to be equivalent to `type[2]`. As such, the alignment of `complex<type>` should be the same as `type`.

I tested scipy 0.14.x (at scipy/scipy@d6c32069f1379b3517eee8511e323607c246c66c, containing the f2py workaround) in the following setups:


##### numpy 1.9.1, w/ this patch

* one genuine error (all platforms). Unlikely to be related to numpy.

* a few minor precision issues that have been here for a while otherwise.

title: ENH: Add support for ATLAS > 3.9.33.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Recent ATLAS combines the previous libraries into two

* libsatlas -- single threaded.
* libtatlas -- threaded.

This fix is a bit of hack in that ATLAS > 3.9.33 is treated as a new,
separate library covered by atlas_3_10_info, but the latter derives
from atlas_info, which treats the cblas, atlas, and atlas_lapack
libraries separately, so the new info has a bit of repetition.

The alternative would be to rewrite atlas_info, but that can wait
on a larger cleanup of the build system.

Closes #3774.

title: ENH: Improve arg handling & enhance test suite for `np.pad`
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/JDWarner', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2184487?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'JDWarner', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2184487, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/JDWarner/followers'}
body:
This PR supersedes #4113, including changes from @ahojnnes and further improvements. Briefly, this consists of major increases to test coverage and enhancements allowing ndarrays as arguments to `pad_width`, `constant_values`, or `end_values`. Also, floating point inputs are now handled properly for `constant_values` and `end_values`.

* Argument handling improved
* Complicated logic in the hidden function `_normalize_shape` replaced
  * New version operates internally on NumPy arrays instead of attempting to do type and shape checking on nested iterables.
  * Overall structure easier to follow
  * Comments added for maintainability
  * Import of `numbers` and `long` from `np.compat` no longer required
* Test suite greatly improved, now 100% coverage
* Removed nonfunctional lines from final `'reflect'` loop - artifacts *someone* forgot to take out after developing this thing...
* PEP8 fixes
* Docstring clarifications in hidden functions.

The concern raised by @charris in #4113 has been addressed, and tests added to ensure this behavior is maintained. The output array dtype always preserves the dtype of the array *to be padded*, including at all intermediate steps. Accomplishing this in an elegant manner required the re-write of `_normalize_shape`.

title: dtype equality operator does not check endianness of fields
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/bmerry', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1963944?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'bmerry', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1963944, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bmerry/followers'}
body:
For simple types, two dtype objects with different endianness are unequal:
```py
>>> np.dtype('<i4') == np.dtype('>i4')
False
```
However, for fields, the endianness is currently ignored when doing a comparison:
```py
>>> np.dtype([('a', '<i4')]) == np.dtype([('a', '>i4')])
True
```

This causes problems with other functions. For example,
```py
>>> big = np.dtype([('a', '>i2')])
>>> little = np.dtype([('a', '<i2')])
>>> arr = np.ones(4, dtype=big)
>>> print arr
[(1,) (1,) (1,) (1,)]
>>> print arr.astype(little)
[(256,) (256,) (256,) (256,)]
```
I'm guessing that astype thought the output dtype was the same, and hence did a memcpy instead of performing the endian conversion.

```
$ python
Python 3.4.1 (default, Aug 24 2014, 21:32:40)

>>> t = np.linspace(start=0, stop=50*np.pi, endpoint=False, num=size)

>>> F = fft2(img)
>>> F_min = F.min()
>>> F = F.clip(F_min) # this crashes python
Segmentation fault: 11
```

title: TST: Fix TestArrayAlmostEqualNulp
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/rnelsonchem', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3750670?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'rnelsonchem', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3750670, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/followers'}
body:
This fix addresses Issue #347.

All of the tests in this class were using random numbers generated without a
seed. In certain cases, this broke `test_simple` in a nondeterministic manner.
Part of the problem for this function is that `nulp` was being set to
2*max(random deviations). This value could be less than one depending on the
random numbers generated. Reset `nulp=1` which is the smallest value that
makes sense. Create a random array of deviations and force them to be in the
range [-1., 1.], because the abs(randn) can occasionally be > 1.

The assertion in test_big_float32 used a `nulp=1000`, which seemed excessive
for this particular test. Changed this to `nulp=1`, because that corresponds
to a value of ~1024 for this test case.

Documentation and random seeds were added to all of the other functions in
this class to make things more explicit.

title: BUG: x.view('S1') raises for 0-dimensional stirng arrays
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/shoyer', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1217238?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'shoyer', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1217238, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/shoyer/followers'}
body:
This works:
```
>>> x = np.array(['asdfkjd'])
>>> x.view('S1')
array(['a', 's', 'd', 'f', 'k', 'j', 'd'],
      dtype='|S1')
```
This doesn't:
```
>>> x = np.array('asdfkjd')
>>> x.view('S1')
*** ValueError: new type not compatible with array.
```

title: Meshgrid shuffles the grid for 3-D or more
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/gabraganca', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2700254?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'gabraganca', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2700254, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gabraganca/followers'}
body:
Hi!

Me and @pedrohasselmann found a strange issue when using numpy.meshgrid for 3 dimensions and higher. The axis of each grid are shuffled and are not returned in the same order in which they were given.

Example:

```python
import numpy as np
X = np.arange(0, 10, 1) # Size = 10
Y = np.arange(0, 10, 2)  # Size = 5
Z = np.arange(0, 10, 5)  # Size = 2

mesh = np.meshgrid(X, Y, Z)

print a[0].shape
```

The axis of the returned grid is `(5, 10, 2)`  when we believe that it should be `(10, 5, 2)`, keeping the same order as the ones given.

We  pinpoint that the following issue is containing in this [block](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/v1.9.1/numpy/lib/function_base.py#L3407-L3411).

If we removed it, we could reproduce the result expected by us.

Is this a mistake or it was designed?

body:
The version check flag for GnuFCompiler and Gnu95FCompiler were changed from
`--version` to `-dumpversion`. This simplifies the gnu_version_match code for
gfortran, and makes it possible to drop much of the check code for g77 as
well. This fix addresses issue #5315 and #5321.

title: DOC: Reorganization request for Development Workflow docs
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/rnelsonchem', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3750670?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'rnelsonchem', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3750670, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rnelsonchem/followers'}
body:
As a new contributor, I tried to follow the Development Workflow documentation; however, I found this page to be a little confusing in places. I've reorganized things in a way that seems to make more sense to me now that I've made a code submission via pull request. I'm not a git wizard, so I would appreciate any feedback in case I messed things up. Below are the major changes and remaining questions that I'd like to address. I'm happy to roll a lot of this back, but this addresses some issues I had as a newcomer. 

Major changes:
* Move the rebasing section out of the basic workflow. The first sentence in this section advises not to do this, so it is unclear why this would be a basic workflow issue. Is there another reason that this is important? Perhaps to make sure there are no merge conflicts, but if so, it is not clear to a beginner.
* Also separate out the problems from the rebasing section. It seems like this covers (or could cover) more than just rebasing, so it made sense to make it a separate section.
* Removed core dev notes from the basic workflow. I don't imagine that the core devs need to run through the basic workflow checklist all that often, and these are not commands that a beginner needs to worry about. (Or they probably can't do without commit rights...?)
* Moved some of the discussion of git push from the New Branch section to the end of the Editing section. It just seemed more natural that you would need to worry about pushing to a remote repo after you've done all of your changes.
* Renamed a few links and removed a broken one (Matthew Brett's NiPy comparison link)

Questions:
* The Asking for a Merge section suggests both code reviews via the mailing list and pull requests. Is there a reason to prefer one over the other? Should pull requests only be filed for opened issues? It might be nice to include that.
* I tried to build the documentation in a fresh conda Python 3.4 environment with the minimal dependencies. However, it choked right away because it could not find the plot_directive extension. Of course, installing Matplotlib into this environment fixed the error. However, there is nothing about this dependency in doc/HOWTO_BUILD_DOCS.rst.txt. I'm happy to add something to this document, but I'm not sure that you want to recommend MPL as a Numpy dependency. Is there an alternate method to finding this extension that should be included in the docs?

title: Array in-place update ordering not respected
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/alexforencich', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/508807?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'alexforencich', 'type': u'User', 'id': 508807, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexforencich/followers'}
body:
When using += and -= on arrays with a shifted copy as an argument, the ordering is not respected.  

Test case:

    import numpy as np

    a = np.array([1,2,3,4,5])
    # a[n] = a[n] + a[n-1]
    a[1:5] = a[1:5] + a[0:4]

    b = np.array([1,2,3,4,5])
    # updates in the wrong order, updating n-1 values before use (expect incorrect result)
    b[1:5] += b[0:4]

    c = np.array([1,2,3,4,5])
    # update in the reverse order so as to not clobber the n-1 values (expect correct result)
    c[4:0:-1] += c[3::-1]

    print(a)
    print(b)
    print(c)

    assert (a != b).any() # OK
    assert (a == c).all() # fails (b == c)

title: API/BUG: np.dtype equality comparisons versus string-like is inconsistent
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jreback', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/953992?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jreback', 'type': u'User', 'id': 953992, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/followers'}
body:
xref: https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/8814

using ``numpy 1.9.1/macosx``

``np.dtype`` equality checking versus string-likes should return a boolean rather than raising
in dtype comparisons. This is currently inconsistent when presented with a valid dtype parse of the string, but will raise if its not valid.

e.g

```
In [12]: np.dtype('i8') == 'int64'
Out[12]: True

In [14]: np.dtype('i8') == 'int32'
Out[14]: False

In [13]: np.dtype('i8') == 'foo'
TypeError: data type "foo" not understood
```

title: [WIP] configure Windows CI with AppVeyor

labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/5%20-%20Testing', 'color': u'fef2c0', 'name': u'5 - Testing'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20build', 'color': u'e11d21', 'name': u'component: build'}]
body:
At the moment I have registered this branch on my ogrisel account:

https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ogrisel/numpy

As you can see there are 9 errors in the tests caused by deprecation warnings. I have not investigated why it's happening. I don't have a windows host at hand at the moment.

If we want to merge this, we should create a shared appveyor account on the ci.appveyor.com service and share the password among core numpy developers.

If we want to have appveyor to monitor all incoming pull request in complement to travis, we would need to setup multi-status github reporting:

http://github-multi-status.herokuapp.com/

Otherwise it's possible to configure appveyor to run the test on commits merged to master only instead.

@cournape is experimenting with building numpy against libopenblas.dll to be able to skip the liblapack_lite build step that is very slow on appveyor.

body:
While `hash(a)` raises an exception as expected for an array `a`, `a.__hash__()` does not, and `isinstance(a, collections.IsHashable)` returns True.

This fixes the issuew/ one trivial test.

title: Error detecting custom gfortran compiler
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/fmatthew5876', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1198466?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'fmatthew5876', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1198466, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fmatthew5876/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.distutils', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.distutils'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}]
body:
This issue was discovered in the numpy 1.9.1 release.

I have my own custom built gcc 4.8.3 on a CentOs 5 machine. This compiler was built using the --with-pkgversion option which affects the output of the gfortran --version command.

For example if you build your gcc 4.8.3 using `--with-pkgversion=AB2`,
then `gfortran --version` will output:

    GNU Fortran (AB2) 4.8.3
    Copyright ....

The last regex used by GnuFCompiler.gnu_version_match() in numpy/distutils/fcompiler/gnu.py chokes on this. It takes the 2 from AB2 as the compiler version and returns "g77". 

The result is that the numpy setup.py was unable to correctly find and use my gfortran compiler. For my site I just created a patch to hack the regex to work but I don't think my fix would be a general solution.

title: Numpy gets slow after creating some scipy matrices and delete the reference to it
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/justhalf', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/539150?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'justhalf', 'type': u'User', 'id': 539150, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/justhalf/followers'}
body:
After creating a csr_matrix from scipy, assigning to a variable, and setting that variable to None, the performance of subsequent operations are affected badly.

    from numpy import *
    from scipy.sparse import *
    import time

    import sys
    test_slow = len(sys.argv)>1  # If this is True, test_sparse is slow, otherwise it's fast
    if test_slow:
        for i in range(int(sys.argv[1])):
            A = random.random((1000,1000))
            A = csr_matrix(A)  # If only this line is commented out, scipy completes in 0.192s
            A = None  # If only this line is commented out, scipy completes in 3s

    C = ndarray(shape=(1000,1000))
    D = ndarray(shape=(1000,1000))
    for i in range(20000):
        C[random.randint(0,1000),random.randint(0,1000)] = random.rand()
        D[random.randint(0,1000),random.randint(0,1000)] = random.rand()
    C1 = csr_matrix(C)
    D1 = csr_matrix(D)

    print 'Numpy dot product sparse'
    start = time.time()
    result = dot(C,D)
    print 'Done in %.3fs' % (time.time() - start)

    print 'Scipy dot product sparse'
    start = time.time()
    result = C1.dot(D1)
    print 'Done in %.3fs' % (time.time() - start)

Running the file without argument (causing `test_slow` to be False):

>Numpy dot product sparse
Done in 0.470s
Scipy dot product sparse
Done in 0.012s

That is the expected performance of numpy and scipy. However, as further tests showed, that performance is affected by the three lines inside `test_slow`.

Running the file with `1` as argument (doing the seemingly useless assignment and unassignment to `A` once):

>Numpy dot product sparse
Done in 0.472s
Scipy dot product sparse
Done in 0.195s

So numpy seems still unaffected, but scipy gets slower.

Running the file with `2` as argument (doing the seemingly useless assignment and unassignment to `A` twice):

>Numpy dot product sparse
Done in 11.071s
Scipy dot product sparse
Done in 69.477s

Both numpy and scipy get *extremely* slow!

This problem doesn't occur if the matrix creation (the `C`, `D`, `C1`, and `D1`) happens before the seemingly useless assignment and unassignment.

If the line `A = csr_matrix(A)` is commented out, only scipy dot product is affected:

>Numpy dot product sparse
Done in 0.473s
Scipy dot product sparse
Done in 0.194s

Any explanation on this? It seems very bizarre, as the assignment and unassignment should not affect anything. It's not due to `random`, since only calling `A = random.random((1000,1000))` before the creation of the array doesn't affect the performance.

I'm not sure whether to put this issue in scipy or numpy, but since it affects numpy also, I guess the slow in scipy is due to the slow in numpy, so I post the issue here.

My system configuration:

```
Python 2.7.3 (default, Sep 26 2013, 20:03:06)
[GCC 4.6.3] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import numpy, scipy
>>> numpy.__version__
'1.8.1'
>>> scipy.__version__
'0.12.0'
>>>
```

title: Docstring for np.linalg.svd still wrong?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ChristophWiesmeyr', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/8068536?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ChristophWiesmeyr', 'type': u'User', 'id': 8068536, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ChristophWiesmeyr/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Documentation', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Documentation'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}]
body:
The docstring of the SVD function in `np.linalg` says

    Factors the matrix `a` as ``u * np.diag(s) * v``, where `u` and `v`
    are unitary and `s` is a 1-d array of `a`'s singular values."

However, this is wrong for non-square matrices `a`. This has been discussed on the mailing list a few years back: [link](http://mail.scipy.org/pipermail/numpy-discussion/2011-January/054722.html). Nevertheless this is still wrong in my version, i.e. 1.9.0.

body: This is my attempt to fix #5306. The docstring is now more accurate; my only concern is that if users don't understand that copying is the default behaviour, then it may now be less clear that if all `array` parameters are left as their defaults, the output will always be C-contiguous.

title: `array` function's docstring is not clear on default value for `order` parameter
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/hunse', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1952250?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'hunse', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1952250, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hunse/followers'}
body:
In the docstring for `numpy.array`, it says that the default value for the `order` parameter is `'C'` (i.e., the output will be C-contiguous). This is true if `copy=True`, but if `copy=False` then `array` acts like `asarray` (not `ascontiguousarray`) and the output is not guaranteed to be contiguous. Explicitly setting `order='C'` forces a copy if the input is not C-contiguous.

The docstring needs to be changed to reflect this difference, so that it does not say that `'C'` is the default value for `order`.

title: np.multiply is inconsistent between sparse and dense types
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/chrisprobert', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2967325?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'chrisprobert', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2967325, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chrisprobert/followers'}
body:
The ufunc `np.multiply()` performs different operations depending on whether the arguments are sparse or dense types. In particular, the spec for np.multiply (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.multiply.html) specifies that it will "Multiply arguments element-wise." But with sparse types, it appears to perform matrix multiplication:

```python
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import scipy as sp
>>> import scipy.sparse
>>> a = np.arange(9).reshape(3,3)
>>> np.multiply(a,a)
array([[ 0,  1,  4],
       [ 9, 16, 25],
       [36, 49, 64]])
>>> a = sp.sparse.csr_matrix(a)
>>> np.multiply(a,a).todense()
matrix([[ 15,  18,  21],
        [ 42,  54,  66],
        [ 69,  90, 111]])
```

title: BUG: astype is broken for structured arrays with different byte orders
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/dranjan', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/404832?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'dranjan', 'type': u'User', 'id': 404832, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dranjan/followers'}
body:
The offending commit is c53b0e4, which introduced two regressions:
- using `astype` to cast a structured array to one with a different byte order no longer works;
- comparing structured-array dtypes can give incorrect results if the two dtypes have different byte orders.

This pull request should fix both.

One thing I wasn't sure about is reordering struct fields.  In my implementation, the `equiv`, `same_kind`, and `safe` rules are now allowed to reorder fields.  If that isn't desired, though, it's a pretty easy change.

title: Possible inconsistency between behaviour of integer arrays and numpy behaviour
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jbzdak', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/112872?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jbzdak', 'type': u'User', 'id': 112872, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbzdak/followers'}
body:
Hi! 

I'm preparing materials for my students about numpy, and found following bug/inconsistency between behavioue and docs. Docs for np.divide state that: 

> When both x1 and x2 are of an integer type, divide will return integers and throw away the fractional part. Moreover, division by zero always yields zero in integer arithmetic.

However when I execute examples from the documentation in my notebook I get behaviour as if floats were used: 

     np.divide(2, 4) 

returns 0.5

and:

     np.divide(np.array([0, 1], dtype=int), np.array([0, 0], dtype=int))

returns: 

array([ nan,  inf]). 

I use numpy 1.9.1(d44b9c61499f8bc5a9fc94286cd52f05e15e003f) on Python 3.4.1.

title: TST: Fix ImportError in runtests.py (fixes #5273)
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/chatcannon', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2848682?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'chatcannon', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2848682, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/followers'}
body: I think the problem is because numpy.testing has only been partially imported when it tries to import numpy.utils, so when numpy.core tries `from numpy.testing import Tester` it can't find it. I've fixed this by moving the import of Tester to before `from .utils import *`. However I'm not sure why this problem hasn't appeared for others -- perhaps I am doing something else wrong.

body:
I get this error when trying to run the tests
```
$ python runtests.py 
Building, see build.log...
Running from numpy source directory.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 251, in <module>
    setup_package()
  File "setup.py", line 235, in setup_package
    from numpy.distutils.core import setup
  File "/home/chris/Downloads/spyder/numpy/numpy/distutils/__init__.py", line 37, in <module>
    from numpy.testing import Tester
  File "/home/chris/Downloads/spyder/numpy/numpy/testing/__init__.py", line 13, in <module>
    from .utils import *
  File "/home/chris/Downloads/spyder/numpy/numpy/testing/utils.py", line 17, in <module>
    from numpy.core import float32, empty, arange, array_repr, ndarray
  File "/home/chris/Downloads/spyder/numpy/numpy/core/__init__.py", line 59, in <module>
    from numpy.testing import Tester
ImportError: cannot import name Tester

Build failed!
```
numpy.testing tries to import numpy.utils, which then tries to import numpy.testing -- but numpy.testing is not fully imported.

title: Stop F2Py from using the deprecated numpy API
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/chatcannon', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2848682?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'chatcannon', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2848682, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/followers'}
body:
The f2py C code currently uses the pre 1.7 deprecated API, which causes lots of spurious warning messages when compiling Fortran extension modules with f2py (see #2639).

This pull request removes almost all of this, except for the `swap_arrays` and `dump_attrs` functions in fortranobject.c, which now cast the `PyArrayObject*` to `PyArrayObject_fields*`

title: Possible regression in `multivariate_normal()`
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/chebee7i', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/326005?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'chebee7i', 'type': u'User', 'id': 326005, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chebee7i/followers'}
body:
When generating numbers from `np.random.multivariate_normal`, I'm not getting the same numbers when moving from NumPy 1.8.2 to 1.9.1.  This seems to happen only when the covariance matrix is not positive semi-definite, but note, the docs never stated this was a requirement to guarantee backwards compatibility.

Here is current behavior:
```
In [1]: np.random.seed(0)

In [2]: np.random.multivariate_normal([.5, .5], [[.3, .2],[.2, .4]])
Out[2]: array([-0.42923317, -0.44352946])

In [3]: np.random.multivariate_normal([.5, .5], [[.3, .5],[.5, .4]])
/Users/me/.virtualenvs/py27/bin/ipython:1: RuntimeWarning: covariance is not positive-semidefinite.
Out[3]: array([-0.10637043, -0.17003179])

In [4]: np.__version__
Out[4]: '1.9.1'
```

Here is behavior in 1.8.1 and also 1.8.2:
```
In [1]: np.random.seed(0)

In [2]: np.random.multivariate_normal([.5, .5], [[.3, .2],[.2, .4]])
Out[2]: array([-0.42923317, -0.44352946])

In [3]: np.random.multivariate_normal([.5, .5], [[.3, .5],[.5, .4]])
Out[3]: array([ 0.54245905, -0.7572144 ])

In [4]: np.__version__
Out[4]: '1.8.1'
```
Resetting the seed before `In [3]` doesn't affect the difference between versions.

title: structured arrays should raise Exception if missing fields are requested in the form of a list
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/gerritholl', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/500246?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'gerritholl', 'type': u'User', 'id': 500246, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/followers'}
body:
If we have an `ndarray` with a structured dtype, and I index it with a single non-existent field, an exception (`ValueError`) is raised, as expected.  However, if I index it with a list of fields, of which at least one is non-existent, no such exception is raised:

```
In [402]: A = numpy.empty(shape=(5,), dtype=[("A", "f2"), ("B", "f4"), ("C", "f8")])

In [403]: A["D"] # expect: ValueError
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-403-6027a6da83aa> in <module>()
----> 1 A["D"] # expect: ValueError

ValueError: field named D not found

In [404]: A[["C", "D"]] # expect: ValueError
Out[404]: 
array([(3.822678085115078e-297,), (-3.1341142554817164e-294,),
       (3.8820982892244793e-265,), (1.9848357676925587e-263,),
       (1.2046357989657346e-307,)], 
      dtype=[('C', '<f8')])

In [405]: A[["D"]] # expect: ValueError
Out[405]: 
array([(), (), (), (), ()], 
      dtype='{'names':[], 'formats':[], 'offsets':[], 'itemsize':14}')
```

I think it would be more consistent if an error would be raised in both cases.

title: np.swapaxes doesn't always return a view
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
Related somehow to the discussion in #5258. The docs for `np.swapaxes` state that it returns a view if the first argument is an ndarray, but it has a fast path for `axis1 == axis2`, where it actually returns the original array incref'ed:

```
>>> a = np.arange(60).reshape(3, 4, 5).copy()
>>> a.base is None
True
>>> a.swapaxes(0, 1).base is None
False
>>> a.swapaxes(0, 0).base is None
True
>>> a.swapaxes(20, 20).base is None  # that this works is bad!!!
True
>>> a.transpose(range(3)).base is None
False
```

I prefer that it always returned a view, even if it is of the whole array unchanged, as the docs say, and as e.g. `np.transpose` does, even if the array is unchanged, and will be more than happy to submit a PR. If there is any good reason why this should not be the case, then at least the docs should be updated, and the check for `axis1 == axis2` be moved to after they have both been checked for in-boundness.

title: Indexing a view with a view yields a non-view?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/keflavich', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/143715?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'keflavich', 'type': u'User', 'id': 143715, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/keflavich/followers'}
body:
Apologies for the title; I don't quite know how to better phrase it.  The issue is easily demonstrated:  If I create a boolean mask, index with it, then create another boolean mask based off of the masked region, I can't nest the masking... better just to see it in action:

```
In [93]: x = np.arange(5)

In [94]: y = x>2

In [95]: z = x[y] > 3

In [96]: x[y][z]
Out[96]: array([4])

In [97]: x[y][z] = 0

In [98]: x
Out[98]: array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4])

In [99]: np.__version__
Out[99]: '1.9.0'

In [102]: x[y] = 0

In [103]: x
Out[103]: array([0, 1, 2, 0, 0])
```

I expected `x[y][z]` to change value, since `x[y]` does.  Is this a bug, or do I harbor a deep misunderstanding of indexing and views?

title: BUG: fix PyArray_IsPythonScalar to detect bytes objects on Python 3
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/immerrr', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/579798?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'immerrr', 'type': u'User', 'id': 579798, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/immerrr/followers'}
body:
This PR should fix `PyArray_IsPythonScalar` to return True for unibyte strings on Python 3.

As you can see [here](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/immerrr/ab4a50a665844c2293aa), unibyte strings don't pass `PyString_Check` on Python 3 and only `PyBytes_Check` will work there. On 2.6/2.7 `PyBytes_Check` is an alias for `PyString_Check` (or vice versa, I don't remember), so it should work too.

title: Class _arraymethod in ma.core is a descriptor, yet mutable.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/markshannon', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/9448417?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'markshannon', 'type': u'User', 'id': 9448417, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markshannon/followers'}
body:
This leads to "interesting" behaviour:
```python
>>> from numpy.ma.core import MaskedArray
>>> import numpy as np
>>> z = np.zeros(5)
>>> z
array([ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.])
>>> o = np.ones(5)
>>> o
array([ 1.,  1.,  1.,  1.,  1.])
>>> mz = MaskedArray(z)
>>> mz
masked_array(data = [ 0.  0.  0.  0.  0.],
             mask = False,
       fill_value = 1e+20)

>>> mo = MaskedArray(o)
>>> mo
masked_array(data = [ 1.  1.  1.  1.  1.],
             mask = False,
       fill_value = 1e+20)

>>> mocopy = mo.copy
>>> mocopy()
masked_array(data = [ 1.  1.  1.  1.  1.],
             mask = False,
       fill_value = 1e+20)

>>> mz.copy
<numpy.ma.core._arraymethod object at 0x29fff10>
>>> mocopy()
masked_array(data = [ 0.  0.  0.  0.  0.],
             mask = False,
       fill_value = 1e+20)

>>> mo.copy
<numpy.ma.core._arraymethod object at 0x29fff10>
>>> mocopy()
masked_array(data = [ 1.  1.  1.  1.  1.],
             mask = False,
       fill_value = 1e+20)
```

title: Bug: Adding a transposed array to itself
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/petered', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1148799?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'petered', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1148799, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/petered/followers'}
body:
Something very strange happens when you try adding a transposed array to itself:
```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> arr = np.ones((100, 100))
>>> arr+=arr.T
>>> arr
array([[ 2.,  2.,  2., ...,  2.,  2.,  2.],
       [ 2.,  2.,  2., ...,  2.,  2.,  2.],
       [ 2.,  2.,  2., ...,  2.,  2.,  2.],
       ..., 
       [ 3.,  3.,  3., ...,  2.,  2.,  2.],
       [ 3.,  3.,  3., ...,  2.,  2.,  2.],
       [ 3.,  3.,  3., ...,  2.,  2.,  2.]])
>>> np.sum(arr==2)
8532
>>> np.sum(arr==3)
1468
```
`arr = arr + arr.T` works fine of course.

It looks like because arr.T is a view of arr, while reading values out of arr.T it reads elements of arr that have already been written to.  This could lead to some really sneaky bugs. Even just detecting the situation and raising an exception would be an acceptable solution.

title: BUG np.std with output given stores variance in output
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
If output is assigned in `np.std`, the variance is stored in that output (while the standard deviation is returned). Possibly related is that for both `np.var` and `np.std`, what is returned is not the same as what is stored in the output array:
```
import numpy as np
a = np.array([1., 2.])
aout = np.array(0.)
np.var(a, out=aout)
# as expected: 0.25
aout
# as expected: array(0.25)
np.std(a, out=aout)
# as expected: 0.5
aout
# OOPS: array(0.25)
b = np.var(a, out=aout)
b is aout
# OOPS: False
b = np.sum(a, out=aout)
b is aout
# as expected: True
```

body:
See the mailing list thread started at http://mail.scipy.org/pipermail/numpy-discussion/2014-October/071522.html.

The doc file is https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/maintenance/1.9.x/doc/source/user/c-info.python-as-glue.rst.

That mailing list thread makes no sense to me because it involves non-technical drama that I don't understand, but in any case the relevant numpy doc file has not been significantly updated in six years while the methods of using Python as glue have been changing substantially.

__Edit__: I see there is an existing issue https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/4492 for adding Cython instructions specifically.

title: BUG: Workaround segfault in Apple Accelerate framework SGEMV function
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sturlamolden', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1970862?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sturlamolden', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1970862, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20build', 'color': u'e11d21', 'name': u'component: build'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.core', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.core'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Maintenance', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Maintenance'}]
body:
SGEMV in Accelerate framework will segfault on MacOS X version 10.9
(aka Mavericks) if arrays are not aligned to 32 byte boundaries
and the CPU supports AVX instructions. This can produce segfaults
in np.dot. This patch overshadows the symbols cblas_sgemv, sgemv_ and
sgemv exported by Accelerate to produce the correct behavior. The MacOS X
version and CPU specs are checked on module import. If Mavericks and
AVX are detected the call to SGEMV is emulated with a call to SGEMM
if the arrays are not 32 byte aligned. If the exported symbols cannot
be overshadowed on module import, a fatal error is produced and the
process aborts. All the fixes are in a self-contained C file
and do not alter the multiarray C code. The patch is not applied
unless NumPy is configured to link with Apple's Accelerate
framework.

body:
The definition of off_t is located in sys/types.h and is not pulled
by other files when compiling in c99 mode instead of the default gnu89.
Closes gh-5231

title: Linalg SVD fails if not computing UV
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/markwmuller', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3056063?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'markwmuller', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3056063, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/markwmuller/followers'}
body: I have a matrix which raises a type error when I run linalg.svd on it and set compute_uv to false. However, the SVD works fine if I also compute U and V. I have a pickle file with the particular matrix here, and a simple script to illustrate: https://www.wuala.com/markwmuller/Documents/NumpyLinalgSVD_problem/?key=GG0oL349Ak7J I'm using numpy version 1.8.1, on python 2.7.6. This works: u, s, v = numpy.linalg.svd(mat) But this does not: s2 = numpy.linalg.svd(mat, compute_uv=False) The message reads: File "svdProb.py", line 9, in s2 = numpy.linalg.svd(mat, compute_uv=False) File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\numpy\linalg\linalg.py", line 1339, in svd s = gufunc(a, signature=signature, extobj=extobj) TypeError: No loop matching the specified signature was found for ufunc svd_m

title: MaskedArray ignores __array_priority__
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/abalkin', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/535197?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'abalkin', 'type': u'User', 'id': 535197, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/followers'}
body:
Given a class like this:

```
class X(int):
    def __add__(self, other):
        return 42
    def __radd__(self, other):
        return 24
    __array_priority__ = 20
```

Adding to a numpy array works as expected:

```
>>> np.array(2) + X()
24
```

However, when I add `X()` to a masked array, `X.__radd__` is not called:

```
>>> np.ma.array(2) + X()
2
```

title: BUG: Ugly fix for Apple's cblas_sgemv segfault
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sturlamolden', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1970862?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sturlamolden', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1970862, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/followers'}
body:
SGEMV in Accelerate framework will segfault on MacOS X version 10.9
(aka Mavericks) if arrays are not aligned to 32 byte boundaries
and the CPU supports AVX instructions. This can produce segfaults
in numpy.dot if we use numpy.float32 as dtype. This patch overshadows
the symbols cblas_sgemv, sgemv_ and sgemv exported by Accelerate
to produce the correct behavior. The MacOS X version and CPU specs
are checked on module import. If Mavericks and AVX are detected
the call to SGEMV is emulated with a call to SGEMM if the arrays
are not 32 byte aligned. If the exported symbols cannot be
overshadowed on module import, a fatal error is produced and the
process aborts. All the fixes are in a self-contained C file
and do not alter the _dotblas C code. The patch is not applied
unless NumPy is configured to link with Apple's Accelerate
framework.

body:
The previous default was 'L', which seems gcc specific, whereas
'll' is the now recognized standard and is also accepted by gcc.

Closes #5027.

Rebased for backport to 1.9.x.

title: MAINT: more informative error message from linalg.norm
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ewmoore', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2314641?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ewmoore', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2314641, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ewmoore/followers'}
body: From the discussion in #5196, provides a better error message for a bad axis specification in `np.linalg.norm`.  The other cases should be handled eventually by which ever ufunc ends up being called.   This particular case needs handled because `norm` wraps anything that isn't a tuple in a tuple.  If that happened to be a list, you would receive an error asking for an int.  So.  `np.linalg.norm(a, axis=[0,1])` failed with an unhelpful error even accounting for #5201.

title: datetime tests fail on Solaris
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/kester-habermann', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/9316765?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'kester-habermann', 'type': u'User', 'id': 9316765, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kester-habermann/followers'}
body:
The datetime tests in numpy.test()  fail on Solaris/SPARC. This problem does not occur on Solaris-x86. The problem is present in Numpy 1.7.1 and in Numpy 1.9.0.

The problem is in the conversion of datetime64 to a string. The type itself is working, but the __str__ method generates the year as "0000".

Example:

On Solaris 10 (SPARC):

Python 2.7.8 (default, Sep 23 2014, 12:47:57) 
[GCC 4.9.0] on sunos5
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import numpy
>>> numpy.__version__
'1.9.0'
>>> d = numpy.datetime64('2013-12-31')
>>> d
numpy.datetime64('0000-12-31')
>>> d.__str__()
'0000-12-31'
>>> d2 = d + 1
>>> d2.__str__()
'0000-01-01'
>>> d.tolist()
datetime.date(2013, 12, 31)
>>> d2.tolist()
datetime.date(2014, 1, 1)
>>> str(d2)
'0000-01-01'
>>>

body:
fix build error with MSVC 2013 caused by C99 complex support

I already tested in Win8.1 with VS2013 Express 64bit.
Because I am not sure this patch is correct, **please let me know if something is wrong in this patch**.

*How to build(Win8.1+VS2013)*
 - Install VS2013 Express(it support 64bit, don't need Windows SDK)
 - In cmd, execute those commad:
````cmd
cd \path\to\numpy
set VS100COMNTOOLS=%VS120COMNTOOLS%
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 12.0\VC\vcvarsall.bat" x86_amd64
python setup.py install
````
