title: BUG: copy inherited masks in MaskedArray.__array_finalize__
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/njsmith', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/609896?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'njsmith', 'type': u'User', 'id': 609896, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/followers'}
body:
Previously, operations which created a new masked array from an old
masked array -- e.g., np.empty_like -- would tend to result in the new
and old arrays sharing the same .mask attribute. This leads to
horrible brokenness in which writes to one array affect the other. In
particular this was responsible for part of the brokenness that
@jenshnielsen reported in gh-5184 in which np.gradient on masked
arrays would modify the original array's mask.

This fixes the worst part of the issues addressed in gh-3404, though
there's still an argument that we ought to deprecate the mask-copying
behaviour entirely so that empty_like returns an array with an empty
mask. That can wait until we find someone who cares though.

I also applied a small speedup to np.gradient (avoiding one copy);
previously this inefficiency was masking (heh) some of the problems
with masked arrays, so removing it is both an optimization and makes
it easier to test that things are working now.

title: numpy.average demotes dtype of weights.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/rainwoodman', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/138060?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'rainwoodman', 'type': u'User', 'id': 138060, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rainwoodman/followers'}
body:
```
numpy.average(x, weights=y)
```
When x is float32 and y is float64, the average effectively converts y into float32.

For example:
```
In [55]: b = numpy.random.random(size=1e8)
In [56]: a = numpy.random.random(size=1e8)
```
Now a, b are both float64
```
In [57]: numpy.average(float32(a), weights=b)
Out[57]: 1.0
In [58]: numpy.average(float64(a), weights=b)
Out[58]: 0.50000304968994025
```

This behaviour is undocumented, and unexpected. It probably also is in contradiction to the general type conversion rule in numpy: one would expect numpy to promote the float32 to float64 in this case.

Possible resolutions:
1. Document this. (still surprises but can be understood)
2. Always cast the intermediate result to the bigger type in x and y. (no document changes, for then average follows usual numpy conventions.)

Affects at least version 1.8.0

title: BLD: try linking a file if compile long double repr detection fails
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
When compiler uses link time optimization it will not emit the binary
representation of the long double during linking. This prevents building
numpy with -flto.
To avoid this try linking the object when the compile detection failed.
With this change numpy can be built with link time optimization with 4 worker
processes using following command:

CC='gcc -fno-fat-lto-objects -flto=4 -fuse-linker-plugin -O3' \
LDSHARED='gcc -fno-fat-lto-objects -flto=4 -fuse-linker-plugin -shared
-O3' AR=gcc-ar \
python setup.py build_ext

See also:
https://www.mail-archive.com/numpy-discussion@scipy.org/msg45535.html

Should also work with icc's -ipo switch (probably closes gh-4992)

title: BUG: Fixes #5184 gradient calculation behavior at boundaries
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pseudocubic', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1757056?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pseudocubic', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1757056, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pseudocubic/followers'}
body:
Previous expected behavior was that the gradient is computed using central differences in the interior and first differences at the boundaries.

gradient was updated in v1.9.0 so that second-order accurate calculations are done at the boundaries, but this breaks expected behavior with old code, so `edge_order` keyword (Default: 1) is added to specify whether first or second order calculations at the boundaries should be used.

Tests and documentation updated to reflect this change.

title: MaskedArray.dot leaks masked values
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/abalkin', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/535197?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'abalkin', 'type': u'User', 'id': 535197, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abalkin/followers'}
body:
```
>>> numpy.__version__
'1.9.0'
>>> x = numpy.ma.masked_array([1., 3e10, 3], mask=[0, 1, 0])
>>> x.dot(x)
9e+20
```

Note that this is a regression from oldnumeric:

```
>>> import numpy.oldnumeric.ma
>>> numpy.__version__
'1.8.1'
>>> x = numpy.oldnumeric.ma.masked_array([1., 3e10, 3], mask=[0, 1, 0])
>>> x.dot(x)
array(10.0)
```

title: numpy.gradient() doesn't compute boundary values correctly in version 1.9.0
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/drandreasdr', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6980975?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'drandreasdr', 'type': u'User', 'id': 6980975, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drandreasdr/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Documentation', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Documentation'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.lib', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.lib'}]
body:
It seems that numpy.gradient() computes the boundary values incorrectly in version 1.9.0 (but correctly in e.g. version 1.8.1)

To reproduce:
Alternative 1:

    >>> x = np.array([1, 2, 4], dtype=np.float)
    >>> np.gradient(x)
    array([ 0.5,  1.5,  2.5])
although the resulting array should be [(2-1)/1, (4-1)/2, (4-2)/1] = [1, 1.5, 2]

Alternative 2:
Just run the first example in the documentation for numpy.gradient():

    >>> x = np.array([1, 2, 4, 7, 11, 16], dtype=np.float)
    >>> np.gradient(x)
The result is

    array([ 0.5,  1.5,  2.5,  3.5,  4.5,  5.5])
although the documentation says that it should be

    array([ 1. , 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5. ])
the latter also seems right, while the former seems wrong.

(see also http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26361007/numpy-gradient-seems-to-produce-erroneous-boundary-values-using-first-differe)

title: BUG: Fix writing of intrinsic long integers in python2 npy files.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
This only happens when C long is smaller than npy_intp, in particular,
on 64 bit windows. The 'L' suffix is not needed as long as safe_eval
is used to recover the values, and the long intrinsic causes problems
for python3.

The python3 read side has been fixed, but we might as well fix the
problem at the root as well.

Rebased for backport to 1.9.x.

title: BUG: fix nanmedian on arrays containing inf
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
There are two issues:
A masked divide of an infinite value is a masked value which means one
can't use np.ma.mean to compute the median as infinity division is well
defined.
This behaviour seems wrong to me but it also looks intentional so
changing it is not appropriate for a bugfix release.

The second issue is that the ordering of the sorted masked array is
undefined for equal values, the sorting considers infinity the largest
floating point value which is not correct in respect to sorting where
nan is considered larger. This is fixed by changing the
minimum_fill_value to nan for float data in the masked sorts.

Closes gh-5138

title: n-array versions of set operations, especially intersect1d
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cbrueffer', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2705287?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cbrueffer', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2705287, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cbrueffer/followers'}
body:
The stock Python set operations support multiple inputs, while the Numpy equivalents only support two arrays.

A version of intersect1d supporting n arrays was posted to numpy-discussion back in 2009: http://numpy-discussion.10968.n7.nabble.com/intersect1d-for-N-input-arrays-td25956.html

The posted multi-array version works well for me, it would be great to see it (or a variant) in Numpy.

title: Numpy npz files need to not use python literals as header descriptors.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/hardkrash', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/104305?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'hardkrash', 'type': u'User', 'id': 104305, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/followers'}
body:
In issue #5170 we have an incompatibility between npz files from python 2.x opening in python 3.x

This is caused by using a evaluated python literal storing the dictionary used for the header.

This header should be properly serialized.
There are to main options:
- Pickle
- JSON

Please update the npz file format accordingly, evaluated python literals are not a reliable method to store dictionaries.  See file numpy/lib/format.py where the use of a python pretty printed representation is documented.

title: numpy npz files with v1 and v2 formats are not interoperable between python 2 and python 3.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/hardkrash', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/104305?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'hardkrash', 'type': u'User', 'id': 104305, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hardkrash/followers'}
body:
The header is a python literal, unfortunately this leaves the numpy file unreadable when it is an array and the literal for array dimensions are Long integers.  e.g. "{'descr': '<i2', 'fortran_order': False, 'shape': (100L, 200L), }    \n"

When loading with an array in the npz file saved with python 2.x and opening with python 3.x we get the following error.

Exception: SyntaxError('invalid syntax', ('<unknown>', 1, 55, "{'descr': '<i2', 'fortran_order': False, 'shape': (100L, 200L), }    \n"

The 100L and 200L are invalid python 3 literals.
A fix is to run a substitution on them, such as this one, for old files.
header = re.sub(b"(\d+)L", b'\\1', header)

there is no need for own code.

body:
Note that Fortran ignores spaces in this case, so that 'in out' is
treated as 'inout'.

Closes #479.

Rebased for backport to 1.9.0.

body:
gcc 4.1.2 (e.g. in red hat 5) will miscompile the function when
inlining. Without static it will not inline solving the issue.
Closes gh-5163

title: Slicing huge matrix (larger (1.5k,80000k)) overwrites parts of matrix with 0
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/dominikgrimm', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/9111493?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'dominikgrimm', 'type': u'User', 'id': 9111493, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dominikgrimm/followers'}
body: Hi all, I encountered a problem slicing huge matrices. My matrix has approximately the following dimensions M = (1500,8000000) (1.5k, 8 million). I tried to remove some columns of this matrix. However, After the slicing operation is done the new matrix contains the correct dimensions but the tail of the matrix only contains zeros. My machine has 512GB of memory. So this shouldn't be a problem. Here is a small example with random numbers In [1]: import numpy as np In [2]: m = np.random.randn(1500,8000000) In [3]: ind = np.arange(0,7000000) In [4]: new_m = m[:,ind] In [5]: new_m[:,-1] Out[6]: array([ 0., 0., 0., ..., 0., 0., 0.]) The matrix new_m contains now many columns with zeros. In [7]: np.where(new_m.sum(axis=0)==0)[0].shape Out [8]: (5726623,) Is this a problem someone else experienced? Is there a "slicing" limit? Best wishes, Dominik

title: ENH: support parallel compilation of extensions
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
Allow extensions using numpy.distutils to compile in parallel.
By passing `--jobs=n` or `-j n` to `setup.py build` the compilation of
extensions is now performed in `n` parallel processes.
Additionally the environment variable NUMPY_NUM_BUILD_JOBS is used as
the default value, if its unset the default is serial compilation.

The parallelization is limited to within the files of an extension, so
only numpy multiarraymodule really profits but its still a nice
improvement when you have 2-4 cores.
Unfortunately Cython will not profit at all as it tends to build one
module per file.

Currently only CCompiler adapted, but adding Fortran and C++ should be
straightforward.

title: memory leak in ndarray.flatten()?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seth-p', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7441788?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seth-p', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7441788, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seth-p/followers'}
body:
Unless I'm missing something, in numpy 1.9.0 (I haven't checked any other versions) calls to ``ndarray.flatten()`` appear to leak memory. In example below, note how ``wset`` grows by approximately 400mb with every call to ``a.flatten()``. Note also that calls to ``gc.collect()`` don't seem to help.
```

?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
%quickref -> Quick reference.
help      -> Python's own help system.
object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.

In [1]: import os

In [2]: import psutil

In [3]: import numpy as np

In [4]: process = psutil.Process(os.getpid())

In [5]: a = np.arange(100000000).reshape(10000,10000)

In [6]: process.get_ext_memory_info()
Out[6]: pextmem(num_page_faults=107513, peak_wset=439070720, wset=439070720, peak_paged_pool=271496, paged_pool=271496, peak_nonpaged_pool=19152, nonpaged_pool=19104, pagefile=434294784, peak_pagefile=434294784, private=434294784)

In [7]: a.flatten()

In [8]: process.get_ext_memory_info()
Out[8]: pextmem(num_page_faults=205412, peak_wset=840065024, wset=840065024, peak_paged_pool=271496, paged_pool=271496, peak_nonpaged_pool=19272, nonpaged_pool=19224, pagefile=835080192, peak_pagefile=835080192, private=835080192)

In [10]: process.get_ext_memory_info()
Out[10]: pextmem(num_page_faults=303267, peak_wset=1240879104, wset=1240879104, peak_paged_pool=271496, paged_pool=271496, peak_nonpaged_pool=19392, nonpaged_pool=19344, pagefile=1235869696, peak_pagefile=1235869696, private=1235869696)

In [11]: import gc

In [12]: gc.collect()
Out[12]: 56

In [13]: process.get_ext_memory_info()
Out[13]: pextmem(num_page_faults=303267, peak_wset=1240879104, wset=1240879104, peak_paged_pool=271496, paged_pool=271496, peak_nonpaged_pool=19392, nonpaged_pool=19344, pagefile=1235869696, peak_pagefile=1235869696, private=1235869696)

In [14]: a.flatten()
```

body:
`loadtxt` with `comments=None` considers the string `'None'` as a comment symbol.
Fixed by adding the same check `genfromtxt` has.

title: loadtxt(comments=None) considers the string 'None' as a comment symbol

body:
Numpy 1.8.2
`numpy.loadtxt(comments=None)` considers the string `'None'` as a comment symbol.


Expected behaviour:
`comments=None` should indicate that there are no comments symbols. Certainly not cast `None` to a string, what is this, Javascript?

title: Einsum double contraction in particular order causes ValueError
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/alexalemi', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/487667?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'alexalemi', 'type': u'User', 'id': 487667, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alexalemi/followers'}
body:
If I try to do

```python
a = np.random.randn(3,3,3,3)
ans1 = np.einsum('iijj',a)
```

I get a `ValueError`:

    >>> ValueError: dimensions in operand 0 for collapsing index 'j' don't match (0 != 3)

However, these alternatives work:

```python
ans2 = np.einsum('ii', np.einsum('ijkk', a))
ans3 = np.einsum('ijij', np.einsum('ijkl->ikjl',a))
ans2 == ans3
````

    >>> True

And these agree with the naive version up to the last decimal place

````python
ans4 = 0.0
for i in xrange(3):
    for j in xrange(3):
        ans4 += a[i,i,j,j]
np.allclose(ans2, ans4) and np.allclose(ans3, ans4)
````

    >>> True

body:
In Python 2, the following code used to work, but no longer in Python 3:

```
In [6]: x = np.array([1.1, 'a'], dtype=np.object)

In [7]: np.unique(x)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-7-9a478241c930> in <module>()
----> 1 np.unique(x)

/Users/tom/Library/Python/3.4/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/lib/arraysetops.py in unique(ar, return_index, return_inverse, return_counts)
    193         aux = ar[perm]
    194     else:
--> 195         ar.sort()
    196         aux = ar
    197     flag = np.concatenate(([True], aux[1:] != aux[:-1]))

TypeError: unorderable types: float() > str()
```

Is this intended behavior, and if so, are there any suggested alternatives in this situation?

body:
When I search scikit-learn issue, I found strange behaviour of ndarray.std.
Althought I understand this argument is too small value, I report it just in case.
I use Numpy 1.9.0, Python 3.4.1, Linux.

```
In [1]: import numpy as np
In [2]: print((np.zeros(6) + np.log(1e-5)).std())
0.0
In [3]: print((np.zeros(7) + np.log(1e-5)).std())
1.7763568394e-15
In [4]: print((np.zeros(8) + np.log(1e-5)).std())
0.0
In [5]: print((np.zeros(9) + np.log(1e-5)).std())
0.0
In [6]: print((np.zeros(10) + np.log(1e-5)).std())
1.7763568394e-15
In [7]: print((np.zeros(11) + np.log(1e-5)).std())
1.7763568394e-15
In [8]: print((np.zeros(12) + np.log(1e-5)).std())
0.0
```

title: strange behaviour of np.nanmedian in np 1.9.0
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/kwgoodman', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/299024?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'kwgoodman', 'type': u'User', 'id': 299024, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/followers'}
body:
This looks good:

```
In [1]: a = np.array([np.inf,  np.nan])
In [2]: np.nanmedian(a, axis=-1)
Out[2]: inf
```

This looks ungood:

```
In [3]: a = np.array([[np.inf,  np.nan], [np.nan, np.nan]])
In [4]: np.nanmedian(a, axis=-1)
Out[4]: array([ nan,  nan])
```

But this looks good:

```
In [5]: a = np.array([[np.inf,  np.nan], [np.inf, np.nan]])
In [6]: np.nanmedian(a, axis=-1)
Out[6]: array([ inf,  inf])
```

body:
Define it as NPY_RESTRICT
Restrict indicates a memory block does not alias, gcc supports it in c89
with the `__restrict__` keyword.

title: ImportError: No module named thread
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pyhits', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3097275?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pyhits', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3097275, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pyhits/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20low', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: low'}]
body:
When compiling and using numpy 1.9.0 with a single-threaded python, an "import numpy" will lead to an ImportError saying that there is no module named thread. The exception trace looks like follows:
  File ".../lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py", line 189, in <module>
    from . import random
  File ".../lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/random/__init__.py", line 99, in <module>
    from .mtrand import *
  File "mtrand.pyx", line 130, in init mtrand (numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.c:27399)
  File ".../lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 6, in <module>
    import thread
The issue was presumably introduced with commit 94172e1bbaf48e121f90d0252e33dc9f433b1534 of "ENH: replace GIL of random module with a per state lock" where an "from threading import Lock" was added to numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.pyx.

title: ENH: unroll correlate loops
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
Unrolling the inner loop ensures the kernel is placed into registers and
reused, this almost doubles performance.
Also move the function to arraytypes.c.src where also our dot product is
placed.
The templ_common.h might still be useful in future so its kept.

title: Fix rate==0.0 bug in financial.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/liufei11111', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4622463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'liufei11111', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4622463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/liufei11111/followers'}
body:
Original issue:
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/5046
This bug is caused by using numpy.where.
This command will evaluate both expression first and then return based on condition. However, if rate==0.0, the expression will cause an error anyway. We replace the same process with a condition checking and the fix is successful. At the same time, broadcast is not  affected.

title: ENH: add small kernel correlate function
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
For cases like convolve/correlate with small kernel calling out to BLAS
dot is very slow as it goes through many wrappers and BLAS is typically
optimized for very large data.
So add a template utility file and add a special function for small dot
products.
2-4 times faster than openblas dot for kernel sizes < 11.

title: BUG: fix bug in genfromtxt
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/fsteinmetz', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/668201?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'fsteinmetz', 'type': u'User', 'id': 668201, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fsteinmetz/followers'}
body:
genfromtxt was not correctly discarding comments when names=True,
resulting in an exception.
It is not useful in thic context to process the line wrt comments,
because it is done already in split_line(). There was an error because
only the comments were retained.
Closes #3386.

title: ENH: added parameter to use periodic x-coordinates
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/saullocastro', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3889819?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'saullocastro', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3889819, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/followers'}
body:
Using the example given in the current `np.interp()` and changing the intervals to be interpolated to:

    xvals = np.linspace(-np.pi, +np.pi, 50)

will lead to the following result:

![figure_3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3889819/4417109/b4c39028-454e-11e4-801f-cbe59c244e3b.png)

note how the proposed enhancement allows a proper interpolation. The only change is the addition of a `period` parameter:

    yinterp_new = interp(xvals, x, y, period=2*np.pi)

title: BUG subclass ignored for inplace operations
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
Normally, `__array_prepare__` and `__array_wrap__` can be used to prepare output given the subclass. However, for inplace operations where the output is an `ndarray`, these are ignored (independent of `__array_priority__`):
```
import numpy as np
class Mine(np.ndarray):
    __array_priority__ = 10000
    def __array_wrap__(self, obj, context=None):
        raise TypeError

a = np.arange(3.)
me = np.array([2.]).view(Mine)
a * me
# ... TypeError
a *= me
a
# array([ 0.,  2.,  4.])
```
(This is not an issue with `__numpy_ufunc__`)

title: ENH: faster (branchless) logical_xor
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/larsmans', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/335383?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'larsmans', 'type': u'User', 'id': 335383, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/followers'}
body:
Here's an optimization to `logical_xor` for non-`bool` types (because @jaimefrio already tackled those in 494abcf189e9b53e42b624752eb3eaaf46a0dfd3). Current master:

```python
In [1]: x = (np.random.RandomState(30).randn(1e7) > 0).astype(np.intc)

In [2]: y = (np.random.RandomState(30).randn(1e7) > 0).astype(np.intc)

In [3]: %timeit np.logical_xor(x, y)
10 loops, best of 3: 41.6 ms per loop

In [5]: x = x.astype(np.uint8)

In [6]: x = x.astype(np.uint8)

In [7]: y = y.astype(np.uint8)

In [8]: %timeit np.logical_xor(x, y)
10 loops, best of 3: 40.8 ms per loop
```

This PR, same data:

```python
In [3]: %timeit np.logical_xor(x, y)
100 loops, best of 3: 11.5 ms per loop

In [4]: np.all(np.logical_xor(x, y) == (x != y))  # sanity check
Out[4]: True

In [7]: %timeit np.logical_xor(x, y)              # np.uint8
100 loops, best of 3: 9.95 ms per loop
```

For floats the speedup isn't quite as dramatic:

```python
In [9]: x = np.random.RandomState(30).randn(1e7)

In [10]: y = np.random.RandomState(30).randn(1e7)

In [11]: %timeit np.logical_xor(x, y)
10 loops, best of 3: 23.2 ms per loop
```

Now:

```python
In [8]: x = np.random.RandomState(30).randn(1e7)

In [9]: y = np.random.RandomState(30).randn(1e7)

In [10]: %timeit np.logical_xor(x, y)
100 loops, best of 3: 17.4 ms per loop
```

(Then again, who would do a XOR on two float arrays?)

title: argmin/argmax NaN behaviour
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/palob', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7050624?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'palob', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7050624, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/palob/followers'}
body:
Be *A* any *array_like* containing `np.nan`, e.g.
`A = [1,2,0,-2,np.nan,-222,1000,np.pi]`

While `max(A)` and `min(A)` expectedly yields 1000 and -222 both `np.argmin(A)` and `np.argmin(A)` yields `4` which is the index of the NaN value.

I`d expect argmin and argmax to disregard the NaN entry.
However is there any good reason for this behaviour which escapes me?

title: NumPy arrays of objects
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jrjohansson', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1198183?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jrjohansson', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1198183, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jrjohansson/followers'}
body:
Since the recent release 1.9 of NumPy, the numpy.array function no longer infer the type of class instances as object if the class defines a `__getitem__` method. See the following notebook for an example:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/jrjohansson/5c977ba22dc952ce2675

This example is a bit artificial but we first encountered this issue in the QuTiP package: qutip/qutip#228. In earlier versions of NumPy it used to work without explicitly having to specify dtype=object.

I assume that this happens because the numpy.array function iterates over all elements in the list that is passed to it, and in addition also tries to iterate over all values that `__getitem__` item returns. But at least for the use-cases I often encounter this is not a very intuitite behaviour, since it doesn't make much change to unravel custom defined classes into their numerical values just because they define a `__getitem__` function. Is it an intentional change? Or is the way I have use the `__getitem__` function not suitable for using NumPy arrays?

title: BUG: np.unique with chararray + inverse_index
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/perimosocordiae', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/82855?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'perimosocordiae', 'type': u'User', 'id': 82855, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/followers'}
body:
The call to `empty_like` was trying to use the `chararray` subclass, which doesn't support the `np.intp` dtype.


```
In [16]: foo = np.chararray(5)

In [17]: np.unique(foo)
Out[17]: 
chararray([''], 
      dtype='|S1')

In [18]: np.unique(foo, return_inverse=True)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-18-bfdd2379988e> in <module>()
----> 1 np.unique(foo, return_inverse=True)

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/lib/arraysetops.pyc in unique(ar, return_index, return_inverse, return_counts)
    205         if return_inverse:
    206             iflag = np.cumsum(flag) - 1
--> 207             inv_idx = np.empty_like(ar, dtype=np.intp)
    208             inv_idx[perm] = iflag
    209             ret += (inv_idx,)

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/core/defchararray.pyc in __array_finalize__(self, obj)
   1846         # The b is a special case because it is used for reconstructing.
   1847         if not _globalvar and self.dtype.char not in 'SUbc':
-> 1848             raise ValueError("Can only create a chararray from string data.")
   1849 
   1850     def __getitem__(self, obj):

ValueError: Can only create a chararray from string data.
```

title: should logaddexp really give a warning for -inf?

title: numpy.poly gives different answers for vector and diagonal matrix inputs
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ketch', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/697763?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ketch', 'type': u'User', 'id': 697763, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ketch/followers'}
body:
The following code demonstrates this bug:

``` python
import numpy as np
N = 20
v = np.arange(1,N+1)
c1 = np.poly(v)
c2 = np.poly(np.diag(v))
print c1-c2
```
The output is not a zero vector.

See http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/ketch/6be81962868fa9e4fb4f for more.

title: ENH: add keyword `nrows` to `genfromtxt`, closes #5084
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/styra', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7038335?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'styra', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7038335, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/styra/followers'}
body:
Add keyword `nrows` to specify the number of rows to read.
1. We should not use keywords `nrows` and `skip_footer` in the same time. (As skip_footer require loading of the whole file, it seems a bit waste when we have already specified the number of rows to read. And the process for `invalid value` would be more complex with `skip_footer`.)
2. If there's not enough rows (less than nrows) to read, an exception would raise.

Add tests  for the new behavior.

title: Broken stride calculation on master
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mdboom', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/38294?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mdboom', 'type': u'User', 'id': 38294, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/followers'}
body:
I'm running into a problem on Numpy master that I don't see on 1.9.0.  This is enough to trigger it

```
import numpy as np
import io

x = np.arange(10)
y = np.array([x])

print(y.strides)

fd = io.BytesIO()
fd.write(y.data)
```

On Python 2:

```
(9223372036854775807, 4)
```

On Python 3:

```
(9223372036854775807, 4)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "arr.py", line 11, in <module>
    fd.write(y.data)
BufferError: memoryview: underlying buffer is not C-contiguous
```

9223372036854775807 is of course -1, so perhaps this is a deliberate marker for the outermost stride?  (Not sure).  However, Python 3 doesn't seem to like that in the buffer interface.

See astropy/astropy#2960

body:
numpy function `genfromtxt` can skip header and footer lines. However sometimes we might want to control the number of rows to read directly. For example, a txt file might contain  several blocks with different number of columns, we can't read them all in once. Specify `nrow` to read would be convenient.

Is it possible add something like 
`genfromtxt(file,skip_header=1,nrows=2)` ?

title: BUG np.broadcast_arrays does not work on void arrays with object fields
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
In the process of working on #4622, it was realised that `np.broadcas_arrays` do not work for void arrays with object fields, because in the process of changing new strides and shapes in `as_strided`, the `dtype` gets lost, and this cannot just be reset when object fields are present. While obviously this is somewhat of a corner case, it might still be good to see if it can be fixed easily, perhaps by doing something that preserves the dtype, or by bypassing the test for object fields.
```
import numpy as np
dt = np.dtype([('x', 'i8'), ('y', '?'), ('z', 'O')])
b = np.array([(1, True, None), (2, False, [3, 4, 5])], dtype=dt)
c = np.array([[-1], [-2]])
b_strided, c_strided = np.broadcast_arrays(b, c)
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
...
/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/numpy/lib/stride_tricks.py in as_strided(x, shape, strides)
     31     # Make sure dtype is correct in case of custom dtype
     32     if array.dtype.kind == 'V':
---> 33         array.dtype = x.dtype
     34     return array
     35 

TypeError: Cannot change data-type for object array.
```

title: any timedelta should be smaller than inf
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/gerritholl', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/500246?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'gerritholl', 'type': u'User', 'id': 500246, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gerritholl/followers'}
body:
One might argue I shouldn't be doing this, but this behaviour is odd:

    In [325]: timedelta64(0) < float('inf')
    Out[325]: False

Use case: I wanted a value that would compare larger than any timedelta64.  There is `timedelta64('NaT')`, there doesn't appear to be an equivalent for inf/-inf, but comparing consistently to those two seems to make sense.

body:
Rename cblas.h to npy_cblas.h and put it in numpy/core/src/private.
Fix the various includes to account for the change.

It turns out that MKL provides cblas, but not cblas.h. Rather, they
provide mkl_cblas.h, which also uses typedefs for the CBLAS_XXX enums.

title: BUG __numpy_ufunc__ does not properly deal with NotImplemented
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
In continuing to try to get astropy's `Quantity` to behave with `__numpy_ufunc__`, I found what probably is another bug.  One of our tests checks that an integer can be used as an `__index__` to, e.g., multiply a list, as in:
```
import numpy as np
np.array([2]) * ['a', 'b']
```
(which yields `['a', 'b', 'a', 'b']`).

But if I make a trivial class that implements `__numpy_ufunc__`, the `NotImplemented` does not seem to be passed on correctly:
```
class MyA(np.ndarray):
    def __numpy_ufunc__(self, ufunc, method, i, inputs, **kwargs):
        result = getattr(ufunc, method)(*((input.view(np.ndarray)
                                           if isinstance(input, np.ndarray)
                                           else input) for input in inputs),
                                        **kwargs)
        print("Got result={}".format(result))
        return result

np.array([2]).view(MyA) * ['a', 'b']
```
yields
```
Got result=NotImplemented
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-21-b1e259840c66> in <module>()
----> 1 np.array([2]).view(MyA) * ['a', 'b']

TypeError: __numpy_ufunc__ not implemented for this type.
```

p.s. This may be related to #4815

title: np.atleast_2d of sparse matrix returns a 1x1 ndarray containing the sparse matrix object

body:
I assume this falls under "numpy doesn't know about your custom matrix-like objects so they are not our problem" but I thought I'd mention this anyway because it was obscuring a bug in another project.  Feel free to close as invalid.

```python
import numpy as np
import scipy.sparse

a = scipy.sparse.identity(2).tocsc()
print a

b = np.atleast_2d(a)
print b
```

```
  (0, 0)        1.0
  (1, 1)        1.0
[[ <2x2 sparse matrix of type '<type 'numpy.float64'>'
        with 2 stored elements in Compressed Sparse Column format>]]
```

title: np.inner segfaults with SciPy's sparse matrices
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/drwells', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3917035?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'drwells', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3917035, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/followers'}
body:
The function `np.inner` segfaults with some of SciPy's sparse matrices. I suspect that it will segfault for other matrix-like things. Here is a minimal working example:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
from __future__ import print_function
import numpy as np
import scipy.sparse as sp

a = np.linspace(1, 2, 4)
values = np.linspace(1, 2, 6)
rows = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3, 0, 1])
columns = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3, 1, 2])
mass = sp.coo_matrix((values, (rows, columns))).tocsc()

print(np.version.full_version)
print("The next line causes a segmentation fault:")
print(np.inner(a, mass))
```

with output
```bash
[drwells@archway ~]$ python test.py 
1.8.2
The next line causes a segmentation fault:
zsh: segmentation fault (core dumped)  python test.py
```

I also observed the same crash with numpy `1.7.0`.

body:
Running the following code with numpy 1.8.1

```
import numpy

class C(object):
    def __index__(self):
        return 0
    def __len__(self):
        return 1
    def __getitem__(self, item):
        raise IndexError

x = numpy.array([1])
i = C()
print(repr(x[i]))
```

I get

```
*** Reference count error detected:
an attempt was made to deallocate 5 (i) ***
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "x.py", line 13, in <module>
    print(x[i])
  File "x.py", line 9, in __getitem__
    raise NotImplementedError
NotImplementedError
```

With 1.9.0, I don't get a reference error, but the result is still wrong:

```
array([1])
```

(I expect `1`.)

title: add C-API PyArray_IsAnyScalarExact
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
PyArray_IsAnyScalarExact checks if an object is exactly any numpy scalar, this allows skipping some costly attribute lookups like `__array_priority__` and `__numpy_ufunc__`.

this improves the array_scalar * numpy_scalar performance issue seen in gh-5030 by about a factor of two.

body:
There's a typo at the end of the _Notes_ paragraph in [numpy.percentile](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.percentile.html#numpy.percentile):

    minimum if q=0``and the same as the maximum if ``q=100.

Also there's a mention of an _interpolation paramete_ without any explanation of what that is. Perhaps a bit more detail would be good?

title: Inconsistent behavior with numpy.unique on array of tuples between 1.8.0 and 1.8.1
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/gkenway', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5203633?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'gkenway', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5203633, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gkenway/followers'}
body:
I use numpy.unique to generate a unique list of tuples. On version 1.8.0, it gives the correct results. For example:
```
Python 2.7.5 (default, Aug  2 2014, 16:01:27)
[GCC 4.8.1] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> splits =  [(0, 1), (0, 33), (2, 1), (2, 49)]
>>> import numpy
>>> numpy.unique(splits)
array([[ 0,  1],
       [ 0, 33],
       [ 2,  1],
       [ 2, 49]])
>>> numpy.__version__
'1.8.0'
>>> 
```
However, on version 1.8.1, the exact code gives
```
Python 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:56)
[GCC 4.8.2] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import numpy
>>> splits =  [(0, 1), (0, 33), (2, 1), (2, 49)]
>>> numpy.unique(splits)
array([[ 0,  1],
       [ 0, 33],
       [ 2, 49],
       [ 1,  2]])
>>> numpy.__version__
'1.8.1'
```
The (2,1) tuples gets flipped to (1,2). I can probably find a way around this. I'm not sure if it is just a fluke that it works correctly on 1.8.0 and not 1.8.1. If this sorting is actually undefined for tuples, it probably should raise an error instead of returning inconsistent results.  I can probably find a way around this for my particular application, but I won't be depending on the specific behavior of numpy.unique in the future.

body: I wanted to use numpy.repeat to get an array of repeated integers with a specific dtype, but it does not accept a dtype argument.  I can work around this by first converting the list of python integers to be repeated into a numpy array with the dtype that I want, but I'd rather be able to specify a dtype in the numpy.repeat function.

title: ravel(A) should return a view if ravel(squeeze(A)) does
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sdrave', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2648288?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sdrave', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2648288, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sdrave/followers'}
body:
With NumPy 1.8.2 I get:
```python
>>> from numpy import *
>>> A = zeros((2, 1)).T

>>> ravel(A)[:] = 1
>>> A
array([[ 0.,  0.]])

>>> ravel(squeeze(A))[:] = 1
>>> A
array([[ 1.,  1.]])
```
This is probably due to the fact that
```python
>>> zeros((2, 1)).T.strides
(8, 8)
```
in contrast to
```python
>>> zeros((1, 2)).strides
(16, 8)
```

body:
A similar issue was raised in #2670, however the edge case of (0, ) shape is still not covered. I can go around it with checking for non-zero length in an ``if`` statement, but it would be more practical if ``np.min`` could handle this, too.


title: MAINT: Make numpy/lib/polynomial/polyval a bit faster.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Multiplying a numpy_scalar times a numpy_array is much faster than
the other way around. This PR switches the order of multiplication
in the polyval function resulting in a speedup of about 5x for scalar
values of x.

Closes #4610.

title: numpy.arange. Wrong last element in some cases. python 2.7.8, numpy 1.8.2. x64
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Njallnir', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/8624168?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Njallnir', 'type': u'User', 'id': 8624168, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Njallnir/followers'}
body:
For this script
```
import numpy as np
start = 0.15
stop1 = 1.25
stop2 = 1.35
step = 0.1
a = np.arange(start, stop1, step)
print a
print a[-1] == stop1
b = np.arange(start, stop2, step)
print b
print b[-1] == stop2
```
I received the following answer:
```
[ 0.15  0.25  0.35  0.45  0.55  0.65  0.75  0.85  0.95  1.05  1.15]
False
[ 0.15  0.25  0.35  0.45  0.55  0.65  0.75  0.85  0.95  1.05  1.15  1.25
  1.35]
True
```
Arange should return values from the interval [start, stop), but in the second case it included and the value stop2.

title: BUG: fix percentage reporting when testing.assert_allclose fails.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pp-mo', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2089069?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pp-mo', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2089069, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pp-mo/followers'}
body:
Aims to address : https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/2912

I separated the inner calculation of 'allclose' into a separate routine for assert_allclose to use it.
This now conforms to the expected behaviour of 'comparison' in assert_array_compare.
Governing concepts:
 * subsidiary routine is private, to avoid extending the api with more routines to support
 * assuming ultimate efficiency is not a big deal for this, so extra function call is ok
 * in an ideal world, this function would be simply 'isclose', but I think that equivalence can't now be assured, and we must leave legacy routines as they are.

title: Comparison operators do not broadcast on object arrays containing arrays
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jakevdp', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/781659?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jakevdp', 'type': u'User', 'id': 781659, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jakevdp/followers'}
body:
This came up [on StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25559027/numpy-where-command-on-arrays-with-dtype-object/25559892) and struck me as pretty strange.

Here is a short demo of the issue (Python 2.x):

``` python
>>> foo = np.array([range(3), 3])
>>> foo
array([[0, 1, 2], 3], dtype=object)
>>> foo == 3
array([False,  True], dtype=bool)
```
As expected, a boolean array over elements.

Now make the list a numpy array:
``` python
>>> foo = np.array([np.arange(3), 3])
>>> foo
array([array([0, 1, 2]), 3], dtype=object)
>>> foo == 3
False
```

I would expect this to raise a ValueError similar to
``` python
>>> bool(np.arange(3) == 3)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-39-a599a9f5d187> in <module>()
----> 1 bool(np.arange(3) == 3)

ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all()
```
Not broadcasting the equality comparison in ``foo == 3`` is very unexpected. Is this intended behavior?
