So I tried running it in different ways:
```
Python 2.7.6 (default, May 29 2014, 17:32:27)
[GCC Intel(R) C++ gcc 4.4 mode] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import numpy as np
>>> from skimage.io import ImageCollection
>>> imc = ImageCollection('/share/experiments/ahm/projections/Block_1_*.tiff')
>>> for i in xrange(len(imc)):
...  low = np.percentile(imc[i],0)
...  hi = np.percentile(imc[i],98)
...
*** glibc detected *** python2.7: double free or corruption (out): 0x0000000003525120 ***
```
But, I have no problem in running it outside loop:
```
Python 2.7.6 (default, May 29 2014, 17:32:27)
[GCC Intel(R) C++ gcc 4.4 mode] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import numpy as np
>>> from skimage.io import ImageCollection
>>> imc=ImageCollection('/share/experiments/ahm/projections/Block_1_*.tiff')
>>> low, hi = np.percentile(imc[0],(0,98))
>>> low
13783.0
>>> hi
23991.0
```

It's just when I used `np.percentile` in loop then things got messy. I used numpy 1.9.0.dev-c24cc4e in this case, but on my other machine with numpy 1.8.0 has no problem at all.

Best regards,
Habib

title: add iterative methods and reordering algorithms
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/SaintDako', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5009136?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'SaintDako', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5009136, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/SaintDako/followers'}
body:
I noticed that numpy doesn't have any iterative methods for solving linear systems (Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel, SOR, conjugate gradient...) and was interested in adding it.

on top of that, there are no reordering algorithms to reduce the bandwidth of a matrix ( (Reverse-)Cuthill-McKee, the greedy algorithm I can't remember the name of...), although this may be more suitable for scipy.linalg as (R)CM is best operated on sparse matrices. I'd be willing to add this too. :)

title: numpy.ndarray.ctypes.data returns invalid pointer
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/bennahugo', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7934586?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'bennahugo', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7934586, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bennahugo/followers'}
body:
I suspect passing a numpy.ndarray.ctypes.data pointer to a C function using the c_types package actually only passes a 32-bit pointer. This caused some indeterministic behaviour for me (it obviously works depending on the allocated address itself), so the bug cannot be reproduced easily. 

The API states it returns this as a "A pointer to the memory area of the array as a Python integer". I believe it should instead return ctypes.c_size_t in order to be compatible with 64-bit addressing?

Current work-around:
When I used data_as(obj) with a ctypes.c_void_p the problem is resolved.

body: Under Python 3, files open in write mode were not recognized as file objects, triggering large memory copies with `np.save`.

body:
In our applications, we often represent datetime as a np.array with dtype
`[('YY', '<i4'), ('MM', '<i4'), ('DD', '<i4'), ('hh', '<i4'), ('mm', '<i4'), ('ss', '<f8')]`

title: BUG: handle rounding issue with histogram edges on float32 data
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
Following inequality causes wrong counting at the edges and can be avoided by
making the edge array of the same type as the input data.

```
In [1]: np.around(np.float64(6010.36962890625), 5)
Out[1]: 6010.3696300000001
In [2]: np.around(np.float32(6010.36962890625), 5)
Out[2]: 6010.3701
```

Closes gh-4799

title: BUG __numpy_ufunc__ gives unexpected TypeError with subclasses
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
I'm trying to use `__numpy_ufunc__` for astropy `Quantity` and found surprising difficulties with subclasses, where `<Q-subclass>+<Q>` yields a `TypeError` while `<Q>+<Q-subclass>` works (see below for a simple example using just `ndarray` subclasses). This behaviour seems surprising. Am I missing something?
```
import numpy as np
np.version.version
# '1.9.0.dev-133d4f4'
class MyA(np.ndarray):                                
    def __numpy_ufunc__(self, ufunc, method, i, inputs, **kwargs):
        return getattr(ufunc, method)(*(input.view(np.ndarray) for input in inputs), **kwargs)

class MyA2(MyA):                                      
    pass

np.arange(2.).view(MyA) + np.arange(2.).view(MyA2)
# array([ 0.,  2.])
np.arange(2.).view(MyA2) + np.arange(2.).view(MyA)
# TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'MyA2' and 'MyA'
```

body:
I've got a large (7000,180,3600) masked array that I've been sending to numpy.ma.median.
Prior to the function call memory used on the system is 20Gb (I have a bunch of other variables I'm also dealing with), and upon the function call memory quickly increases to 200 and then 300Gb! without even returning a result (I kill the job before it completes)

Is this expected behaviour?

I've tried using the overwrite_input=True option, however this doesn't seem to resolve anything. 

I'm using python 2.7.4 and numpy 1.7.1

title: numpy.linalg hangs with multiprocessing and OpenBLAS / Linux
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/vmarkovtsev', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2793551?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'vmarkovtsev', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2793551, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/vmarkovtsev/followers'}
body:
Consider the following code:
```Python
import numpy
from numpy.linalg import inv
from multiprocessing import Process

def hang():
    a = numpy.identity(3)
    b = inv(a)


p = Process(target=hang)
p.start()
p.join()
```

If numpy uses OpenBLAS, it hangs forever consuming 100% CPU with OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS>1. If export OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS=1, it works OK.
I am testing this code on 32-core machine, if this matters.
It may be related to issue #654 

numpy version 1.8.1
python version 3.4.1
openblas version 0.2.8
ubuntu 14.04

title: Align bloat
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
this PR fixes two bugs that lead to arrays not having correct alignment flag and limits the maximum required alignment to 16 bytes, the largest loads numpy does for long doubles.

the one bug is a missing alignment update on array transposes which can break alignment for structured arrays.
the other more significant one was in the main creation routine did not set the alignment flag for input data pointers that are aligned and did set the flag when when malloc did not provide the right alignment (only known platform with the property is sparc for long doubles).
The former had the effect that sometimes arrays that are aligned did not have the alignment flag, e.g. this slowed down ufunc_at significantly.
The latter caused arrays that were not aligned to have alignment flags due to the assumption that malloc works as it should. This now again causes f2py test failures on the broken platforms as the inout intent cannot be satisfied anymore when the array is unaligned as fortran knows no unaligned memory. Also several tests failed randomly due to exact flag match tests. Those tests are now disabled on this platform.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/smoneck', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7861774?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'smoneck', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7861774, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/smoneck/followers'}
body:
Hello together,

the -= assignment seems to break for matrices > (90,90).

**Reproduction**

    import numpy as np
        for a in xrange(200):
        px=np.arange(a)
        #px=np.random.random(a)
        dx = np.repeat(px[np.newaxis, :], a, axis=0) - np.repeat(px[:, np.newaxis], a, axis=1)
        dx2 = np.repeat(px[np.newaxis, :], a, axis=0)
        dx2 -= dx2.T
        if len(np.nonzero(dx-dx2)[0]) != 0:
            print a
            break

I'm using  `numpy` version 1.8.1.

Cheers,
Stephan

# -------
Edit: I tested it on different machines:

It gives out
- 91 on`numpy` version 1.6.2, 1.8.0 and 1.8.1.
- 3 on 1.3.0

title: FIX pickling ufuncs defined in nested modules
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ogrisel', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/89061?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ogrisel', 'type': u'User', 'id': 89061, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogrisel/followers'}
body:
This is a fix for the following problem with ufuncs that are not defined in a top level module:

```
>>> from scipy.special import expit
>>> import pickle
>>> pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(expit))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<ipython-input-4-c8a97e87e418>", line 1, in <module>
    pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(expit))
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/pickle.py", line 1382, in loads
    return Unpickler(file).load()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/pickle.py", line 858, in load
    dispatch[key](self)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/pickle.py", line 1133, in load_reduce
    value = func(*args)
  File "/volatile/ogrisel/envs/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/__init__.py", line 56, in _ufunc_reconstruct
    return getattr(mod, name)
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'expit'
```

Unfortunately I don't know how to write a test in numpy as all its ufuncs are importable from the namespace of the top level `numpy` package as far as I know.

title: Missing data point in histogram2d when using float32 arrays
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/eyurtsev', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3205522?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'eyurtsev', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3205522, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/eyurtsev/followers'}
body:
I am getting an incorrect count from the histogram2d function when using arrays with dtype=numpy.float32. Specifically, the histogram2d fails to count one of the data points when I use bins=100.

If on the other hand I put dtype=numpy.float64, then I get an output of 3 from both function calls below.

```python
import numpy

x = numpy.array([276.318359  , -69.593948  , 21.329449], dtype=numpy.float32)
y = numpy.array([5005.689453, 4481.327637, 6010.369629], dtype=numpy.float32)

counts_hist, xedges, yedges = numpy.histogram2d(x, y, bins=200)
print sum(sum(counts_hist)) # <-- outputs 3

counts_hist, xedges, yedges = numpy.histogram2d(x, y, bins=100)
print sum(sum(counts_hist)) # <-- outputs 2, but expecting 3
```

# Information

eyurtsev@puddles:~/Desktop$ uname -a
Linux puddles 3.13.0-24-generic #47-Ubuntu SMP Fri May 2 23:30:00 UTC 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

eyurtsev@puddles:~/Desktop$ ipython -c 'import numpy; print numpy.__version__'
1.8.1

Python 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:56) 


Please let me know if there is any more information I can provide that will be helpful.

title: BLD: workaround msvc being stupid
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
Apparently it tries to respect calling conventions for static inline
functions so the 4th variable can't be passed over the stack as it needs
16 byte alignment.
Work around this by passing the variable as a pointer.
Closes gh-4795

body:
The Visual Studio 2008 and 2010 compilers for 32 bit fail to build numpy 1.9.0b2 . The 64 bit builds succeed. The compiler error is:
```
numpy\core\src\umath\simd.inc.src(486) : error C2719: 'r4': formal parameter with __declspec(align('16')) won't be aligned
```

title: BUG: Correct behavior for lists of tuples in unique, closes #4785
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
`np.unique` produces wrong results when passed a list of tuples and
no keyword arguments, as it fails to recognize it as a multidim
array, but handles it as a 1D array of objects. The only way around
this seems to be to completely eliminate the fast path for non-array
inputs using `set`.

title: numpy.unique inconsistent behavior on array of tuples
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/qnzhou', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3606672?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'qnzhou', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3606672, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/qnzhou/followers'}
body:
I have noticed that numpy.unique have inconsistent behavior on array of tuples depending on whether return_inverse flag is set:

```
import numpy
a = [(1, 2), (1, 2), (2, 3)]
a1 = numpy.unique(a)
a2, a_inverse = numpy.unique(a, return_inverse=True)
print(a1)
print(a2)
```

The output is:
```
[[1 2]
 [2 3]]
[1 2 3]
```

It seems setting `return_inverse` will cause the array of tuples to be flattened, otherwise the array will not be flattened.  Could this be fixed so numpy.unique would have consistent behavior (ideally, not flatten array of tuples)?  Thanks!

python version: 2.7.6
numpy version: 1.8.1

title: BUG: Avoid double iterator deallocation in `ufunc_object.c`
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
In `PyUFunc_GeneralizedFunction`, whenever a call to
`NpyIter_GetIterNext` fails, `NpyIter_Deallocate` is called twice, one
right after the error check, the second in the `goto fail`. Removed
the first one.

title: ENH: use copyswap instead of memmove for flat assignment
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
improves d.flat = x performance by about 35% for basic types as the
copyswap functions have known elementsizes and these are implemented
optimally by the compiler while for the generic call the compiler needs
to call out to libc.

title: PR #4606 introduces regression into astropy table join
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/taldcroft', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/348089?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'taldcroft', 'type': u'User', 'id': 348089, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/taldcroft/followers'}
body:
The numpy commit e47a50efc284c677ba4d0337e11dc8514fca7e5b causes a failure of an astropy test that works fine with all previous numpy versions through 1.5.  This was determined with git bisect on numpy dev.

The failure manifests as an apparent leak of memory bytes between two tables during a table join operation.  This is demonstrated below.  Apologies that I haven't had time to make a simpler test to reproduce without using the `astropy.table.np_utils.join` function, but perhaps the symptoms may be obvious enough?  If not I can try harder to figure out where this is happening within the `join` function.

This is discussed in https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/2281.

```
In [8]: t1
Out[8]: 
array([('M31', '2012-01-02', 17.0, 16.0),
       ('M82', '2012-10-29', 16.2, 15.2),
       ('M101', '2012-10-31', 15.1, 15.5)], 
      dtype=[('name', 'S4'), ('obs_date', 'S10'), ('mag_b', '<f8'), ('mag_v', '<f8')])

In [9]: t2
Out[9]: 
array([('NGC3516', '2011-11-11', 42.1), ('M31', '1999-01-05', 43.1),
       ('M82', '2012-10-29', 45.0)], 
      dtype=[('name', 'S7'), ('obs_date', 'S10'), ('logLx', '<f8')])

In [10]: from astropy.table import np_utils

In [11]: t3 = np_utils.join(t1, t2, keys='name', join_type='left')

In [12]: t3
Out[12]: 
masked_array(data = [('M101516', '2012-10-31', 15.1, 15.5, --, --)
 ('M31', '2012-01-02', 17.0, 16.0, '1999-01-05', 43.1)
 ('M82', '2012-10-29', 16.2, 15.2, '2012-10-29', 45.0)],
             mask = [(False, False, False, False, True, True)
 (False, False, False, False, False, False)
 (False, False, False, False, False, False)],
       fill_value = ('N/A', 'N/A', 1e+20, 1e+20, 'N/A', 1e+20),
            dtype = [('name', 'S7'), ('obs_date_1', 'S10'), ('mag_b', '<f8'), ('mag_v', '<f8'), ('obs_date_2', 'S10'), ('logLx', '<f8')])


In [13]: print t3
[('M101516', '2012-10-31', 15.1, 15.5, --, --)
 ('M31', '2012-01-02', 17.0, 16.0, '1999-01-05', 43.1)
 ('M82', '2012-10-29', 16.2, 15.2, '2012-10-29', 45.0)]
```
The expected first value of the first row is `'M101'`.  It appears that the final three characters of the first value in the `t2` table are leaking into the `t3` table (the `516` characters from `NGC3516`).

title: Multiprocessing hangs on Mac OS X without MKL
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ppeder08', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5364988?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ppeder08', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5364988, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ppeder08/followers'}
body:
This bug occurs on Mac OS X 10.9 (but does not seem to occur on Linux and Windows) with both Python 2.7 and Python 3.3 at least for numpy 1.8.1 not compiled with MKL.

The following piece of code reproduces the bug:

```
import multiprocessing as mp

import numpy as np


def compute(n):
    print('Enter')
    np.dot(np.eye(n), np.eye(n))
    print('Exit')


print('\nWithout multiprocessing:')
compute(1000)

print('\nWith multiprocessing:')
workers = mp.Pool(1)
results = workers.map(compute, (1000, 1000))
```

The above code hangs in the `workers.map` call when executing `np.dot(np.eye(n), np.eye(n))`.

If the sequential call to `compute` is ommitted, the code runs as it should. Also, if the argument `n` is reduced sufficiently (< 100 on the computer which the bug was detected on), the code runs as it should. Again, the bug is not present when numpy is compiled with MKL.

title: byteswap regression in v1.8.0b1~149^2 leads to Bus error on sparcs

body:
with 1.8.x on sparcs pytables started to experience a bus error (didn't
happen with 1.7.1).  bisect fun seems to lead to

commit 99cb95f7379a95f978fd04d183fde2d262b262a6
ENH: optimize byteswapping via intrinsics

Byteswapping is implemented in hardware on x86 cpus which is more than     double as fast than the existing implementation.     The masked version used for 32bit plays better with compiler pattern     matching so it can be optimized also by non-gcc/clang compilers.

```

317                 *a_ = __builtin_bswap32(*a_);

body:
The version check was not valid for python3, though the whole logic can
be removed with a finally clause.
This requires that the savez tests need to cleanup the NpyzFile results
which still hold an open file descriptor.

title: Memory leak in numpy version 1.8.0
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/RorySmith', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6014610?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'RorySmith', 'type': u'User', 'id': 6014610, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/RorySmith/followers'}
body:
Hi,

I've noticed what I believe to be a memory leak when using numpy.dot to take the dot product of elements of an array. Below is some example code which highlights the issue.


import numpy as np

e=  np.zeros((400, 1024*2048))

for i in range(len(e)):
        g = np.dot(e[i],e[i])

title: ENH: add storage format 2.0 with 4 byte header size
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
The new format only increases the header length field to 4 bytes.
allows storing structured arrays with a large number of named columns.
The dtype serialization for these can exceed the 2 byte header length
field required by the 1.0 format.
The generic functions automatically use the 2.0 format if the to be
stored data requires it. To avoid unintentional incompatibilies a
UserWarning is emitted when this happens.
If the format is not required the more compatible 1.0 format is used.

Closes gh-4690

title: RandomState_ctor accesses /dev/urandom, a significant bottleneck when copying RandomStates
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/depristo', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2250400?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'depristo', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2250400, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/depristo/followers'}
body:
The RandomState_ctor function in numpy.random.__init__ makes an call to construct a new RandomState object without an explicit seed.  The unseeded call results in an access to /dev/urandom which is wildly expensive.  Given that the purpose of this function to add in pickling, so that the internal state will be updated to reflect the state of the pickled RandomState, this expensive access actually don't do anything.  Because the state of the newly created RandomState is irrelevant (it'll be updated by pickling), its safe to use the fast cached seed value of 0.  An example of updating the function is below as well as a nosetest backed unit test that verifies behavior.  In order to incorporate into master branch the code in __init__.py in random simply needs to have seed=0 added to it.

```
def __Fast_RandomState_ctor():
    """Patch the __RandomState_ctor initialization routine for performance

    numpy.random.__init__.__RandomState_ctor calls RandomState() directly, which
    interacts with the filesystem and kernel via /dev/urandom, causing a major performance
    bottleneck running many short parallel jobs.

    This function overrides that code and uses the seed=0 version to avoid the bad
    system call interaction.  As far as I can tell this is totally kosher, as this
    routine appears to be used for pickling only, and produces a random state object
    that will be initialized in some other way later.

    """
    return RandomState(seed=0)

numpy.random.__RandomState_ctor = __Fast_RandomState_ctor
```

Unit test to verify behavior works:
```
def test_copy_random_state():
    """Test that we can deep copy a random state properly

    Checks that our constructor optimization is safe
    """
    def state_eq(ran1, ran2):
        """Need to know too much about structure of RandomState.get_state()"""
        name1, state1 = ran1.get_state()[0:2]
        name2, state2 = ran2.get_state()[0:2]
        nose.tools.eq_(name1, name2)
        nose.tools.ok_((state1 == state2).all())

    def checkme(seed):
        """Ensure that RandomState created with seed can be duplicated properly"""
        if seed == 'no_arg':
            state = np.random.RandomState()
        else:
            state = np.random.RandomState(seed=seed)
        dup1 = copy.deepcopy(state)     # dup1 is the same as state
        state_eq(state, dup1)
        state_rands = (state.rand(), state.rand(), state.rand())
        dup1_rand1 = dup1.rand()        # dup1 is two behind state
        dup2 = copy.deepcopy(dup1)      # dup2 is == dup1, and two behind state
        state_eq(dup1, dup2)

        dup1_rands = (dup1_rand1, dup1.rand(), dup1.rand())
        dup2_rands = (dup1_rand1, dup2.rand(), dup2.rand())
        nose.tools.eq_(state_rands, dup1_rands, 'Original and immediate duplicate produce random numbers')
        nose.tools.eq_(state_rands, dup2_rands, 'Dup2 should be dup1 + 1 rand')

        # ensure that we're really not synchronized
        state.rand()
        for _ in range(100):
            nose.tools.assert_not_equal(state.rand(), dup1.rand())
            nose.tools.assert_not_equal(state.rand(), dup2.rand())

    nose.tools.eq_(np.random.__RandomState_ctor, __Fast_RandomState_ctor)

    yield checkme, 0
    yield checkme, None
    yield checkme, 'no_arg'
    yield checkme, [1, 2, 3]
```

title: ENH: rewrite ma.median to improve poor performance for multiple dimensions
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
many masked median along a small dimension is extremely slow due to the
usage of apply_along_axis which iterates fully in python. The unmasked
median is about 1000x faster.
    
Work around this issue by using indexing to select the median element
instead of apply_along_axis.
    
Further improvements are possible, e.g. using the current np.nanmedian
approach for masked medians along large dimensions so partition is used
instead of sort or to extend partition to allow broadcasting over
multiple elements.
    
Closes gh-4683.

title: meshgrid silently ignores unknown arguments.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mforbes', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1028433?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mforbes', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1028433, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/followers'}
body:
The ``meshgrid`` function silently ignores arguments.

```python
>>> import numpy
>>> X, Y = numpy.meshgrid(range(3), range(4), indexing='ij')
>>> x, y = numpy.ogrid[:3,:4]
>>> np.allclose(X, x) and np.allclose(Y, y)
True
>>> X, Y = numpy.meshgrid(range(3), range(4), indices='ij')  # OOPS!

title: BUG cannot specify second output to ufunc as keyword argument
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
Currently, it does not seem possible to pass on an array to catch the second output of a `ufunc` via a keyword parameter:
```
a1 = np.array([1.])
a2 = np.array([1.])
np.modf(1.333, out=a1, out2=a2)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-9ca83f6d80bd> in <module>()
----> 1 np.modf(1.333, out=a1, out2=a2)

ValueError: cannot specify 'out' as both a positional and keyword argument
```

One can do `np.modf(1.333, out=a1)`, which works as expected. If one gives instead `np.modf(1.333, out2=a2)`, the first part is assigned to `a2`.  (Note that the documentation suggests to use `out1, out2`, but any characters after `out` simply seem to be skipped.)

It would seem good to have the option of giving these as keyword arguments.  One solution might be to have it be consistent with the usage in `__numpy_ufunc__`, i.e., one would give `np.modf(values, out=(a1, a2))`.

title: PyObject_AsWriteBuffer does not work on Fortran-order array in Python 3
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/inducer', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/352067?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'inducer', 'type': u'User', 'id': 352067, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/followers'}
body:
This snippet of code works for me in Python 2.7, but fails in Python 3.4 with the following error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "a.py", line 9, in <module>
    ctypes.addressof(buf), ctypes.addressof(l))
TypeError: expected an object with a writable buffer interface
```

I'm using numpy 1.8.1 in both cases.

```
import numpy as np
import ctypes

a = np.empty((10, 20), np.float32, order='F')
buf = ctypes.c_void_p()
l = ctypes.c_size_t()
ctypes.pythonapi.PyObject_AsWriteBuffer(
    ctypes.py_object(a),
    ctypes.addressof(buf), ctypes.addressof(l))
```

title: ENH: improve VOID_compare performance
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
use small memory cache for the temporary data allocation in the compare
loop and use npy_is_aligned instead of the very expensive signed
division.

Improves unaligned compares which occur in structured arrays with
strings:

d = np.ones((2,10000), dtype=np.dtype([('f0', 'S5'), ('f1', '<i4')]))
%timeit np.argsort(d)
100 loops, best of 3: 8.6 ms per loop

vs before:
100 loops, best of 3: 23.7 ms per loop

title: BUG: Fix missing fragment in ARGOUTVIEWM typemaps.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/dfroger', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/697102?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'dfroger', 'type': u'User', 'id': 697102, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/followers'}
body:
The argout typemaps of all the ARGOUTVIEWM typemap suites make use of the
free_cap function, defined in the NumPy_Utilities fragment, which was not
listed in the fragment argument of the typemaps.

As a result, the free_cap function is not included in the source generated
code by SWIG, and the code do not compile (unless another typemap including
the missing fragment has been used).

body:
Forwarding the bug from Debian:
https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=749195

Hi,

The patch provided (against version 1.8.1-1) allows to get this package compiled in OpenRISC/or1k architecture that Christian and I are creating in Debian.

After installing python-numpy and python-nose, most of the unit tests seem to pass, and the ones that do not pass might be due to underlying problems in blas or others (e.g. threading issues in the platform) that we still have to work out.

Cheers.

title: numpy.i contains duplicated code.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/dfroger', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/697102?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'dfroger', 'type': u'User', 'id': 697102, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dfroger/followers'}
body:
In numpy.i, (NumPy 1.8.1), the 4 typemap suites for ARGOUTVIEWM for 4D arrays are
duplicated:

    sed -n 2737,2887p numpy.i > part0.i
    sed -n 2889,3039p numpy.i > part1.i
    diff part0.i part1.i

Seems that the first part can be removed (and that it contains a bug at line
2827, overriden by the second part).

title: ENH: speed-up minimum, maximum and xor for bool dtype
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
Replaced the operations for the above ufuncs on bools, by simpler
single instructions.

On random inputs `np.minimum` and `np.maximum` run about 25% faster,
and `np.logical_xor` and `np.bitwise_xor` almost 3x faster.

title: numpy.conjugate and numpy.ndarray.conjugate behave inconsistently
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/andyjost', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/887544?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'andyjost', 'type': u'User', 'id': 887544, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andyjost/followers'}
body:
If x is an ndarray of objects that define a method "conjugate", then numpy.conjugate(x) takes the conjugate of each element, but x.conjugate() does nothing.

>>> numpy.version.git_revision
'697316a867a32e9f72778a29226c9febbf867ee8'
>>> numpy.version.version
'1.7.1'
>>> numpy.version.release
True


>>> class Object(object):
...   def conjugate(self, *args, **kwds):
...     print 'Calling conjugate'
...     return self
...
>>> o = Object()
>>> o.conjugate()
Calling conjugate
<__main__.Object object at 0x18db1c90>
>>> oo = numpy.array([o,o])
>>> numpy.conjugate(oo)
Calling conjugate
Calling conjugate
array([<__main__.Object object at 0x18db1c90>,
       <__main__.Object object at 0x18db1c90>], dtype=object)
>>> oo.conjugate()
array([<__main__.Object object at 0x18db1c90>,
       <__main__.Object object at 0x18db1c90>], dtype=object)

title: Make windows installers quiet,  issue #572
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mathijs-dumon', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/364371?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mathijs-dumon', 'type': u'User', 'id': 364371, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mathijs-dumon/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Official%20binaries', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Official binaries'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Enhancement', 'color': u'e102d8', 'name': u'Enhancement'}]
body:
The possibility for a silent numpy and/or scipy installer has been requested a number of times.
I have made a number of changes that should enable this, please review this. I'm not familiar with compiling numpy, so this is untested!

The basic idea is to create MSI installers instead of exe's. Then we can use msiexec and pass it a silent flag if the NSIS installer was passed a silent flag. This can be achieved using the NSIS 'IfSilent' directive.

title: arrays could support getsizeof()
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pitrou', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1721820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pitrou', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1721820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pitrou/followers'}
body:
sys.getsizeof() uses the ``__sizeof__`` method, if defined, to return a Python object's full memory footprint (including owned data areas that lay outside of the basic object structure).

Currently:
```
>>> x = np.zeros((20000,))
>>> x.nbytes 
160000
>>> sys.getsizeof(x)
80
```

On the other hand, since the underlying buffer can be shared by several objects, it's not obvious how non-misleading the answer would be.

title: argsort does not work for multidimensional arrays

body:
consider the following code:
    a = np.random.random([5,5])
    ind = np.argsort(a, axis=1)
    a_sorted = a[ind]
    np.sort(a, axis=1)

now a_sorted and a should be both sorted along the 1-axis. However not even the shapes are identical anymore. a is still of (5,5) while a_sorted is (5,5,5). If this is the intended behaviour, can someone tell me why?

title: fails to compile on AIX
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/fz0dbx', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7605711?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'fz0dbx', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7605711, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fz0dbx/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20build', 'color': u'e11d21', 'name': u'component: build'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}]
body:
I am building numpy on AIX 6.1 using the xlc compilers.  They are failing with errors like this:
creating build/temp.aix-6.1-2.7/build/src.aix-6.1-2.7/numpy/core/src/npysort
compile options: '-Ibuild/src.aix-6.1-2.7/numpy/core/src/private -Inumpy/core/include -Ibuild/src.aix-6.1-2.7/numpy/core/include/numpy -Inumpy/core/src/private -Inumpy/core/src -Inumpy/core -Inumpy/core/src/npymath -Inumpy/core/src/multiarray -Inumpy/core/src/umath -Inumpy/core/src/npysort -Inumpy/core/include -I/profit/freeware/python/aix/python2.7.6/include/python2.7 -Ibuild/src.aix-6.1-2.7/numpy/core/src/private -Ibuild/src.aix-6.1-2.7/numpy/core/src/private -Ibuild/src.aix-6.1-2.7/numpy/core/src/private -Ibuild/src.aix-6.1-2.7/numpy/core/src/private -c'
xlc_r: build/src.aix-6.1-2.7/numpy/core/src/npysort/heapsort.c
"/usr/include/stdio.h", line 528.12: 1506-343 (S) Redeclaration of fgetpos64 differs from previous declaration on line 323 of "/usr/include/stdio.h".
"/usr/include/stdio.h", line 528.12: 1506-377 (I) The type "long long*" of parameter 2 differs from the previous type "long* restrict".
"/usr/include/stdio.h", line 531.12: 1506-343 (S) Redeclaration of fseeko64 differs from previous declaration on line 471 of "/usr/include/stdio.h".
"/

The problem is that on AIX as well as other platforms, Python.h contains system level defines that are used in standard libraries.  This particular problem is in stdio.h.
On AIX, Python is built with -DLARGE_FILES and this define is in Python.h(actually pyconfig.h included in Python.h.)  Basically, since Python.h has these system level defines, Python.h should be included before any other include so that the defines are seen first before any other includes are processed.  If you look at all of the Python source code, you will see that this is the case.  In fact, most of the numpy source also does this and it probably is a know fact that it should be done.  However, the following numpy source files do not include Python.h first or in some cases at all.
numpy/core/src/multiarray/methods.c
numpy/core/src/umath/test_rational.c.src
numpy/core/src/umath/operand_flag_test.c.src

The following don't have include Python.h at all and need to have for them to compile:
numpy/core/src/npysort/heapsort.c.src
numpy/core/src/npysort/quicksort.c.src
numpy/core/src/npysort/mergesort.c.src

Once I moved the #include Python.h to be the first include or added it if not there, numpy compiled.

body:
I get frequent segmentation faults when converting arrays of empty strings to objects, because the STRING_getitem function reads one byte too far before the front of the allocated memory on empty strings.

This happens in the context of reading database tables containing null values for char columns (using IOpro) and converting the results to a pandas DataFrame.

I'm using numpy 1.8.1 on Mac 10.9.3.
```
Thread 0 Crashed:: Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread
0   multiarray.so                   0x000000010482be80 STRING_to_OBJECT + 112
1   multiarray.so                   0x000000010482d0e6 raw_array_assign_array + 518
2   multiarray.so                   0x000000010482da16 PyArray_AssignArray + 838
3   multiarray.so                   0x000000010483bd20 PyArray_FromArray + 368
4   multiarray.so                   0x000000010483ea7b PyArray_FromAny + 203
5   multiarray.so                   0x000000010483f3f4 PyArray_CheckFromAny + 116
6   multiarray.so                   0x00000001048b86cd _array_fromobject + 653
7   libpython2.7.dylib              0x00000001000c927f PyEval_EvalFrameEx + 25135
```

title: Vonmises problem for kappa slightly bigger than threshold 1e-8
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/can-cs', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7195403?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'can-cs', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7195403, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/can-cs/followers'}
body:
When sampling using vonmises I get stuck for kappa slightly bigger than 1e-8, no returned value and I need to kill the process. Code snippet that shows the problem

import numpy as np
np.random.vonmises(0., 1.1e-8) 

From what I can see the threshold for (I guess?) truncating to a uniform dist over -pi, pi is 1e-8.

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/random/mtrand/distributions.c

I think an efficient solution would be to instead implement an efficient uniform rejection sampler for small kappa. That our first sample on -pi,pi would be rejected is very unlikely.

body:
This makes the scalar richcmp behave exactly as
"array(self) <op> other". The difference comes in when "other" is an ndarray
subclass, in which case this change allows the subclass to override the
comparison operations via usual Python binop dispatch rules.

Fixes gh-4709

title: Difference in behavior between python and numpy array add/subtract assignment operator
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/slee0', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1873814?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'slee0', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1873814, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/slee0/followers'}
body:
**Summary:** There is a difference in how the add/subtract assignment operators work between normal Python ints and int64s in Numpy arrays that leads to potentially unexpected and inconsistent results.

**Problem:** Consider the following code, in which a normal Python int is typecast to a float in a new variable:
```
>>> x = 1
>>> type(x)
<type 'int'>
>>> y = x + 0.5
>>> print y
1.5
>>> type(y)
<type 'float'>
```

As expected, the type of y has now been cast to float, due to the addition of a float to an int.

Now, using an assignment operator on an int gives a similar result: it typecasts x as a float. I assume it needs to create new memory to cope, but it's now a float to the user. 
```
>>> x = 1
>>> type(x)
<type 'int'>
>>> x += 0.5
>>> print x
1.5
>>> type(x)
<type 'float'>
```

Now consider the following operation using a numpy array, in which assignment of a new variable (y) results in typecasting the int64 to a float64, yielding the expected result.
```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> x = np.array([1])
>>> x.dtype
dtype('int64')
>>> y = x + 0.5
>>> y
array([1.5])
>>> y.dtype
dtype('float64')
```

A user may reasonably be expected to perform the add assignment operation using a numpy array with the exact same results as the parallel operation on a standard int and as shown immediately above in the numpy array, when not using an assignment operator. The following example illustrates the issue:
```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> x = np.array([1])
>>> x.dtype
dtype('int64')
>>> x += 0.5
```

**Expected result:** A user may reasonably expect the result of this operation to be equivalent to assignment to a new variable, since this behavior is paralleled in normal Python ints. One would expect the following as a continuation from above:
```
>>> x
array([1.5])
>>> x.dtype
dtype('float64')
```

**Actual result:** Instead of new memory being created to allocate the new dtype, numpy does this instead:
```
>>> x
array([1])
>>> x.dtype
dtype('int64')
```

**Workarounds:** Obviously, the workaround is to typecast the original numpy array in the type consistent with the types with which it is expected to work (in this case, float64):
```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> x = np.array([1.])
>>> x
array([1.])
>>> x.dtype
dtype('float64')
>>> x += 0.5
>>> x
array([1.5])
>>> x.dtype
dtype('float64')
```

**Comments:** This is normally not a problem when you have overt control over the output type. But this issue was encountered in the following context, in which the user would have to explicitly re-type the resultant vector as floats instead of ints or avoid confusingly using assignment operators in this case but NOT a similar non-Numpy Python case:
```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> x = np.random.poisson(1, 10)
>>> x.dtype
dtype('int64')
```

It turns out that this issue affects add assignment and subtract assignment operators but not multiply (shown below) and divide assignment operators, for which it is happy to typecast the existing numpy array as a float:
```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> x = np.array([1])
>>> x.dtype
dtype('int64')
>>> y = x * 0.5
>>> y
array([0.5])
>>> y.dtype
dtype('float64')
>>> x *= 0.5
>>> x
array([0.5])
>>> x.dtype
dtype('float64')
```

**System:** Python 2.7.6 from MacPorts on Mac OS X 10.9.2.

title: np.asscalar should pass through scalars
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mforbes', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1028433?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mforbes', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1028433, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/followers'}
body:
**Suggestion**
It would be very convenient if ``np.asscalar()`` would pass through scalars.  The use-case is to ensure that an argument is a scalar, regardless what is passed in (as long as it behaves as a scalar).

```python
>>> np.asarray(1.0)
1.0
>>> np.asarray(1j)
1j
```

Presently these fail as the implementation simply looks for the ``.item()`` method, which scalars do not possess:
```python
>>> np.asarray(1.0)
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-13-c6bc08be135e> in <module>()
----> 1 np.asscalar(1.0)

.../python2.7/site-packages/numpy/lib/type_check.pyc in asscalar(a)
    461 
    462     """
--> 463     return a.item()
    464 
    465 #-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

AttributeError: 'float' object has no attribute 'item'```
```

**Rational**
It is common to use ``np.asarray()`` to ensure that the argument is an array (in the case that it might be a list etc.).  In an analogous use case, it would be useful to be able to use ``np.asscalar()`` to ensure that an argument is a scalar (as long as it can be converted to a scalar).

**Workaround**
Convert the argument to an array first.
```python
np.asscalar(np.asarray(x))
```

**Resolution**
Perhaps code like the following would work:
```python
def asscalar(a):
    try:
        return a.item()
    except AttributeError, e:
        return np.asarray(a).item()
```

body:
The masked array count method was fixed to use np.intp when doing sums.
The return type is always np.intp except for count(arr, axis=None) when
arr has no mask, in which case the return type is that of ndarray.size.

The test errors were noted in #4698.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ifriad', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7543722?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ifriad', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7543722, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ifriad/followers'}
body:
I am not quite sure if this is a bug or not. I did the following integral using numpy.quad quad(lambda h:
np.exp(-.5*2334.0090702455204-1936.9610182100055*5*log10(h)-(12.5*2132.5498892927189)*log10(h)*log10(h)),0,inf)

and I got the following answer (1.8368139214123403e-126, 3.3631976081491865e-126).

I tried the integral with maple and mathematica and I got the following: 2.643019766*10^(-127)


Could you please check if this is a bug or a problem some where else.

Cheers Ihab

title: BUG: fix crash when sending interrupt signal to fft functions
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
the SIGINT handling code must be in the GIL released section so the
longjmp does not skip the retaking.
This implies that the signal handlers must use thread local storage to
avoid a crash when sending interrupt to threaded fft functions.
Distribution of SIGINT to each threads must be handled by the
application as only the master thread receives it
Closes gh-4634

title: Importing scipy.ndimage raises RuntimeError on Python 3
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/matze', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/115270?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'matze', 'type': u'User', 'id': 115270, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/matze/followers'}
body:
I noticed problems with [builds](https://travis-ci.org/ufo-kit/concert/jobs/24726108) on Python 3. Whenever, `scipy.ndimage` is imported, NumPy raises a `RuntimeError`. The problem is related to [these](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/_import_tools.py#L114-L117) lines, in which you modify the dictionary while iterating over it. The Python [docs](https://docs.python.org/2/library/stdtypes.html#dict.iterkeys) are pretty clear, that this causes undefined behaviour.

Why this only happens on Python 3 and with this particular package, I have no idea.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/wa03', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/725688?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'wa03', 'type': u'User', 'id': 725688, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/wa03/followers'}
body:
Proposed fix for issue 2012:
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/2012

Also relevant is the discussion on scipy-user:
http://mail.scipy.org/pipermail/scipy-user/2012-October/033299.html

The else block should not be conditional (i.e., remove the else, {, }, and properly indent).
Also the counting variables need a +1.

title: Extrange behaviour with numpy boolean values

body:
```python
ipdb> np.isnan(table_ids) == True
True
ipdb> np.isnan(table_ids) is True
False

ipdb> np.True_ == True
True
