```python
False
```
Obviously, question is why can't be used "is True" statement into comparison ?

title: DEPR: why are bool comparison on object arrays deprecated now in 1.9?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jreback', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/953992?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jreback', 'type': u'User', 'id': 953992, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/followers'}
body:
depr warning just started showing up (we test against numpy master in pandas master)

this seems like a reasonable comparison

In fact I don't check ``is`` here on purpose as I only want an element-wise comparison
(and pandas handles the nan issue separately)

```
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: np.__version__
Out[2]: '1.9.0.dev-02008f7'

In [3]: left = np.array(['R1', 'R2', nan, 'R4'], dtype=object)

In [4]: right = np.array(['R1', 'R2', nan, 'R4'], dtype=object)

In [5]: left == right
/usr/local/bin/ipython:1: FutureWarning: numpy equal will not check object identity in the future. The comparison did not return the same result as suggested by the identity (`is`)) and will change.
  #!/usr/local/bin/python
Out[5]: array([ True,  True,  True,  True], dtype=bool)
```

or should I be masking the ``np.nan`` first?

e.g. we are ultimately doing this:

```
    # NaNs occur only in object arrays, float or complex arrays.
    if issubclass(left.dtype.type, np.object_):
        return ((left == right) | (pd.isnull(left) & pd.isnull(right))).all()
```

title: BUG: argwhere is not equivalent to transpose(nonzero(...)))
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/perimosocordiae', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/82855?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'perimosocordiae', 'type': u'User', 'id': 82855, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/perimosocordiae/followers'}
body:
This is the cause of https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/3621.

`np.nonzero` already takes care of non-ndarray inputs, and it tends to do a better job of it. This change simply gets rid of unnecessary code.

title: poor performance of multidimensional masked median
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
due to the use of apply_over_axis masked median operations gets incredibly slow when computing them along a small dimension of a large array:

```
In [3]: d = np.random.uniform(size=(200, 200, 50))
In [4]: %timeit np.median(d,axis=2)
10 loops, best of 3: 40.1 ms per loop
In [5]: %timeit np.nanmedian(d,axis=2)
1 loops, best of 3: 1.32 s per loop
In [6]: %timeit np.ma.median(d,axis=2)
1 loops, best of 3: 4.89 s per loop
```

a way out is using bottlenecks nanmedian which is on par with our non-masked performance (and better for the slow axis) but I think we should think of ways to improve this in numpy.

I can think of following improvements for median:

* implement apply_over_axis in C, should be relatively easy but will only give us ~50% boost at best. it should still be worthwhile as there are likely more users of that function out there.

* extend partition to broadcast the index, then one could compute the right index from the mask and do everything in one partition call. Probably worthwhile but it will make the partition interface more complicated and would probably imply rewritting our pretty ugly sorting code.

* probably the simplest would be add a check on the size of the axis and use sort instead of partition as currently done in ma.median but then instead of selecting via apply_along_axis, one selects the elements to average (or not) via fancy indexing (always select the middle two and if the non-masked count is odd duplicate one of the elements so mean() does nothing)

* add a MaskedPartition C-Api function

* see if we can integrate bottleneck directly somehow

any more options I'm might be overlooking?

title: Change RELAXED_STRIDES to not intentionally mangle them up
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
Currently when RELAXED_STRIDES is active, new arrays which have a dimension with size 1 get a stride of `NPY_MAX_INTP` set to help debugging (since this will almost certainly trigger such bugs for any input array with such a shape, and not juts when one happens to have an input array with funny strides).

In release versions we should probably *not* do this. So for 1.10 I would suggest creating a RELAXED_STRIDES=2 setting where we actually still scramble up the stride, but as default with RELAXED_STRIDES=1 don't in the release. This requires `ctors.h` around line 3718 (`/* For testing purpose only */`) to be changed.

title: BUG: numpy tile does not copy
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/briancheung', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1216594?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'briancheung', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1216594, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/briancheung/followers'}
body:
For single repetitions, tile returns the same reference. More intuitive behavior would be to return a copy regardless of number of repetitions.
```python
In [1]: import numpy as np
In [2]: x = np.arange(5)
In [3]: y = np.tile(x,(1,1))
In [4]: y
Out[4]: array([[0, 1, 2, 3, 4]])
In [5]: y+=3
In [6]: y
Out[6]: array([[3, 4, 5, 6, 7]])
In [7]: x
Out[7]: array([3, 4, 5, 6, 7])
```

body:
Revert "ENH: ma.asarray() and ma.asanyarray() will pass through input
        of the correct type."

This reverts commit d8fd28389adb491e24b7cdc25cd1b20f539310c3.

That commit caused test errors in scipy, which was apparently
expecting a copy rather than a passed through array. The idea
may be good, but at a minimum it should probably be preceded
by a deprecation period.

Closes #4675.

title: BUG: reject too large seeds to RandomState
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
mtrand accepts seeds larger than 32 bit but silently truncates them back
to 32 bit. This can lead to accidentally getting the same random stream
for two different seeds, e.g. 1 and 1 + 2**40.

title: numpy.random.RandomState cannot handle integers > 20 digits
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jbwhit', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/105829?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jbwhit', 'type': u'User', 'id': 105829, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jbwhit/followers'}
body:
I think I've stumbled upon a either a coding or documentation bug.

    from numpy.random import RandomState
    testing_state = RandomState(1234567891011121314)

Works without problems. However adding one more digit breaks with the following error: 

    testing_state = RandomState(12345678910111213141)
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
    <ipython-input-2-346870f94b6d> in <module>()
    ----> 1 testing_state = RandomState(12345678910111213141)
    
    /Library/Frameworks/EPD64.framework/Versions/7.3/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/random/mtrand.so in mtrand.RandomState.__init__ (numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.c:5217)()

    /Library/Frameworks/EPD64.framework/Versions/7.3/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/random/mtrand.so in mtrand.RandomState.seed (numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.c:5468)()

    ValueError: object of too small depth for desired array

From the docs (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.random.RandomState.html): 

    seed : {None, int, array_like}, optional
    Random seed initializing the pseudo-random number generator. Can be an integer, an array (or other sequence) of integers of any length, or None (the default).

numpy.__version__ '1.8.0'

I think this is probably one where either the "any length" in the docs should be changed to say < 20 (probably simplest) -- or RandomState to actually take any sequence of integers.

body:
This private variable has disappeared in later versions of setuptools.
In older versions of setuptools it is the same as
distutils.command.install.install, so use that instead.

Closes #4664.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20build', 'color': u'e11d21', 'name': u'component: build'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20high', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: high'}]
body:
I suspect there has been a change in the configuration of some of the build machines, but maybe something else is broken. The end of the traceback is:
```
File "/tmp/pip-0jmng0-build/numpy/distutils/command/install.py", line 33, in setuptools_run

return old_install_mod._install.run(self)

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '_install'
```
Where `old_install_mod` is python's `distutils.command.install`.

title: array creation from ctypes.c_double fails
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
```
In [3]: numpy.array([(ctypes.c_double*3)(), (ctypes.c_double*3)(), (ctypes.c_double*3)()])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-19a5914106c5> in <module>()
----> 1 numpy.array([(ctypes.c_double*3)(), (ctypes.c_double*3)(), (ctypes.c_double*3)()])

TypeError: object of type 'float' has no len()
```

this works but gives you a object array which is probably not what one wants

    numpy.array([[3,3,3], (ctypes.c_double*3)(), (ctypes.c_double*3)()])

both examples worked in 1.6 but not in newer numpy, but also in 1.6 you got object arrays

title: Bug in behavior of np.random.negative_binomial
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/tjlane', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2085719?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'tjlane', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2085719, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tjlane/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Documentation', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Documentation'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.random', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.random'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}]
body:
Hi,
I haven't delved into the code, but I think the random number generation in `np.random.negative_binomial` is screwed. A simple test shows that, e.g. the numerical mean is not the same as what is analytically expected even for large empirical samples:

```
In [1]: from numpy import random
In [2]: n = 10
In [3]: p = 0.25
In [4]: print random.negative_binomial(n, p, 10000).mean()
30.1287
In [5]: print n*p / (1-p)
3.33333333333
```

The last two numbers should be the same :).

See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_binomial_distribution, cited in the doc string of `random.negative_binomial`.

title: Fix for #4655: Make fftpack._raw_fft threadsafe
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/foogod', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3247763?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'foogod', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3247763, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/followers'}
body: This patch replaces the naive dictionary-cache implementation in _raw_fft with an equivalent cache that will perform correctly in a multithreaded context.

title: numpy.fft.fft / rfft / etc routines are not threadsafe
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/foogod', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3247763?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'foogod', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3247763, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/foogod/followers'}
body:
It appears that numpy.fft.fftpack._raw_fft is doing internal caching in a non-threadsafe manner, causing data corruption if FFTs are done on similarly-sized arrays from multiple threads at the same time.

The following sample code can be used to reproduce the issue:

```
import numpy
import threading

mat = numpy.random.random((1000,1000))
result = numpy.fft.fft(mat)

def do_test():
    global mat, result
    r = numpy.fft.fft(mat)
    if not (r == result).all():
        print "FAILED: %s produced wrong result." % (threading.current_thread().name,)

for i in xrange(16):
    threading.Thread(target=do_test).start()
```

title: Memory leaks with np.random.shuffle
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/alimuldal', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2284074?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'alimuldal', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2284074, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alimuldal/followers'}
body:
Hi everyone,

I've found a nasty memory leak while using `np.random.shuffle`:

    import numpy as np

    @profile
    def shuffle_leaktest():
        x = np.random.randn(1000, 1000)
        for ii in xrange(1000):
            np.random.shuffle(x)
        del x

    if __name__ == '__main__':
        print "numpy version: " + np.__version__
        shuffle_leaktest()

`$ python -m memory_profiler shuffle_leaktest.py`

    numpy version: 1.9.0.dev-fae89b0
    Filename: shuffle_leaktest.py

    Line #    Mem usage    Increment   Line Contents
    ================================================
         3  110.535 MiB    0.000 MiB   @profile
         4                             def shuffle_leaktest():
         5  118.195 MiB    7.660 MiB       x = np.random.randn(1000, 1000)
         6  337.770 MiB  219.574 MiB       for ii in xrange(1000):
         7  337.770 MiB    0.000 MiB           np.random.shuffle(x)
         8  337.770 MiB    0.000 MiB       del x

Using `git bisect` I've tracked down the first instance of memory leakage to commit 607863d7387e80dab4b064856b598a8c86e9bee4.

No leak:

     numpy version: 1.9.0.dev-c7a30d5
     Filename: shuffle_leaktest.py

     Line #    Mem usage    Increment   Line Contents
     ================================================
          3  103.633 MiB    0.000 MiB   @profile
          4                             def shuffle_leaktest():
          5  111.285 MiB    7.652 MiB       x = np.random.randn(1000, 1000)

title: Memory leak in combination with Theano
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ogh', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1223350?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ogh', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1223350, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ogh/followers'}
body:
Hi everyone,

I found a memory leak writing code using the [theano](http://deeplearning.net/software/theano/) module and I was able to trace it back to numpy.

[I already posted on the theano mailing list about it](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/theano-dev/3gI_S9ns9oE)

Sample code to reproduce the leak:

Required modules:
  - Numpy ([commit](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/commit/0c9f285f38ea4d143c5e79badd0d36cb808242a6): `0c9f285f38ea4d143c5e79badd0d36cb808242a6`)
  - Scipy ([commit](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/commit/d9a8c214c4cea75f7d240957a646b562cf081f8b): `d9a8c214c4cea75f7d240957a646b562cf081f8b`)
  - Theano ([commit](https://github.com/Theano/Theano/commit/26d913091e56b3e80e7c562175b856a90dd782e4): `26d913091e56b3e80e7c562175b856a90dd782e4`)
  - for "@profile" decorator: memory_profiler and psutils
  - I also use OpenBlas

```ruby
import theano
from theano import tensor as T
import numpy as np

k = T.iscalar("k")
A = T.vector("A")

# Symbolic description of the result
result, updates = theano.scan(fn=lambda prior_result, A: prior_result * A,
                              outputs_info=T.ones_like(A),
                              non_sequences=A,
                              n_steps=k)

print "Compiling function"
power = theano.function(inputs=[A,k], outputs=result, updates=updates)
print "Compiling function - done"

ip = np.arange(10000)
x = None
print "Starting loop"
@profile
def test():
    for i in xrange(10000):
        x = power(ip,6)
test()
print "Done."
```

For more logs:
https://gist.github.com/ogh/b6694c8eb7793b454dee


With the same configuration except for numpy switched out with a version from last September everything works fine without any leak.
(tried the November version since I was using it on a server where I did not have the memory leak)

The version of numpy that works without a leak: [commit](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/tree/135443768a24ab4fbfd4fa5c8fc40f27d2e25c96)`135443768a24ab4fbfd4fa5c8fc40f27d2e25c96`

Can you give me any advice on how to narrow down the problem further?

title: Fix np.genfromtxt field name handling when dtype != None
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/alanbriolat', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/12193?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'alanbriolat', 'type': u'User', 'id': 12193, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/alanbriolat/followers'}
body:
``np.genfromtxt`` validates field names twice: once in ``genfromtxt`` and once in ``easy_dtype``.  Whilst the arguments to ``genfromtxt`` are used in the first validation, they aren't passed to ``easy_dtype`` (which is used only when ``dtype != None``) and therefore in this case the default validation (strip non-alphanum, replace spaces) gets confusingly applied, ignoring ``genfromtxt``'s arguments.

This patch adds failing tests for the issue and fixes ``genfromtxt`` by passing the appropriate arguments onwards to ``easy_dtype``.

This is probably the least invasive way to fix the issue.  In my opinion, the whole thing is a nest of poorly-defined responsibilities between ``genfromtxt``, ``easy_dtype`` and ``NameValidator``, especially since the latter two are only used in the former.  I'm willing to take the time to try and clean that up if it's likely to be well-received.

body:
Set the `NPY_NEEDS_PYAPI` flag for types with fields, as these need
access to the Python API to manipulate the tuples and dicts holding
field information. It remains unset for the base `np.void` type.

title: Segfault when using numpy.searchsorted with recarrays in multithreaded environment
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/quantax-github', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5172213?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'quantax-github', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5172213, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/quantax-github/followers'}
body:
recarrays have a dtype.flags of 0 which allows numpy to release the GIL when using the NPY_BEGIN_THREADS_DESCR macro.
We suspect that PyArray_SearchSorted in item_selection.c uses VOID_compare for comparison of recarray elements which requires Python API functions.

Python code to reproduce under Windows 7 x64 using Python 2.7.5 x64 and Numpy 1.8.1 (or 1.7.1)

```python
import numpy
import threading

def index(a,b,notfound=-1):
	""" find index of b in a """
	index = numpy.argsort(a)
	sorted_a = a[index]
	sorted_index = numpy.searchsorted(sorted_a,b)

	bindex = numpy.take(index,sorted_index,mode="clip")
	bindex[a[bindex] != b] = notfound

	return bindex

def index2dim(a,b,notfound=-1):
	""" like .index, but for n-dim arrays a and b along axis 0 """
	a = a.view([('',a.dtype)] * a.shape[1]).ravel()
	b = b.view([('',b.dtype)] * b.shape[1]).ravel()
	print str(threading.currentThread().ident),type(a),type(b),a.dtype,b.dtype,repr(a),repr(b)
	x = index(a,b,notfound=notfound)
	return x

def thread(a,b):
	while True:
		index2dim(a,b)

a = numpy.arange(200)
b = numpy.arange(10)

a = a.reshape((100,2))
b = b.reshape((5,2))

for i in xrange(10):
	t = threading.Thread(target=thread,args=(a,b))
	t.start()
```

Thanks and best regards
Martin Gfeller (martin.gfeller@swisscom.com) and Fabio Scala (fabio.scala@swisscom.com)

title: DOC: standardize "size" arg description in random module docstrings
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/gdementen', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/832092?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'gdementen', 'type': u'User', 'id': 832092, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gdementen/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Documentation', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Documentation'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.random', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.random'}]
body:
There were many different versions for no good reason.

I tried to combine the useful bits in all common docstrings and came up with this:

    size : int or tuple of ints, optional
        Output shape.  If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
        ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn.  Default is None, in which case a
        single value is returned.

However, at the end, I found the docstring for zipf, which adds the following precision:

    ... a single integer is equivalent in
    its result to providing a mono-tuple, i.e., a 1-D array of length
    *size* is returned.

So, I should probably include that sentence in all docstrings too. Thoughts?

PS: the module would really benefit from more docstring standardisation:
* descriptions for (other) arguments of many functions do not include the default value
* "optional" in arg description is missing in a lot of places
* returns should also be standardized
* possibly raises too

I will probably do this one day, but it might take a while...

title: BUG: overflow on integer ops on 32-bit
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jreback', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/953992?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jreback', 'type': u'User', 'id': 953992, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jreback/followers'}
body:
numpy 1.8.1

32-bit linux
```
(Pdb) np.arange(5249571,dtype='int64').sum()
13778995217235
(Pdb) np.arange(5249571,dtype='int32').sum()
740131667
(Pdb) np.arange(5249571,dtype='int32').mean()
2624785.0
(Pdb) np.arange(5249571,dtype='int64').mean()
2624785.0
```

64-bit linux
```
In [2]: np.arange(5249571,dtype='int64').sum()
Out[2]: 13778995217235

In [3]: np.arange(5249571,dtype='int32').sum()
Out[3]: 13778995217235

In [4]: np.arange(5249571,dtype='int32').mean()
Out[4]: 2624785.0

In [5]: np.arange(5249571,dtype='int64').mean()
Out[5]: 2624785.0
```

So it seems that when the ``int32`` overflows it should then upcast to ``int64`` if needed; interesting that this works on 64-bit.

related issue: https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/6915

title: annotate reference semantics of c-api
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
annotate multiarray c-api reference semantics, like stealing and borrowing
the functions are decorated with cpychecker attributes which allow it to perform better static analysis

no guarantee for correctness I might have missed a few functions. The nonull attribute can probably added to most of our functions but I didn't go through them all to add it, only those that happened to steal references too.
also the umath api is not annotated yet

additionally this could be extended to add reference semantic information to our (horribly outdated) c-api docs, with the sphinx reference addon (like python.org docs does)

title: Segfault when ctr+c during pathological fft
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cournape', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/25111?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cournape', 'type': u'User', 'id': 25111, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cournape/followers'}
body:
On Debian unstable, numpy 1.8.1 built from sources:

```
import numpy as np
np.fft.fft(np.random.randn(2**16+))
# ctrl+C before the fft finishes segfaults
```

2**16+1 is a size where the fft goes back to O(N^2) behaviour (prime size).

title: BUG: polynomial: UnboundLocalError: local variable 'quo' referenced before assignment
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/WarrenWeckesser', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/321463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'WarrenWeckesser', 'type': u'User', 'id': 321463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/followers'}
body:
An error was reported on stackoverflow (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23186008/numpy-namespace-issue).  My answer, repeated here, describes the problem.

In the implementation of `__rtruediv__` at https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/polynomial/_polybase.py#L421, you can see that if `len(self.coef)` is not 1, the statement

        return self.__class__(quo, self.domain, self.window)

is executed, but `quo` is not defined.

Here's a simple example that generates the error:

    In [1]: import numpy.polynomial.polynomial as npp

    In [2]: p1 = npp.Polynomial([1,2])

    In [3]: p2 = npp.Polynomial([3,4])

    In [4]: npp.polydiv(p1, p2)
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    UnboundLocalError                         Traceback (most recent call last)
    <ipython-input-4-00c25f56fb20> in <module>()
    ----> 1 npp.polydiv(p1, p2)

        /Users/warren/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/polynomial/polynomial.pyc in polydiv(c1, c2)
        406     len2 = len(c2)
        407     if len2 == 1 :
    --> 408         return c1/c2[-1], c1[:1]*0
        409     elif len1 < len2 :
        410         return c1[:1]*0, c1

    /Users/warren/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/polynomial/polynomial.pyc in __rtruediv__(self, other)

    UnboundLocalError: local variable 'quo' referenced before assignment

body:
....

The "-Wl,-undefined,dynamic_lookup" flag is enough to make things work
with OS X bundles.  On the mailing list an issue was reported with
Anaconda (non-framework build) where f2py was picking up the system framework
Python instead of the Anaconda one.

Thanks to @rkern for explaining how to fix this.

title: BUG: incorrect argument order to _copyto in in np.nanmax, np.nanmin
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
In https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/2340, it was noticed that `np.nanmax` on the `ndarray` subclass `Quantity` did not work properly. This can be traced to the arguments to the `_copyto` call in `numpy.lib/nanfunctions` not being in the correct order:
```
res = _copyto(res, mask, np.nan)
```
while the call sequence to `_copyto` is
```
def _copyto(a, val, mask):
```

This PR corrects the two occurrences of this mistake. 

Obviously, it should also add test cases, and the simplest would seem to be to run all the ones in `test_nanfunctions.py` with an `ndarray` subclass. Is there an easy way to implement this?

title: ``ma.apply_along_axis`` regression
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/rgommers', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/98330?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'rgommers', 'type': u'User', 'id': 98330, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/rgommers/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.ma', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.ma'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Regression', 'color': u'7F0000', 'name': u'Regression'}]
body:
After merging gh-4463, a ``scipy.stats.mstats.trim`` is failing: https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/3554

It looks to me like the expected result for this test is correct, but the mask has one row too many of the mask set to true:

    import numpy as np
    from scipy import stats

    x = np.ma.arange(110).reshape(11, 10)
    x[1] = np.ma.masked

    trimx = stats.mstats.trim(x, (0.1,0.2), relative=True, axis=0)
    np.testing.assert_equal(trimx._mask.ravel(), [1]*20 + [0]*70 + [1]*20)

    trimx = stats.mstats.trim(x.T, (0.1,0.2), relative=True, axis=-1)
    np.testing.assert_equal(trimx.T._mask.ravel(), [1]*20 + [0]*70 + [1]*20)

title: Update ufunc override to work properly with ufunc methods.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cowlicks', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/598099?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cowlicks', 'type': u'User', 'id': 598099, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/followers'}
body:
This allows the ufunc override machinery to work properly with all the ufunc methods.

There is one failing test [here](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py#L929) which I am looking into. It passes for some python versions and not others.

The ufunc methods required some API design decisions and I'd like to hear what people think. The original ufunc override spec [called for the arguments to be parsed into `inputs` and `kwargs`](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/doc/neps/ufunc-overrides.rst#proposed-interface). But what is an input and what is a kwarg?

The methods I'm wondering about are `ufunc.outer(A, B)` and `ufunc.at(a, indices[, b])`.
For `outer` I guess both `A` and `B` should be in `inputs`? For `at` should `b` also be in `inputs`.

Also please check my reference counting, I'm not confident about it.

body: As is, `np.broadcast_arrays` does not preserve subclasses, even though for the shape manipulation subclasses should not be a problem. This PR adds a `subok` option that allows one to change that, but is `False` by default, so that existing code will continue to behave as is.

title: ENH: allow subclass overrides by removing explicit ndarray methods
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
This is a follow-on of #4586, and it removes all direct use of `ndarray` methods, changing, e.g., 
`ndarray.__iadd__(self._data, ...)` to `self._data.__iadd__(...)`. The idea again is to not presume what data is being held (though it is not as essential to making masked `Quantity` work as is #4586).

body:
The following code causes a segfault:
```python
import numpy

# dummy class where __array__ throws exception
class Foo(object):
    __array_priority__ = 1002
    def __array__(self,*args,**kwargs):
        raise Exception()

print (numpy.array(1) == Foo())
```
I'm using `Version: 1:1.8.1-1` from the debian sid repos.

This worked with older versions of numpy, and I think the culprit is https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/maintenance/1.8.x/numpy/core/src/multiarray/arrayobject.c#L1401-L1413.

title: ENH: replace GIL of random module with a per state lock
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
The random module currently relies on the GIL for the state
synchronization which hampers threading performance.
Instead add a lock to the RandomState object and take it for all
operations calling into randomkit while releasing the GIL.
This allows parallizing random number generation using multiple states
or asynchronous generation in a worker thread.

Note that with a large number of threads the standard mersenne twister
used may exhibit overlap if the number of parallel streams is large
compared to the size of the state space, though due to the limited
scalability of Python in regards to threads this is likely not a big
issue.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sashkab', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/868842?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sashkab', 'type': u'User', 'id': 868842, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sashkab/followers'}
body:
After back-porting #4191 into 1.8.1, openblas is not found on systems by default. 

Backward compatibility logic is wrong.

```diff
diff --git a/numpy/distutils/system_info.py b/numpy/distutils/system_info.py
index fbdd164..35aba17 100644
--- a/numpy/distutils/system_info.py
+++ b/numpy/distutils/system_info.py
@@ -1565,7 +1565,7 @@ class openblas_info(blas_info):
         lib_dirs = self.get_lib_dirs()

         openblas_libs = self.get_libs('libraries', self._lib_names)
-        if openblas_libs == self._lib_names: # backward compat with 1.8.0
+        if openblas_libs == []: # backward compat with 1.8.0
             openblas_libs = self.get_libs('openblas_libs', self._lib_names)
         info = self.check_libs(lib_dirs, openblas_libs, [])
         if info is None:
```

title: Critical issue when subtracting two numpy arrays
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/nroth0815', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5796787?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'nroth0815', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5796787, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nroth0815/followers'}
body:
I've discovered a rather strange but definitely critical bug when subtracting two numpy arrays with ndim>1:

Try the following example:
<code>x = np.zeros((arsize,2))
res = x[arsize/2]
res[:]=(1,2)
x-=res

Expected result: a 2D array of length arsize with entries (-1,-2) everywhere except at arsize/2, where it should be (0.,0.).

However, this fails for arsize > 4097 (in 2D), because the value of "res" is updated to (0.,0.) BEFORE the whole array is traversed, and thus nothing gets subtracted from the second half!

Result for arsize>4097: half of the array correctly has the value (-1,-2), the rest still has (0.,0.).

The same is true for 3 dimensions and arsize> 2732, so it happens when the total number of elements is > 8196. (4D: 2049, 1D seems fine for arbitrarily large numbers of arsize.)

We have been able to reproduce this with numpy versions 1.7.1 and 1.8.1 on MacOSX 10.8.5 and 10.9, as well as version 1.8.1 on Ubuntu.

title: None in a timedelta array is converted to a very small number.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/janrito', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/31504?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'janrito', 'type': u'User', 'id': 31504, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/janrito/followers'}
body:
~~~{python}
np.array([np.timedelta64(1, 's'), np.timedelta64(2, 's'), None], dtype=np.timedelta64)
~~~
results in:

~~~{python}
array([                   1,                    2, -9223372036854775808], dtype='timedelta64[s]')
~~~

rather than:

~~~{python}
array([                   1,                    2,                 NaN], dtype='timedelta64[s]')
~~~

Other dtypes work like this:

~~~{python}
np.array([1, 2, None], dtype=np.float64)
>>>array([  1.,   2.,  nan])
~~~

or throw an error:

~~~{python}
np.array([1, 2, None], dtype=np.int64)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-98-e16efa488157> in <module>()
----> 1 np.array([1, 2, None], dtype=np.int64)

TypeError: long() argument must be a string or a number, not 'NoneType'

title: trapz returns wrong values when x is out of order
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jprafael', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/876908?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jprafael', 'type': u'User', 'id': 876908, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jprafael/followers'}
body:
Internally, trapz uses np.diff() to calculate dx. This makes the assumption that the x values are increasing monotonically. This leads to wrong values when x does not have this property:

```python
x = array([0, 1, 2])
y = array([0, 2, 4])
trapz(y, x) # 4, correct value
trapz(y[::-1], x[::-1]) # -4, incorrect value

idx = random.permutation(arange(3))
x_shuffled = x[idx]
y_shuffled = y[idx]
trapz(y_shuffled, x_shuffled) # 1, incorrect value
```

This limitation of trapz should be fixed by sorting both y,x values before proceeding. I can sugest two possible courses of action: Either properly document trapz, indicating this limitation, and add a new "safe_trapz" that fixes this. Or do the exact opposite, have trapz sort the input values, and add a "fast_trapz" that doesn't.

title: ENH: Quoting support in np.genfromtxt(...)
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ddasilva', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/536378?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ddasilva', 'type': u'User', 'id': 536378, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ddasilva/followers'}
body:
Based off patch in #2211. Implements custom split method and adds new keyword argument ``quoter=`` to ``np.genfromtxt``. The quoting feature also supports escaping.

#### Example usage:
data.txt:
```
"King","Henry, VI"
"Queen","Victoria"
Sir,Isaac Newton
```
Python:
```
>>> np.genfromtxt("data.txt", quoter='"', delimiter=",", dtype="|S20")
array([[b'King', b'Henry, VI'],
       [b'Queen', b'Victoria'],
       [b'Sir', b'Isaac Newton']], 
      dtype='|S20')
```

#### Changes from original patch:
* **Python 3 compatibility**:
   old code was iterating through bytes and not expecting int
* **Bugfix**:
   old code was dropping final word in split implemention
* **Test**:
   added a unit test

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/samueljohn', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/725299?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'samueljohn', 'type': u'User', 'id': 725299, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/samueljohn/followers'}
body:
I noticed that there is an error in the test `test_callback.TestF77Callback.test_string_callback` when I have installed numpy via homebrew for python 2.x. This error shows up for brewed python and for system python.

I maintain Homebrew/python, and especially numpy/scipy, so I wanted to assure that 1.9.0 of numpy will work, once released. And now I am puzzled about that error message. Is numpy actually trying to compile something with gfortran during the tests?

Note that in homebrew we use `gfortran 4.8.2` at the moment.

The gist of the output is at https://gist.github.com/samueljohn/10008974.

title: ENH: Let MaskedArray getter, setter respect baseclass overrides
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
As is, `MaskedArray` uses explicity calls to `ndarray.__setitem__(self.data, indx, value)` and `ndarray.__getitem__(self.data, indx)` to access elements of its baseclass. This PR uses `self.data[indx]` instead, so that possible overrides of `__getitem__` and `__setitem__` are respected.

This is particularly useful for astropy's `Quantity` ndarray subclass, since it should check that anything written to it has the correct unit, and associate units for anything gotten from it.

(Note: this includes #4585, as otherwise some of the tests would fail; I'll rebase once that is in.)

title: BUG: Ensure MaskedArray.flat can access single items
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
Currently, the `MaskedArray.flat` iterator barfs when trying to access single items, because it is tried to overwrite `shape` of a non-ndarray mask (see below). This PR corrects this, and adds test cases.

```
import numpy as np
ma = np.ma.MaskedArray([1,2,3], mask=[0,1,0])
ma.flat[1]
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-d9496ad7cbf6> in <module>()
----> 1 ma.flat[1]

/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/numpy/ma/core.py in __getitem__(self, indx)
   2530         if self.maskiter is not None:
   2531             _mask = self.maskiter.__getitem__(indx)
-> 2532             _mask.shape = result.shape
   2533             result._mask = _mask
   2534         return result

AttributeError: attribute 'shape' of 'numpy.generic' objects is not writable
```

When initialising a structured masked array with `empty`, `zeros`, or `ones`, in the `numpy.ma` module, a `ValueError` is raised, as illustrated below:

```

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-19-fa42e8196770> in <module>()
----> 1 E = numpy.ma.zeros(1, [("time", "M8[s]")])

/home/gerrit/venv/python-3.4/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/ma/core.py in __call__(self, a, *args, **params)
   7221             _extras[p] = params.pop(p)
   7222         # Get the result
-> 7223         result = self._func.__call__(a, *args, **params).view(MaskedArray)
   7224         if "fill_value" in common_params:
   7225             result.fill_value = _extras.get("fill_value", None)

/home/gerrit/venv/python-3.4/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/ma/core.py in __array_finalize__(self, obj)
   2798         if self.dtype.names:
   2799             if self._fill_value is None:
-> 2800                 self._fill_value = _check_fill_value(None, self.dtype)
   2801         return
   2802 

/home/gerrit/venv/python-3.4/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/ma/core.py in _check_fill_value(fill_value, ndtype)
    400             descr = ndtype.descr
    401             fill_value = np.array(_recursive_set_default_fill_value(descr),
--> 402                                   dtype=ndtype,)
    403         else:
    404             fill_value = default_fill_value(ndtype)

ValueError: Error parsing datetime string "?" at position 0
```

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
OpenBLAS starts as many threads as it can and assigns them to cpus
This includes the main thread Python is running in.
This means any threads or processes Python starts must all share this
cpu, nullifying any parallization efforts.
Luckily this behaviour can be disabled via an environment variable which
we need to set before loading dotblas which may be linked to OpenBLAS.
Libraries loading BLAS before numpy are stills screwed.

title: Array C API Documentation for PyArray_Newshape missing parameter
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/tintedFrantic', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7143092?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'tintedFrantic', 'type': u'User', 'id': 7143092, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tintedFrantic/followers'}
body:
While writing C code to reshape an array, I call the PyArray_Newshape function, passing arguments of the types listed in the Array API documentation (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.8.0/reference/c-api.array.html).

During compile, I get the following error:
"error: too few arguments to function"

After digging around in the source code, I found that instead of the function signature listed in the documentation,

PyObject* PyArray_Newshape(PyArrayObject* self, PyArray_Dims* newshape)

the source code specifies the following interface:

PyObject* PyArray_Newshape(PyArrayObject* self, PyArray_Dims* newshape,NPY_ORDER order)

with NPY_ORDER explained at (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.6.0/reference/c-api.array.html#NPY_ORDER)

Once I updated my code to include an appropriate enum value for NPY_ORDER, the program compiled just fine.  I propose that the documentation be updated to include this third parameter.

title: ENH: Ensure that repr and str work for MaskedArray non-ndarray bases
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mhvk', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2789820?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mhvk', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2789820, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mhvk/followers'}
body:
(@charris: this is one of the corrections I mentioned in #3907 that we need to make to MaskedArray to get astropy's more complicated ndarray subclasses to be used as base classes.)

Currently, `repr(ma)` and `str(ma)` do not deal well with base classes that redefine `__repr__` to use a different way to print the class name, or that override `__setitem__` to do checks on values, respectively. This PR corrects this, by simply letting `__repr__` use `__class__.__name__` instead of trying to be smart in how to get it, and by ensuring that `__str__` inserts `masked_print_option` in an `ndarray` view of the object array that is created for string output (the current way `__str__` is handled is perhaps too clever a trick, but I'm not quite sure yet how to make it safer; my PR should at least help a little.). 

Specifically, currently, after defining:
```
import numpy as np

class ComplicatedSubArray(np.ndarray):
    def __new__(cls, arr):
        return np.asanyarray(arr).view(cls)

    def __str__(self):
        return 'myprefix {0} mypostfix'.format(
            super(ComplicatedSubArray, self).__str__())

    def __repr__(self):
        # Return a repr that does not start with 'name('
        return '<{0} {1}>'.format(self.__class__.__name__, self)

    def __setitem__(self, item, value):
        # this ensures direct assignment to masked_print_option will fail
        if not isinstance(value, ComplicatedSubArray):
            raise ValueError("Can only set to MySubArray values")
        super(ComplicatedSubArray, self).__setitem__(item, value)

xcsub = ComplicatedSubArray(np.arange(5))
mxcsub1 = np.ma.masked_array(xcsub)
mxcsub2 = np.ma.masked_array(xcsub, mask=[True, False, True, False, False])
```
one gets
```
In [15]: mxcsub1
Out[15]: 
masked_<ComplicatedSubArray myprefix [0 1 2 3 4] mypostfix>(data = myprefix [0 1 2 3 4] mypostfix,
                                                            mask = False,
                                                      fill_value = 999999)
In [16]: mxcsub2
Out[16]: 
.
.
.
ValueError: Can only set to MySubArray values
```

With the PR,
```
In [2]: mxcsub1
Out[2]: 
masked_ComplicatedSubArray(data = myprefix [0 1 2 3 4] mypostfix,
                           mask = False,
                     fill_value = 999999)
In [3]: mxcsub2
Out[3]: 
masked_ComplicatedSubArray(data = myprefix [-- 1 -- 3 4] mypostfix,
                           mask = [ True False  True False False],
                     fill_value = 999999)
```

title: numpy.fromstring unable to parse values > 2^32 on 32 bit arch
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jpwhite4', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5342179?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jpwhite4', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5342179, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jpwhite4/followers'}
body:
Steps to reproduce:
run the following command on a 32 bit x86 python:
```python
numpy.fromstring( "25041670086757 104783749223640", dtype=numpy.uint64, sep=' ')
```
and the incorrect output is:
```python
array([4294967295, 4294967295], dtype=uint64)
```
If the same command is executed on a 64 bit machine, the output appears correct:
```python
array([ 25041670086757, 104783749223640], dtype=uint64)
```
Versions tested:
numpy 1.8.1 
Python 2.7.3 (default, Feb 27 2014, 20:00:17)  [GCC 4.6.3] on linux2

title: ENH: optimize array creation from homogenous python sequences
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
Instead calling PyArray_DTypeFromObjectHelper for each item in a
sequence, check if all items in the sequence are of the same scalar
type, if this is the case we only need to recurse on one item.
Also use the PySequence_Fast API to avoid expensive function calls for
the common case of lists or tuples.

np.array(range(10)) improves about 25%
np.array(range(100)) improves about 40%

title: BUG: raise error for erroneous structured array assignment
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mbyt', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1878241?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mbyt', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1878241, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mbyt/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.core', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.core'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Maintenance', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Maintenance'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Needs%20decision', 'color': u'0b02e1', 'name': u'Needs decision'}]
body:
This pull request shows one possible way how to resolve #3126 and #3561: It just raises an error for non supported / erroneous operations.

```python
import numpy as np
print np.__version__

x = np.empty(1, dtype=[('field', 'i4', 10)])
ones = np.ones(10, dtype='i4')

# OK
x[:]['field'] = 1 * ones     # array_assign_subscript
print x
x['field'] = 2 * ones        # array_assign_subscript
print x
x[0]['field'][:] = 3 * ones  # array_assign_slice
print x

# FAIL (only first item is assigned)
x[0]['field'] = 4 * ones     # voidtype_ass_subscript 
print x
```

However, it might be much nicer to actually assign the call correctly (I did not manage to do this, therefore I just raise an error). The above code lines show 4 operations how to assign the same field with their C function call as comment. Note that only the call to `voidtype_ass_subscript` fails.

`python -c "import numpy; numpy.test()" ` run OK.

title: error range dtype
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/toddrjen', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2272878?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'toddrjen', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2272878, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/followers'}
body:
It is nearly universal in scientific data to have data with error ranges.  However, there is currently no easy way to deal with data with error ranges in python.  You generally need to either keep a second array or carry a lot of extra values around.  There is also no established way to do mathematics on data with error ranges.

I think it would be useful if python provided dtypes for dealing with data with error ranges.  It would probably be something like the complex dtype, which could be thought of as holding two floating point values per element.  There would probably be two dtypes, one which holds two floating-point values per element (for cases where the error above and below is the same), and a second which holds three floating-point values per element (for cases where the error above and below is different).
