title: Protect the wsave array in fftpack_lite against concurrent access
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sturlamolden', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1970862?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sturlamolden', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1970862, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sturlamolden/followers'}
body:
fftpacklite_module.c releases the GIL. The ```wsave``` array must therefore be protected against concurrent access. Only a minor change to fftpack.py is required. Basically line 56 must be 

```python
# try to grab a wsave array and protect it from concurrent access
# dict.pop is atomic in the Python interpreter
wsave = fftcache.pop(n)
```

instead of 

```wsave = fftcache[n]```

And finally we need to put it back before returning from ```_raw_fft```

```fftcache[n] = wsave```

Unless we make this change, two Python threads calling numpy.fft.* functions concurrently can accidentally use the same work array. 

The comment lines should be included so it's clear why a pop instead of an indexing is required.

title: BUG: #2408, Fix f2py Python 3 error message string bug.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The original was generating an exception message and, after aliasing,
calling PyBytes_AsString on a unicode string -> error. It was also
leaking references, although that probably didn't matter in context.

The fix here is on the cheap side, just use a C string for the message
without including the extra information about the erroneous type that
led to the exception.

No test, I don't know how to evoke this error.

Closes #2408.

    nose version 1.3.0
    test_drop_fields (test_recfunctions.TestRecFunctions) ... ok
    test_find_duplicates (test_recfunctions.TestRecFunctions) ... Bus error

title: Function to chain multiplications / `dot` for many arrays
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sotte', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/79138?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sotte', 'type': u'User', 'id': 79138, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sotte/followers'}
body:
I wrote myself a little helper function tat I constantly use. The function chains calls of `dot` which makes long matrix multiplication much more readable. I call the function `mdot` for "multiple dot".

```python
M = np.eye(5)
# instead of this
print M.dot(M).dot(M).dot(M).dot(M)
# or this
print np.dot(np.dot(np.dot(np.dot(M, M), M), M), M)
# I can write this
print mdot(M, M, M, M, M)
```

This is the implementation:
```python
def mdot(*args):
    return reduce(np.dot, args)    
```

This is a really simple function but it helps me tremendously. Are you interested in integrating something like this?

title: fancy indexing does not release GIL
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
this harms parallization of code

example for simple boolean indexing:

```
import numpy as np
def f():
    d = np.arange(1000000.) / 2
    d[::10] = np.nan
    c2 = ~np.isnan(d)
    for needle in range(1000):
        d[c2]

import threading
t = [threading.Thread(target=f) for x in range(2)]
for x in t:
    x.start()
for x in t:
    x.join()
```

```
$ time python test.py

real	0m18.226s
user	0m10.124s
sys	0m8.058s
```

this time could be cut in half on a 2 core machine.

body:
Use PyUString_FromStringAndSize defined in npy_3kcompat instead. Not
using bytes may cause some problems, but strings seem like a better
choice. As modules generated with current f2py error out, this
particular use is not common and we are free to choose.

Closes #4256.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
A NaN interpolation point was interpreted as out of bounds on the left
side, hence the value of the left parameter in the function call was
returned.

>>> np.interp(np.nan, [-10, 10], [-2, 2])
-2.0

NaN is a better choice.

Closes #605.

hint that nelem == 1 branch is more likely

title: np.ma.array(np.matrix(0)).compressed() returns a np.matrix
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/argriffing', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/101416?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'argriffing', 'type': u'User', 'id': 101416, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/followers'}
body:
According to the [docs](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.ma.MaskedArray.compressed.html#numpy.ma.MaskedArray.compressed) it should return an ndarray, although technically a `np.matrix` is an `ndarray` in the sense of inheritance so maybe this is OK.

see https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/3324

title: LinAlgError Array must not contain infs or NaNs
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/agustinhaller', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/597833?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'agustinhaller', 'type': u'User', 'id': 597833, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/agustinhaller/followers'}
body:
I'm having some weird behavior. In my local environment the same code works as expected, and in my prod environment throws this error:

```
LinAlgError Array must not contain infs or NaNs
```

This is because a matrix in prod has nans, but the same matrix in local is correct.
So this makes me think that for some reason numpy is working differently in my prod environment.

I'm running python 2.7.6 using GCC 4.2.1 on osx in my local environment.
And i'm running python 2.7.3 using GCC 4.6.3 on ubuntu 12.04 in my prod environment.

Does anyone know which may be the difference in the numpy behavior?
Any help is appreciated!

title: Mistake in seterr docs?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/nh2', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/399535?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'nh2', 'type': u'User', 'id': 399535, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nh2/followers'}
body:
From http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.seterr.html

```python
>>> old_settings = np.seterr(all='ignore')  #seterr to known value
>>> np.seterr(over='raise')
{'over': 'ignore', 'divide': 'ignore', 'invalid': 'ignore',
 'under': 'ignore'}
>>> np.seterr(all='ignore')  # reset to default
{'over': 'raise', 'divide': 'ignore', 'invalid': 'ignore', 'under': 'ignore'}
```

Shouldn't that be `np.seterr(**old_settings)  # reset to default`?

title: Closes issue #4266, fixes histogramdd treatment of events at rightmost binedge
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/robquant', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/370867?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'robquant', 'type': u'User', 'id': 370867, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robquant/followers'}
body:
This fixes the treatment of values very close to the rightmost binedge in historgramdd. It makes sure values are greater or equal to the bin edge (if they are smaller they will already be in the correct bin), before moving them one bin left.
Fixes Github issue #4266

title: ENH: single pass over array in `bincount` to determine output size
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
`bincount` checks its input array to make sure there are no negative entries,
and to determine the size of the output array. This is done by calling two
different functions, each having to loop over the whole array. This PR
adds a new function, `minmax`, that computes the minimum and maximum of the
array in a single pass over it. This leads to speed-ups peaking at 1.5x,
with typical values for large arrays around 1.15x - 1.25x.

A full benchmark summary of the new implementation, including a supposedly
more efficient algorithm that turned out to run slower, can be found [here](https://gist.github.com/jaimefrio/8743836).

title: matrix wart
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/argriffing', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/101416?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'argriffing', 'type': u'User', 'id': 101416, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/argriffing/followers'}
body:
If the output of this product is a matrix, should it not be a column vector matrix rather than a row vector matrix?

```
>>> matrix([[1, 2], [3, 4]]).dot(array([5, 6]))
matrix([[17, 39]])
```

This seems like a bug, although I do not have extensive knowledge of the behavior of `numpy.matrix` and this has probably already been discussed extensively.

title: np.random.shuffle not work with non-default dtypes
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/fehiepsi', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4736342?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'fehiepsi', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4736342, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fehiepsi/followers'}
body:
I display the situation here:
```
arr = [(0, 1), (2, 3)]
dt = np.dtype([('a', np.int32, 1), ('b', np.int32, 1)])
nparr = np.array(arr, dtype=dt)
nparr
```
I get the expected result:
```
array([(0, 1), (2, 3)], 
      dtype=[('a', '<i4'), ('b', '<i4')])
```
After shuffle:
```
np.random.shuffle(nparr)
nparr
```
The result is
```
array([(0, 1), (0, 1)], 
      dtype=[('a', '<i4'), ('b', '<i4')])
```
Is this an issue, or `np.random.shuffle` is expected not work with other dtypes? I use `numpy 1.7.1` and `python 2.7.5`.

title: linalg.svd uses more memory than necessary
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/tantrev', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1903672?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'tantrev', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1903672, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tantrev/followers'}
body:
Hello!

I just discovered that linalg.svd is using more memory than it needs to (both Numpy and Scipy's implementations).  I haven't had a chance to look through the code but I suspect it has to do with temporarily storing a matrix in memory rather than immediately using the result in computation.

One knows this is the case because feeding a full-dense matrix to scipy.sparse.lingalg.svds does not use even a fraction of the memory used by linalg.avd!  

Anyways, I ran into the issue while working on my Macbook Pro with 16GB and I wanted to compute the SVD for some large matrices. :)

Cheers,
Trevor

title: BUG: numpy.histogramdd - wrong result  for entries very close to last boundary (standard numpy.histogram succeeds there)
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/thoglu', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6616661?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'thoglu', 'type': u'User', 'id': 6616661, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/thoglu/followers'}
body: (Numpy Version 1.8) See the following example for the precision where it happens: 1) In [68]: numpy.histogramdd([0.9999995], bins=[[0, 0.5, 1]]) Out[68]: (array([ 1., 0.]), [array([ 0. , 0.5, 1. ])]) As you can see the entry lands in the wrong bin. Lowering the value by 10^-7 suddenly makes the jump to the last bin (which is correct): 2) In [69]: numpy.histogramdd([0.9999994], bins=[[0, 0.5, 1]]) Out[69]: (array([ 0., 1.]), [array([ 0. , 0.5, 1. ])]) Interestingly, increasing the 2nd to last edge value to a high precision also helps: 3) In [88]: numpy.histogramdd([0.9999999997], bins=[[0, 0.99999, 1]]) Out[88]: (array([ 0., 1.]), [array([ 0. , 0.99999, 1. ])] Standard numpy.histogram behaves as expected to arbitrary high values close to 1: 4) In [71]: numpy.histogram(0.99999999999, bins=[0, 0.5, 1]) Out[71]: (array([0, 1]), array([ 0. , 0.5, 1. ])) The whole issue is only there for the rightmost boundary, not for intermediate ones. But as you can see in snippet 3), it has to do with the 2nd to last edge-value aswell. I hope it gets fixed soon. The precision is not that high (cosine of small angles can easily be in this regime - actually for my work it is) and a wrong bin is populated... if unnoticed wrong results are the outcome.

it gets used.

title: Detect vendor versions of GNU Compilers
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ahmadia', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/512293?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ahmadia', 'type': u'User', 'id': 512293, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/followers'}
body:
Cray and other HPC vendors provide patched versions of the GNU compilers
with modified version strings.  Use `re.search` instead of `re.match` in the
version detection scripts to account for modified version strings.

Ref: https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/4259

title: Support for Cray cross-compilers?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ahmadia', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/512293?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ahmadia', 'type': u'User', 'id': 512293, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ahmadia/followers'}
body:
The error has to do with matching the version string, and should have a simple fix, see below.

~~The Cray cross-compilers prefer to be invoked as `ftn`, `cc`, or `CC` for the corresponding Fortran, C, and C++ compilers.  The GNU compilers are included on all Cray systems, but they are accessed through the generic front-ends, not their standard name.  When the Intel, Portland Group, or PathScale compilers are made available, they are also shared through their front-ends.~~

~~I know that NumPy does not have great support for cross-compiling, but I'm wondering what some first steps toward supporting these compilers might look like.  A simple choice would be to add the corresponding executables to the list of `possible_executables` in `distutils/fcompiler/*.py`.  Another option would be to inherit the compilers and make them available as `cray_gnu`, etc.~~

~~Yet another option would be to create some sort of plugin that lives outside of the NumPy source that injects the Cray compilers in to the NumPy distutils fcompiler module.~~

~~I'm happy to submit a PR that implements the first two options (or put together the third option), but I was curious what everybody else thinks before I proceed.~~

title: ENH: add tobytes and stop using tostring in documentation
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
tostring returns bytes which are not equal to string, so provide a
tobytes function alias and deprecate tostring.

PyArray_ToString is not yet deprected in this PR, but should probably also be in favor of a more descriptive name.

I'm not sure if we should really deprecate tostring, it would force rdepends to add checks for both names if they want to support older versions without warnings.
We might also want an equivalent frombytes that does not accept strings for symmetry, but currently fromstring seems works for bytes and strings as it can also read formated strings instead of only raw bytes.

title: f2py sometimes generates python3-incompatible C wrappings
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/drwells', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3917035?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'drwells', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3917035, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/drwells/followers'}
body:
f2py uses deprecated CPython functions (notably `PyString_FromStringAndSize`) when wrapping callbacks with string parameters. An example is the FORTRAN-77 subroutine

```fortran
       SUBROUTINE BUG(CALLBACK, A)
          IMPLICIT NONE
          EXTERNAL CALLBACK
          DOUBLE PRECISION CALLBACK
          DOUBLE PRECISION A
          CHARACTER*1 R
          R = 'R'
!f2py intent(out) A
          A = CALLBACK(R)
       END SUBROUTINE
```
compiled with

    f2py -c -m bug test.f # on Arch Linux, this is the python3 version of f2py

with the Python wrapping

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
from __future__ import print_function
import bug

def callback(code):
    if code == 'F':
        return 2.0
    else:
        return 3.0

print(bug.bug(callback))
```

Calling the Python2 version of `f2py` and running the script under Python 2.7 yields the correct answer. However, under Python3 we get

```
~/Documents/Code/Fortran/f2pyBug $ python3 test.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 4, in <module>
    import bug
ImportError: /home/drwells/Documents/Code/Fortran/f2pyBug/bug.cpython-33m.so: undefined symbol: PyString_FromStringAndSize
```

I tested this under Arch Linux (fully updated) with Python 3.3.3 and Python 2.7.6. In both cases I used Numpy 1.8. I also tested this under Ubuntu (Quantal) with Python 3.2.3 and Python 2.7.3. In both cases I used Numpy 1.6.2.

title: `PyArray_CheckFromAny` with `NPY_ARRAY_NOTSWAPPED` changes the byte order of single byte types
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
The following example demonstrates what's going on:

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> np.dtype(np.uint8).byteorder
'|'
>>> a = np.arange(5, dtype=np.uint8)
>>> a.searchsorted(a)
array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], dtype=int64)
>>> np.dtype(np.uint8).byteorder
'='
```
The change is caused by searchsorted calling `PyArray_CheckFromAny` with the `NPY_ARRAY_NOTSWAPPED ` flag set [here](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/core/src/multiarray/item_selection.c#L2109). There the dtype gets its byteorder set to `NPY_NATIVE`, even if it originally was set to `NPY_IGNORE` as is the case with single byte types, see [here](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/core/src/multiarray/ctors.c#L1842).

After the byte order of `np.uint8` has been changed `np.core.test()` returns 21 failures, due to mistmatches between the expected and actual encodings of dtypes, e.g.:

```
======================================================================
FAIL: test_complex_dtype_repr (test_dtype.TestString)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\WinPython-64bit-2.7.6.2\python-2.7.6.amd64\lib\site-packages\numpy\core\tests\test_dtype.py", line 411, in test_complex_dtype_repr
    "dtype([(('Red pixel', 'r'), 'u1'), "
  File "C:\WinPython-64bit-2.7.6.2\python-2.7.6.amd64\lib\site-packages\numpy\testing\utils.py", line 317, in assert_equal
    raise AssertionError(msg)
AssertionError: 
Items are not equal:
 ACTUAL: "dtype([(('Red pixel', 'r'), '<u1'), (('Green pixel', 'g'), '<u1'), (('Blue pixel', 'b'), '<u1')], align=True)"
 DESIRED: "dtype([(('Red pixel', 'r'), 'u1'), (('Green pixel', 'g'), 'u1'), (('Blue pixel', 'b'), 'u1')], align=True)"

======================================================================
```

I have solved it within #4244 by adding an explicit check for `NPY_IGNORE` in `PyArray_CheckFromAny`, i.e.:

```
if (descr && descr->byteorder != NPY_IGNORE) {
    descr->byteorder = NPY_NATIVE;
}
```

While it seems to handle this particular case, I am unsure if other cases need to be handled, and whether this should be fixed in a separate PR.

title: BUG: IRR was returning nan instead of valid negative answer, and returni...
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/peliot', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6125745?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'peliot', 'type': u'User', 'id': 6125745, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/peliot/followers'}
body:
...ng array instead of float

This change corrects the following two bugs in numpy.irr:
* When the solution was negative, numpy.irr returned nan instead of the correct solution because of the mask applied to the roots. Corrected by removing the mask that 0 < res < 1.
* When multiple roots were found, numpy.irr was returning an array of all roots rather than a single float. This bug was corrected by selecting the single root closest to zero (min(abs(root)).

With these corrections, numpy.irr returns the same result as the corresponding spreadsheet function in LibreOffice Calc for all test cases (additional test cases were added to cover cases with multiple positive and negative roots)

title: numpy.allclose fails with smallest negative integer as 2nd argument
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/sklam', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1929845?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'sklam', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1929845, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/sklam/followers'}
body:
The line (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/843792b6d349133114930911424772e6bbbc0c9c/numpy/core/numeric.py#L2157):

```
r = all(less_equal(abs(x-y), atol + rtol * abs(y)))
```

abs(y) can be negative if y contains the smallest negative integer.

The following demonstrates the problem:
```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> a=np.int32(-2147483648) 
>>> a
-2147483648
>>> a==a
True
>>> abs(a)
-2147483648
>>> np.allclose(a, a)
False
```

title: BUG: fix scalar type memory leak
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
have an explicit tp_free that is different from PyObject_Free which is also the
tp_free of PyBaseObject so python does not COPYSLOT it, instead it takes the
next parent PyInt which has a different allocator.
Also added it for arrays just in case, currently not required as they don't
don't inherit from a python type.

title: BUG: check for monotonic bin arrays in digitize
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jaimefrio', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3343990?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jaimefrio', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3343990, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jaimefrio/followers'}
body:
The check for monotonic bin arrays of `digitize` doesn't properly handle
inputs with repeated entries at the beginning of the array:

```
>>> np.__version__
'1.8.0'
>>> np.digitize([1], [0, 0 , 2])
array([2], dtype=int64)
>>> np.digitize([1], [2, 2, 0])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ValueError: The bins must be monotonically increasing or decreasing
```

Modified `check_array_monotonic` in `_compiled_base.c` to skip over repeating
entries before deciding to check for increasing or decreasing monotonicity
and added relevant tests to `test_function_base.py`.
